Many times the flow of blood from an artery that had been cut and was outside or near to a vein; it could happen by cutting oneself with sharp instruments, or by cautery on the member itself; such things cause difficulty in removing him (i.e., the blood).
Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	 "Then, if the needle passes through to that place where your hand is placed over the opening of an artery and you put forth your finger there: then grasp it firmly with both hands until blood comes out of it; otherwise, do not let go.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then take a large oil lamp and set the wick on fire with it; then blow out the flame by holding it above what you are aiming at until the flame goes out.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one of them - a small one or a large one depending on the location where the artery has been cut and place the cautery over that spot immediately after you have removed your finger; then hold it until blood stops flowing from there.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If you expel the needle along with your finger from the opening of an artery and extinguish the cautery, then take another one immediately after extinguishing it; from the cauteries that have been prepared by fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Do not do this with just one other one until blood stops flowing.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And if you touch the inflamed wound nearby and apply another cautery to it instead.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And you know that when blood flows from an artery, it is not possible to remove it; especially if the artery is large unless you use four methods at once.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery as we mentioned before.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction when it is not possible to remove the object.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 If an object is extracted out of them (the fingers), their extremities are cramped and blood stops flowing from there.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or placed upon it medicines to stop the bleeding and tie it down using an appropriate constriction of veins so that it does not become loose or fall off.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 Whoever administers the excision with a ligature, and a tie down using cloth or something else, or by placing things on top of it, he should not apply excessive pressure to prevent pain unless very rarely necessary.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 If the person to whom that is done does not have a physician at hand and no medicine: then let it be placed over the opening of the vein in question as we described before, and by constriction of his own veins until blood stops flowing above the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 The finger is not removed immediately upon contact with cold water; it remains frozen for a long time and becomes swollen, hard, and falls off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 In the meantime you should examine whether there was an injury or some medicine that caused this condition.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 The end of the first part
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Chapter 2: On Surgery
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 Chapter 2: Of incisions, perforations, and phlebotomies of veins, and the like
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 I am the tenth book of Albucasis and my purpose is to explain everything about cautery in medical practice.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And placed here chapters up to the foot.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 I proceed through this chapter with the same path, so that he may be relieved of whatever was asked for him.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before beginning this chapter, it is necessary that you know the offspring of what was mentioned in Chapter 1 on cautery, as it should be a warning to them.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And for this reason it is necessary that the caution be more severe, because in operation which takes place here there are many deaths of people from bleeding and all other causes mentioned earlier.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 I warn you that if something like this happens to any of you, then when they fall into the same art with the weakness of people, there can be death too.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 From these is he who becomes angry with his own pain and death occurs from him through the severity of this and the length of it, as a result of its bitterness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And when there are pain and fear that mean death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 From these is he who gives himself over to his own pain and says it with him, hoping for healing but the severity of his pain is harmful.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 "You should treat him with kindness who has come among you from those people whose method is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Your caution must be greater than your desire and your greediness
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 Do not boast over anything from him unless after certain knowledge that would have benefited you in the successful outcome which occurred because of his method.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 You should apply your skills to the care and management of all the sick people's health, using predictions and indications as needed for what is more beneficial for their welfare.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 That man among you shall be your teacher in acquiring fame and glory, memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 The God inspired you sons, his mind and gave no guidance or suggestions to you because it was only in his own hand that this happened
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 I have also given you this chapter distinguishing it by the chapters of Cautery as far down to your feet so that you may know what is to be done from him and what benefits you.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 Of the care of waters which are gathered up among children
Caput I.	 Chapter 1
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Remember that this illness has often struck children at birth or when the mother's womb is tight without release.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 And also when it occurs from an obscure cause which cannot be known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 I did not find this disease to be as severe in others than in children, and death came upon everyone who was affected by it; for that is why I wish to withdraw the use of my treatment from them.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 I also knew of a child whose head was bound with water and it was adorned with beauty every day until he could not stay upon himself because of the greatness of his head; and dampness increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this disease also appears when moisture gathers between skin and mouth or beneath bones above the nose.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 The operation on that should be performed when there is moisture between the skin and mouth or beneath the bones above the nose; it must occur so that a cut made at the top of the head in breadth occurs, and its length should be like two fingers until the dampness runs.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 This is the form of a sponge
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If therefore humidity increases more, and the sponge becomes larger, then make two cuts along this shape
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if humidity is below bone and its sign shows that the corners of your head are open on all sides; water will descend when you compress it with your hand to the inside, but not be hidden from you: then you should find three cuts in the middle of the top of the head, as shown.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 After cutting out the humidity
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then tie up the cuts with gauze and cotton.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then wrap it over with wine, oil, and olive oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 After that, remove the bandage and care for wounds along with linen and ointment.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not tie up your head in an uneven manner.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 And make sure to keep the body as dry as possible and use any available moisture until the member is comfortable and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another way of cutting it is that you consider where the size of the sponge becomes visible and collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Sometimes when there are cuts on one side or another, or in both hands/arms.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore ascend with the incision where you see the sponge and pull out water; then it will be done in a way that is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And be careful not to cut the artery and cause blood flow stoppage; or else the member may die from that loss of fluid with the removal of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 Of the cuts in arteries which are behind ears.
Caput II.	 The head (second part).
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 If cuts occur on the eye or nose and become infected; then more than ever is the final care for it as a last resort, cutting of both arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore when you see that he has cut them to remove his own head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then cover the place with a bandage so that the arteries are visible.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 "Then he ties his own arm with a bandage.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 "And then he considers where to apply the bandage.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And his two hands are tied behind his ears and are rare unless some men have them.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 "Then he puts a bandage made of wax on both his hands and smashes them with nails or picks up the corners to remove it from his face, inserting it through the slit in the back of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 "And if he is lying down, he puts a bandage made of wax under his arm and cuts it off above with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 The length of the incision should be as close to two fingers joined together as possible.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 "When one is cut open, blood flows out through a narrow slit that runs up the center of his body.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 If an artery is not visible to him (the surgeon), then he should measure from the ear how far three fingers would be apart and insert the bandage at that distance into his body.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 "Then he puts a bandage made of wax all the way up to his nose.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 The object that should be emitted with blood is six finger-breadths and at most it can be emitted from him more than or less than this.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 "That bandage should always be placed in accordance with the amount that is visible to you through your examination and pressing on his arteries, as much or more than this.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 "Then he considers where to remove it from the nose.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 "Then if anything remains at his nose after having removed the bandage made of wax, then he cuts it off and ties up that part of the face with linen.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 "And then he applies a treatment by anointing him with oil until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 "In the extraction of arteries, which are located behind his ears.
Caput III.	 Chapter three
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 "When a man has an old or acute catarrh of the ears due to acrimonious moisture and coldness of the lacrimal canals, or due to soda or other things that irritate him (the surgeon), he must be treated with medical methods, without causing any harm: then we are skilled in his treatment of extracting arteries from behind his ears, as we have been taught.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 The method of removing ears is as follows: first, the surgeon severs the hairs which are within a certain time limit and aims for an artery which lies close to it
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 The pulse test is performed on you by means of your own pulse and is rare unless only a few men are involved or there is coldness causing it.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If the pulse test shows that you should be examined by an attendant with a cloth to remove fear and apply it gently.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or if there is warmth in place after removing the cloth then immediately show your face for immediate inspection.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take it gently as I made before a short time ago
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Afterwards wash with that cloth in a hurry until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Afterwards remove it quickly and take it out to the top part until you pull it off from your skin, then tie it up securely below that with whatever is under it on all sides.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If the artery is shallow then immediately take it out quickly with your nail.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Afterwards cut off a piece as large as the parts of his extremities and tie them together securely so that no blood flows through it.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 If not cut off or removed then there will be no bleeding from the artery.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Afterwards wash with water until you reach 6-3-
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large then you must tie it with two or three ropes, firm and strong, from either a cord or a strip so that no blood flows through after tying, to prevent decay of the flesh before healing wounds and to ensure no blood flow.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Afterwards cut off any excess between two ropes.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this during that time or at another time.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish then sear it with a cautery until reaching the mouth using a cautery and tie it up securely once his extremities are cut off to ensure its location for that purpose.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 And if the surgeon is ill or the face becomes red then a better method must be used.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because of the cautery is from those who go to end the dampness
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it's better
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 After extraction of arteries, let there be placed on an old vein and put the pulp down gently on top of it
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after curing with dry medicines which cause to be born meat, and with vinegar until they are cured.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation there was a sudden bleeding from an artery, then immediately apply it with a cautery or else take out what you have grasped and stop the blood with vinegar.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If nothing is present among these things to you at this time, then put your finger over the place and until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And cover it with cold water and let it cool down and be bound as needed.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And that which is better and easier to remove from the artery is with a cautery holding two hooks together so that both their sharpness are equal in strength.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 However, smaller knives have less force than two hooks.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Because if they are sharp like the two hooks, it is equally to each side so that they do not cut through meat with pressure.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Therefore there is some excess of fat and heat in them and they are burned with fire or else the meat is cut off quickly, but because of this therefore it's better for all operations and more so.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 And place what is between two hooks the size of your fingers after you put both places with encaustic wax and leave them to burn until they come out at their own mouth, or else cut off one in two different places so that it can be stretched as long as it extends from his extremities.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 Because the pain is not relieved with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 This is how the cautery works.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 On curing of tears from eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Caput IV
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When there are excessive tears and the course of them is from within the ears, which are over the outer sides of the head's skull; and nothing was done for their cure with medicines, but they see a reddening in front of themselves: and it feels a movement on its forehead like that of scraping off scabs: and their eyes become moist, as if corroded by corrosion. And the eyelashes of them are heated from excessive tears, then those who were treating them did so through this operation, and called it treatment, using "Ensay".
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 It is also that the very hairs on their forehead may be removed by a certain ailment/disease
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then there are three cuts equally spaced horizontally across the forehead; and their length is nearly equal to two fingers' breadth each, one cut being midway along the nasal bone: another cut following just behind the motion of tears: the third cut at a part which is opposite from the second: then come blood vessels on both sides: and stretch your hand out by the length of both lower jaws. The total amount of all incisions is three fingers joined together, so that you may take sponges or many cloths soaked with blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then introduce sharp pointed sticks in pairs to which their form follows.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the cut at the part of the ear to the second one: and shave with that all the way through to the cut between two incisions, up towards the nose.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do this as well from the middle cut to the second one.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then remove that with a pair of sharp sticks and introduce the same cutting tool again for the first cut from another part which is not pointed: but use an actual cutting tool for removing from another part which is pointed.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 Then he puts the cutting tool into their ear with flesh on one side and then removes it leaving only the nose for them to pull out; and then pushes him towards the middle cut, until they reach that which appears from the flesh: except when there is a cut all the way up to where we see something coming.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 In the middle of a wound until another cut is made
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 After the flow of blood becomes equal to that expressed through the coagulated wounds, express it from the severed vessels with forceps
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then apply a bandage over all the cuts made and bind it firmly to the severed vessels with sutures; and press upon it a mixture of powdered alum, vinegar or acetic acid.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And be sure that the cold compresses are not too cold.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 On the third day use a ligature and administer an infusion of warm water several times.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then apply that with the ointment of the basilisk [a healing ointment made from various herbs] to all those in need; and let them gradually heal.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 For eye drops, nose drops, and throat drops applied from the inside of the head [the sinuses].
Caput V.	 Head V
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone has a sudden attack of the eyes and nose drops, and in his aspect there is a weakening; and the eyelids are ulcerated, the hairs fall off from them, and at that place [the head] there is an acute pain, severe, and the result thereof: then remove these things which have been mentioned, as they will not come through any other means but by many vessels.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 And the cure for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 So that you may strongly pull at your face.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make one incision in the middle of your face, or slightly higher and to the right; and begin with a cut at the left side of the nose until you reach the mouth. And stretch out your hand towards the lips, which move during mastication: until you have reached the mouth. When you have reached it, you will extract all the blood through a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then make an incision between the lips with old linen or with linen cloth.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind a bandage over it and press upon it a mixture of powdered alum, vinegar, or acetic acid to prevent cold from causing shock.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 When it has warmed up and you see that the tip of the hook is ready to be inserted into flesh (carp), then it should be removed from water so that it may begin to grow inside the flesh
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then take care of it while you are regulating the heat so that it makes flesh grow (carp): just as if you were to pull apart two parts from a mixture of wheat flour and four parts from colophonium, and prepare an implement using those parts, and administer them in order to bring the meat into being on these hooks.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 Take care of it when it has fallen down inside the hook (carp).
Caput VI.	 The sixth part is the head, which contains two cavities: one for air and one for water.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls down inside the hook (carp) is divided into four species: a mineral stone or a pebble like iron; earth and water are also included in this category: anything that comes from plants, such as wine from grapes, bread made of wheat; water itself, as well as vinegar.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 Therefore when a mineral stone falls inside the hook (carp), or if there is no addition to its species so that it does not grow within the hook, just remove the hook from water and observe whether you see a pebble: in such a case distill something from olive oil, or sesame seed.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer the extraction of it and make it grow with care, and pull up the nostrils towards the entrance of the nose after placing a hook (carp) on the ears, or wool, and raise the hook to its highest point.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 Many things will be attributed with this kind of care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If not, then administer the extraction of it using a gesture (carp), that is, you pull back his head by subtle motions with such a shape as this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If so attributed to him after the gesture, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not with a gesture (carp), then administer the extraction of it using a blind touch by subtle strokes in two directions.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If not with a blind touch by the gesture (carp), then make a hook from feathers and let its tip enter deeply into the ear opening and pull it out forcefully through your strong grip after loosening it gently with oil, so that no injury occurs to the ear: unless you use a hook.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 "For one reason I am delighted that you have come.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If not, then you must take it from the skullcap or from my hand, that is to say, prepare gluten, with which we cut the vein; and afterwards put this into your forearm just below where you had placed it badly when you were holding on too firmly. Afterwards introduce it into the earhole with ease, after you have shaken off the moisture of the ear.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 Therefore if I am not delighted with everything that we have taken [i.e., the vein], then quickly prepare a hot chisel or any other suitable instrument to cut it off before removing the hook.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 And the method of the incision is so that first you make an incision into the head; and remove him from the blood according to his measure of strength he has.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Afterwards let the weak one rest between your hands; and gently pull his ear up to its highest point; find the incision in the root of the ear near his cheekbone; and make a slit into the ear's figure, until you have reached the stone: then take him with those instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Afterwards seal up the incision at your time when it is ready; and look after her carefully until she has healed completely.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If something falls into the ear from one of many growing growths that are there and inflate; then administer an extraction for him/her.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 If it does not go out to you with the thin, gentle, subtle manner, then take a very small, fine one according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And administer the removal of this kind from growths that fall into the ear and do not make it if you think that this one is already moistened through the moisture of the ear because of the swelling; wait until you place it on his/her forehead; then take her out with hooks, or with gentle, subtle, precise movements.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 If something falls into the ear from water, let the weak one breathe with a nosebleed first; and already closed his/her ear because of some old clot; he/she is lying above her, where there was moisture.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 Therefore I have learned that this is good
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 If not then take many stones according to the length of your fingers, thin, light ones and set them ablaze with fire, and introduce one into his ear using a stone from that part [left side] for healing; after this strike him on the foot with another stone placed above it in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore, I will not stop doing that until he is entirely healed with a stone and another.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 I have already learned water so that you take one from a bowl or jug and introduce it into his ear; you set ablaze the extremity of another with fire until all parts are consumed.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then you take another with a tube as prescribed and draw out the one that has been burned into the stone; you will do this many times until he is entirely healed by water.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 In extracting an animal which is too small for the body, you pour it out as you would from a vessel; and to him who has received such care, treat him similarly by drawing out.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it is a large body which appears to the senses; then administer the extraction of him with a hand gesture and tweezers; and as for them who have received such care, it will be easier for them than those held in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 In extracting the uremic excrements from the ear when you have cured him as prescribed by distillation and not conferred care; then it is necessary that you scratch his ear with a finger.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 If therefore something appears there from the excrements, then draw out this one with a gesture or with tweezers.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 If however nothing appears there, then take a tube as prescribed; the shape of which is narrow below and wide above; and introduce the delicate extremity into the ear according to how much that can be tolerated by the patient. Afterwards suck with it strongly.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 Do this many times until all excrements have been extracted.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 If they refuse to obey you at your departure, then they should be tied up with cords as I described it on stone
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 If they do not comply with what we have said, then administer the distilled substances which are now expert at infecting wounds and use them according to the treatment of distillations.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let there be a shower for you with olive oil and medicines on top with this instrument which shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 As I showed you before from the bronze or air below the narrow one where the hole of the ear is, above the broad one.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 So that it pushes what is within the corded cannula away from the air and down lower.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 If you are on fire and receive the water; then pour into that which is at its end with a gentle movement of the hand, so as to send the oil or syrup towards it through the cannula; thereafter let there be heated up by fire above, and then come out cooled down from the flame. And what is poured in the ear should now become hot, as if ignited by fire, so that no thing which is distilled may remain cold, for medicines do not tolerate this.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 Of the care of hair loss accidents ears.
Caput VII.	 The seventh head
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 When some infants come from the parents who have not been perforated.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 And it has also happened to some people that loss of hair happens because there was injury at the ear or from birth.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this loss of hair occurs sometimes in the deep hole at the ear which is not due to us; and sometimes it happens from the outside holes barely, and it follows that one.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, those who it has happened at the deep hole of the ear and does not understand the aspect, are very difficult to heal many ways.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And for those who it follows us because of an injury at the ear hole, it is necessary to put the ear in the hand with its face down and wash gently; if you see the loss of hair appear, open her with a small brush which shape is this which follows, place your thumb on his extremity where there is some slight latitude, sharp part also exists. And what remains after that should be washed by two hands lightly so as not to burn it.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 The opening of an artery from skin to ear is done with an incision made delicately and cutting it easily after applying a certain substance that facilitates the process until complete severance of the flesh occurs.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If the opening is in the deep ear: Then take a small needle and thread it through delicately, until you have heated it over fire to harden it; then move it into the ear canal.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you are performing surgery using this tool and it becomes worn out because of frequent use with hearing impairment, then repair the opening for him carefully to avoid ear pain
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 After placing the ligature in the ear according to its size opening and piercing it with an awl from Egypt: let this be done for several days until the swelling is settled.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take the ligature and immerse it in hot water, then squeeze over it vinegar juice, until you mix them together; after that use this mixture to suture him up.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you are removing the ligature already: then remove it immediately and allow it to be mixed with another ligature that has been soaked in olive oil, until the heated ligature is cooled down; after that, take good care of it so that it can heal completely.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If you have a burst artery: Then immerse the sponge or cloth in cold water and place it over his head; after that use the remaining cure to stop the blood flow which was cut off by this distillation treatment.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 On how to heal eyes.
Caput VIII.	 The eighth chapter of the book on head surgery.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 Those who fall into the eyes and sometimes become wet or dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore you should hold them with tweezers; or with a needle and thread the eye and cut it at its root.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 After that apply vinegar juice to the location.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If blood flows from them: then burn them with a small, fine cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And after cutting them it is better to burn them.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 "Many become infected when a part of their roots is severed.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 If they are burned with fire, the roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 For healing of eyes
Caput IX.	 Head 9
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 Many is damaged to the eyes something which is like Ceado with its strength and firmness, because of that it is called Grando; and there is an accumulation of large moisture on the upper eyelid and lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 Therefore operation on them is necessary, so that you consider when Grando proceeds to it what appears from the eyelid and move to all parts of it; for his is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Then find a fissure across the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then smooth it all around with ease until it is gone.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then suspend it with a hook and remove it.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 If the separation of his part is not prepared for you except after you penetrate the eyelid with a more powerful incision then that will be harmful to him somewhere.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If there is a large fissure, then bind it firmly with stitching and heal it until it becomes well.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if the fracture is small, you will not suffer evil from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 It was restored and reborn.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 If Grando is removed from the inner surface of the ear to its outer surface then the eyelid should be turned inward and suspended with a hook except where you cut it and remove it completely around.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 If the eyelid is stretched by an incision, it will not be harmful somewhere.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then close the eye after Grando's removal with salty water and heal the place where it was reborn until the injured one has healed.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 For healing of eyes
Caput X.	 Head 10
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 Axirnath is a swelling that occurs in the upper eyelids of children; and it happens to many boys, causing tears from them morning by morning, so they are not able to look at the sun because their eyes become swollen, hence there were always tears flowing from them, and also the swelling was under the eyebrows which was caused by the inflation. And its great prominence is noticeable on the eye when you touch it with your fingers, and then you feel Axirnath between those two eyelids.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 To perform an operation you should place his head in your hand
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 After receiving the sheet with incisions and tying it around his neck, proceed to cut off the head according to the quantity contained in the Axirnath from every part of him.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 Then place him upon it and fasten his head with your hands around the middle of the circle so that Axirnath will be centered within it.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 After this, find the center of his moisture with a spit-like instrument and make an incision according to depth so that no incision is made for phlebotomy into the deep parts.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 Or perhaps you should find a complete cut and pass it on to Axirnath with many incisions so that Axirnath proceeds from the incision according to the shape of the white part's edges.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 Then take the sheet away with your hands and spread it out between yours so that they can be separated; proceed to not include an incision lest you may cut off his eye, tie him back up
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 If however the shape of Axirnath is not apparent to you at first incision, proceed with the incision only slightly
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then remove it as we described.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 After removing the sheet with vinegar and water, place them upon a spot, and tie him up tightly.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And there are those who have taken the salt and placed it into the incision so that it may dissolve what remains of the moisture from before.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 After this, take care of her until she is healed.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 If however he falls into a hot place bind him tightly with satiated plasters so that he may be healed.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 In the mode of Axirnath to the eye, which means with a relaxation of the eyelid so that it moves like it should not
Caput XI.	 The 11th Head
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When there are hairs added to the eyelashes of the eye that grow beyond their course under natural hairs and are equal in number: at this point they harm the eye by striking it with blows like tears and causing irritation of the eyelids and dryness, until this occurs as a cause for destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 "And for curing eye ailments, there are four modes.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 With fire cautery.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with a lancet and acute medicine, as described in the chapter on cauteries.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 And for curing eye ailments using incisions and stitches (sutures).
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 Or with tubes, as I say.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 It is to be placed on the head of a physician into your hand.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then, with the left hand cover the eye socket.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 If it is so done, then it's good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if not: pull the thread from beneath the eyelid as it is and make it penetrate through with a needle and tie to the eyebrow ridge; that is, to the hair's head, i.e., to the eyebrow margin where hairs are born; and draw the thread up to the top of the eye as you cover her with your hand.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find it in the inner part of the eyelid, under hairs added due to spit and tears running down to the tears below; then you will have reached the tear duct lower than the tear ducts themselves.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then draw it out and place beneath the eyelid a small knot made of wax or cloth; then take signs over the eye with charcoal, as it is like the shape of a mourning wreath.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, let its figure be according to the quantity and elevation of the eyelid; because it has already been diversified among men.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 These are done by those who make incisions into large portions from the eyelid according to how much the eyelids have been softened.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then find it above two lines that you have drawn and start at the tear duct lower than tears itself down to tears; and there should be a single hole near natural hairs as large as the radius of your hand is wide.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then introduce it into one of two angles of skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 And then you are done.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Finally bind the lips closed with a double fold of thread and needle thin linen; and remove blood, so that you do not exceed what is left on both sides by the threads above two eyebrows, if it can be done: and if not, then do not cure.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 "If you remove sutures after three days at the latest, or four.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 "And if there is a wound without sutures, then take care of it with oil and vinegar so that it may be dried up and tightened.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 "The eyelid swells upon the swelling around the wound, but recovery is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 "This manner of treatment was used by ancient physicians.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 "However, there is a lot of effort on the sick person and good work does not create fear.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 "And another way of treatment is in Ataxmir as well; and it is so that there are signs above the eyelid shaped like a leaf cut out, just like we know.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 "After the eyelid swells apart from three strands or together with four, according to its shape which follows then you cut off what is left over using small cuts in the same way as before.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 "If you cannot hold onto one thread and it does not match well then take the other thread in your hand and put it into the middle of the shape; and put another thread on its way towards tears more, and one thread on its way to tears less: and gather the threads between your fingers with equality.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 "After you have gathered both hands equally then take a thread above the one that is marked out as before in the same way.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 "Then gather two lips together with sutures and care for it until it gets better.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 "If you accidentally cut the eyelid when making your incision or tearing it then apply oil and vinegar to it.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 "And sometimes eyelids also occur where hair grows out of them.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 "Therefore, it is advised to use sutures as we mentioned before the incision; but stitching more than one is artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 "About curing of Ataxmir with animals.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 "And it is so that you apply oil and vinegar to the eyelid, and cut off any cuts that have come out in the same way as before.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 In the art of making two hooks or two thin rods, their length should be according to the length of the eyelid and their width shall be less than that of a very small sponge; you have already made an incision at both ends where you hold them together
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 After attaching both ends to the eyelid using a thin rod in excess of that which is available from the eyeball's eyelid, and after binding them with strong thread on both sides, you should release it at intervals over several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 The tightened skin will die (die) and become emaciated, and will decompose unless it is released itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If this occurs late then make an incision with hooks.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 After which you must take care of it so that it may heal.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 Once they are secured together the eyelid will become firm; and hairs will not be pulled out.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the shape of two hooks that you should make according to this figure, quantity being in length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 With the pulling out of hairs from the eye with sharpness
Caput XII.	 The end
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 Operation is performed on this as you take a thin thread and introduce it into the eye from its edge with great care.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 After attaching both ends to him, then tie each end of the thin cord firmly and let one thread be as long as a finger.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 After joining them together with another thin thread below him for a short time, then tie off the ends of his fingers tightly
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 After you have placed your head inside your hand and it is close to the sun, for this operation is thin or small in size.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 After you have introduced the thread at the root of the eyelid and made it penetrate further into the eyelid with force, until you remove it from above a natural hair.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 After removing the thread up to where you have introduced it, then introduce another thread at this point or somewhere above that, either one or two or three threads, not more than these.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then take your finger with him, until he gets away from under his hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 If his hair is pulled back after taking your finger, and he does not get away from under it: take that same finger to the lower eyelid, using a thread you prepared earlier, until he gets away from under his hair; then pull him towards the upper eyelid with the other hand, so that both eyes are covered. When this has been done, remove the eye patch as described above, and in three days or more it will grow back over its place on his forehead, restoring him to normal health.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is very short, then attach it to his longer hairs with those of nature and tie him down as mentioned above; or remove him immediately if you want to shorten them quickly, until they reach their full length, after which remove him again.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 Of the causes that may occur in the eyelid above.
Caput XIII.	 The Thirteenth Head
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this happens to an eye, it is called Leporinia.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 This eye patch can be either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 Accidental causes include injuries caused by blows to the face, cutting off his eyelids with scissors, or tearing them in wrestling matches or similar situations.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 The mode of operation is as follows: to find a thread between the eyelids and sew it up so that his eyes are closed, until he recovers from this injury.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 Do not neglect the need for treatment of any injury that causes pain or constriction when he is being operated on; since if you do this, his eye patch will be worse than before, use such remedies to soften them as a poultice made from fennel leaves soaked in water, rubbed with ointment of unguentum dyaquilon, which has been made by mixing it with olive oil. And bind him up tightly and carefully, so that the treatment is complete, or you will be unable to remove his eye patch even if he recovers from the injury.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 Your treasure trove of treatments is as follows: you must apply your ingenuity and not let him get sewn up again in the way it was at first; but rather use a poultice made from fennel leaves soaked in water, rubbed with unguentum dyaquilon ointment that has been made by mixing olive oil.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 "This operation is not mentioned in our previous discussion, but rather a correction by Albucasis to prevent the form from becoming distorted according to what was originally intended.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 "The treatment of the lower eyelid by Albucasis is either a fold or contraction upwards towards the right and left sides.
Caput XIIII.	 The number 12, in Roman numerals.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 "The treatment of the lower eyelid by Albucasis is called the 'treatment of Albucasis.'
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 "It's natural and accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 "Accidental injuries can occur through a wound or tear, or by other means similar to these.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 "The path of this operation is to grasp the doubled thread and pull it through to the skin, then cut it so that it penetrates into both sides of the nose up to both sides of the tear.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 "Then stretch out the meat upwards with a knife on one side and cut it, then use your other hand as well.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 "If this operation causes the eyelid to conform to what is expected, it is beneficial.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 "If the eyelid was not corrected properly then grasp a rod and put it in a tear, hold the eye lid so that you make two tears on the inner corner of the eyelid, and find both tears at the ends from which angles the incision occurs. Until they meet and become one figure: until when they are made into these figures is the Greek letter 'L'. It means 'good luck'.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 "Then stretch out that meat from its inferior thickness downwards towards the eye.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 "Then bring together the separate parts: hold it with a thread of linen.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 "And then perform the treatment as mentioned before in our discussion about mollifying medicines and applying ointments until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 "And if Albucasis caused a tear or cut it then you should apply a patch until the flat tear is found below the eyebrow hair, as well as according to what came before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate between two lips with a hook, as we have stated before
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 And at the end of a patient's care, when it is superior or inferior to his operation, it should be performed according to what has been prepared from the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 The shape of each part is different: and a prudent artificer prepares the body with whatever way it can be done, until he has directed the figure to its natural form or direction towards it, or even to that which is impaired; and the same infirmity, according to what was agreed upon by his operation and instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 The detachment of the eyelids from the conjunctiva or the cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter Fifteen.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 When this occurs in many men, the fixation of the upper eyelid with the whites of the eyes should be done so that it may not be hindered by its own natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore you must insert the extremities of your fingers under the eyelid and hold it up: or extend it with a hook; then cut through to its detachment with a small sharp tool, so that it is not hindered by the sharpness of the incision, rather being obtuse than blunt: in order not to disturb the patient during operation, and remove it gently, and anoint the eye with your own fluid; and make an incision as you release it from its attachment gradually, until when returned to its natural form, and become whole again.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then drop into the eye some salty water, or distill it from its own juice if you are able to do so with water alone.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a hook liner; and place over the eye a moistened cloth lined with white linen; and after three days use it along with solids, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 Chapter Sixteen.
Caput XVI.	 Of the incision of the eyelids and prominence of the cheeks in weeping.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 It is done according to two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 "It is a gentle thing and it is similar in strength to a sinew.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 "It is not a gentle thing and it resembles frozen white frost; when touched by iron or grasped with an awl, it splits apart and does not stick to the awl.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 "The two do not begin to grow together unless they are wetted with more tears, until it yields gradually and stops the flow of light, and moves the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 "The method of using this substance is as follows: you place a weakened head into your own hand, or put it between your fingers.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 "Then you open the eyes by touching them with your hand.
