Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If anything contrary to your benefit arises from cutting into an artery, or one of the veins: then cauterize that vein; until blood is withdrawn.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then attend to him with the remaining care, until he has recovered.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	 The end of treatment for hydropsy
Caput LIIII.	 Epilogue
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	 We have finished the treatment of hydropsy as described above; and so it is with all its signs, and the care for him along with his medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	 Only the treatment of hydropsy with iron is finished; and it does not come close to the treatment of the earache, nor comes near to that of tinnitus (ringing in the ears); or it does not reach for the shortness of breath caused by hypo-sarcosis: this would be fatal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	 When you have finished treating hydropsy tinnitus with medicines, and did not affect the treatment by your medicine; then consider it.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	 If there is some weakness or other illness after hydropsy; as if it were with him another affliction beyond hydropsy, just like if he were tired and needed to drink water, or anything else of that sort; then make sure you do not treat him with iron: because this would be terrible.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	 However, if there is some excess of strength that weakens him; it does not come near to weakness because of hydropsy alone: nor the child, nor the old man either: then you must find a way for treatment in him as he sits between your hands, and the nurse afterwards expresses his drink towards lower part of stomach.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	 "Then take a small and thin skewer.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	 "Slice the two larger arteries (or veins) as sharp as possible, then slice the thinner one at its tip like a toothpick.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	 "However, be careful of some small break that may occur while passing it through the operation up to the intestine, and put a bandage on it.
Deinde considera.	 "Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	 "If generation is through the abdominal part of the intestine, then it should be stretched with a three-finger incision from below to above its belly.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	 "If generation is due to weakness in the liver, then your left section should be made from below with three fingers.
Et si generatio eius est propter splenem, tunc sit sectio in latere dextro: et non oportet etiam ut sit sectio in latere super quod uult iacere infirmus, ut non currant superfluitates ad illum locum debilem.	 "And if the generation is due to weakness, then make a cut on the right side; and it should not be made so deep that he who is weak cannot pass them through.
Deinde perfora cum instrumento cutem totam.	 "Then proceed with your tool to complete the cut.
Deinde intromitte in illam sectionem, et eleua manum tuam cum Spatumili inter cutem, et sifac, quasi tu excories ipsum: et sit quantitas quae excoriatur quantitas unguis, aut circiter ilud.	 "Then introduce your hand into the cut and press it in like manner as you saw before.
Deinde perfora sifac, donec perueniat Spatumile ad locum uacuum: et est locus aquae.	 "Then pierce the skewer through until there is a void place; then the water will flow out of that place.
Deinde extrahe ipsum, et intromitte in foramen instrumentum, cuius haec est forma.	 "Then take it out and introduce your tool with its shape into the hole.
Et est simile cannulae: fit ex argento, aut aere, aut aurichalco, lene, tersum: cui in inferiori parte sui est foramen paruum, et in lateribus eius sunt tria foramina, duo ab una parte, et unum a parte altera: et facia est extremitas eius incisa, secundum modum incisionis calami, sicut uides: in extremitate eius superiore est armilla.	 "It is like a straw; it can be withdrawn through air or water, or by a mixture of both, the lower part being open and the three sides closed except for one on each side, so that its upper extremity is cut off just as you saw before.
Nam quando instrumentum peruenit ad aquam, tunc ipsa descendit statim super instrumentum, ergo euacua ex aqua in hora quantitatem mediam.	 "When the tool went into water immediately it descended quickly on top of the tool; so that half quantity of water was discharged at once.
Quoniam si tu euacuas ex ea plus quam oportet, in hora fortasse moritur infirmus per resolutionem spiritus sui animalis: aut accidit ei syncopis quae appropinquat morti.	 "If you draw out more water than necessary at once, the weak person will either die because of a failure to breathe or suffer from a stroke if something approaches his face while he is dying.
Verum euacua ex ea secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius, et secundum quod significant tibi dispositiones infirmi ex uirtute pulsus eius, et ex bonitate eius.	 Certainly! Here's a possible English translation of the Latin text you provided: "For truly true surgical skill comes from practice and experience, just as its significance is evident to you through your own efforts in training.
Deinde extrahe instrumentum, et retine aquam.	 After this, take an instrument, and hold water.
Quod est, quia retinetur statim propter cutem quae retinet foramen quod est super sifac: de quo narraui, ut perfores ipsum secundum illum modum.	 This means "When you have taken the instrument in your hand and hold water close to it (i.e., as if performing a tracheotomy), proceed by inserting it into the opening that leads out from the nostril.
Deinde itera instrumentum die altero, si uides infirmum tolerare illud: et extrahe etiam ex aqua quantitatem paruam.	 After this, take another instrument on a different day if you find yourself unable to tolerate holding water with one; and then extract that from the water as well.
Fac illud diebus aliquot sine timore, et custodi te ab errore: donec non remaneat ex aqua nisi parum.	 Perform this process for a certain number of days without fear, and ensure you avoid making any mistakes by closely observing; until the removal from water does not remain.
Si autem times super infirmum, et dimittis ex aqua rem multam: tunc cura ipsum cum sepultura in harena calida, et sudore multo in balneo et sole, et expectet super sitim: et cura ipsum cum medicinis exiccatiuis, donec sanetur: et cauteriza super stomachum, et epar, et splenem, post extractionem aquae: secundum quod narraui in eo quod praecessit.	 If you find yourself unable to tolerate it on a day of the illness (i.e., tracheotomy), then remove that from water and place him upon a warm bed with much moisture, and expectoration through his mouth; and then apply fire above the stomach as well, and extract smoke along with the sputum after removal from water according to what I have previously explained.

Caput LV.	 Head L (lower case).
Quando egreditur aliquis infantium ex uentre matris suae, et caput mutonis eius est non perforatum, aut est foramen strictum, aut in non suo loco. Illi autem in quibus est foramen in non suo loco, laeduntur.	 "In those where the hole is not in its proper place, they are treated (lit.: bandaged or otherwise managed).

Neque est ei generatio, propterea, quod sperma non potest peruenire ad matricem secundum rectitudinem: et est aegritudo foeda ualde.	 "There is no generation [of offspring], therefore, since the semen cannot penetrate to its mother according to the right way; and there are bitter fruits.
Et modus operationis in illo est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum.	 "The method of treatment for him is that he lies on his back.

"Then extend your left hand to the neck of him with his left arm; and strike off the head from its place with a sharp blow or an acute instrument, as you would cut something on a knife; so that it falls into the middle according to what is necessary.
Et caue tibi apud operationem tuam a fluxu sanguinis.	 "So that you may be in a position for your blood flow during treatment.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	 "Indeed many accidents have occurred to him.

¶ De Albather quae accidunt in praeputio et capite uigae, et corruptione, nigredine, et adhaerentia.	 "Of Albucasis concerning what happens to the neck and head of a person, and corruption, blackening (i.e., death by strangulation), and detachment.
Caput LVI.	 "The 66th chapter.

¶ De mundificatione infantium, et curatione ex errore eis accidente.	 For the correction of children's mistakes and their care from errors that may occur
Caput LVII.	 Chapter Seventy Two
Circumcisio non est solutio continuitatis, sicut reliqua uulnera: uerumtamen cum sit ex operatione nostra, uoluntate nostra, et usus eius sit in pueris proprie, est necesse ut signemus in ea operationem meliorem, et uiam leuiorem perducentem ad salutem.	 Circumcision is not a solution to continuality like other nails; however, if it comes from our operation, with our care and use for him becomes proper for children, it is necessary that we indicate in this operation the better one and the more suitable for salvation.
Dico ergo, quod antiqui non dixerunt circumcisionem in aliquo suorum librorum: quoniam non utuntur in legibus suis, et non est nisi quod acquisiuimus per experimentum.	 Therefore, I say that the ancients did not write about circumcision in any of their books because they are not used according to their laws and only what we have acquired through experimentation is written.
Quod est, quia ego inueni maiorem partem artificum, et phlebotomatorum uti mundificatione, circumcidendo cum nouacula, et cum forficibus: et utuntur alfecati, et ligaudo cum filo, et incisione cum ungula.	 What is important is that I use a greater portion of the art and phlebotomist to make the world better; circumcision with new tools, and wounds; and they are used in pain, and ligature with thread, and incision with knife.
Et ego quidem iam probaui omnes istos modos, et non inueni meliorem mundificatione cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo.	 I have already tested all these methods, but I did not find a better one to make the world better with thread and ligature.
Quoniam in mundificatione cum nouacula, multotiens effugit cutis.	 Because when making the world better with new tools, it often escapes the skin.
Quoniam cutis praeputii duas habet tunicas: ergo forsitan inciditur cutis superior, et temanet tunica inferior: cogitur ergo ad incisionem ad incidendum alteram, et dolorem futurum.	 The two parts of an incision have two tunics; so that one part of the incision must be on top and hold back the lower tunic; therefore it is necessary to cut through the upper tunic until you reach another incision or future pain.
Et cum mundificatione quae fit per alfecati, id est, digitalis, quo utuntur sutores, non securatur incisio extremitatis uirilis membri: quoniam fortasse ingreditur in foramen eius.	 And when making the world better through needles like sutures, that is, fingers, which are used by sews, it cannot be cut off from a man's arm member; because perhaps it will enter into his hole.
In mundificatione autem cum ungula, fortasse euadit ferrum, et corrumpit operationem tuam: et cutis quidem pueri est breuis natura, et multotiens nascuntur taliter, quod non indigent mundificatione: et iam uidi illud.	 But when making the world better with a knife, it may give iron and ruin your work; and indeed children are born with nature to be this way, and many are born like that, so they do not improve the world; I have already heard of this.
Mundificationis autem cum forficibus, et ligamento cum filo, bonum experimentum detexit mihi: quoniam forfices sunt proportionalis incisionis: propterea, quod acuitas quae est superius, est sicut acuitas quae est inferius.	 Mundification is done with forceps and ligature with thread; this [act] brought me good fortune as the cut on top was like one below in severity
Cum ergo premis manum tuam, proportionantur duae acuitates, et incidunt secundum operationem unam in tempore uno: et fit compressio simili figura, continens cutem uirgae ab omni parte, cum qua non cadit error omnino.	 When you use both hands for this purpose and align their forces, two cuts of equal severity are made at once during the operation; after which a compression is applied in such a way that all the excess flesh is drawn together from every part without falling off any part.
Et modus operationis propriae est, ut facias extimare, puerum praecipue, si est ex eis qui intelligunt parumper, quod tu non facis, nisi quod ligas filum in uirga sua tantum: et dimittas ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 The proper way to perform the operation is as follows: you will have to estimate and measure carefully, especially for children if they understand better; otherwise, do not tie it too tightly with a thread of your own hand, but leave it until another day.
Deinde fac eum gaudere et laetari omnimodo quo possibile est tibi illud, ex eo quod recipit intelligentia sua.	 Then let him enjoy and learn in whatever way is possible for you to do this thing with the help of his intelligence.
Deinde fac eum stare inter manus tuas praeparatae staturae, et non sit sedens: et occulta forfices in manica tua, aut sub pede tuo, ne uideat eos puer omnino, neque aliquid ex instrumentis.	 Then let him stand on your prepared height with both hands free; do not let him lie down, and make an invisible incision on one hand or below the foot to prevent any child from seeing them without using the instruments.
Deinde intromitte manum tuam ad uirgam eius, et suffla in cutem, et trahe eam sursum, donec egrediatur caput uirgae.	 Then insert your hand into his and blow out the blood with it; then draw up his head to prevent him from going down completely.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex eo quod aggregatur in ea sordicie.	 After that, you will have to clean yourself after wiping off the excess flesh.
Deinde liga locum signatum cum filo duplo.	 Then tie a knot with twice as much thread.
Postea liga inferius eo parumper ligamentum secundum.	 After that, tie it with even more ligature below to prevent him from escaping further.
Deinde tene cum indice tuo, et pollice locum ligamenti inferioris retentione bona, et incide inter duo ligamenta.	 Then hold on firmly with your index finger and thumb; keep the lower knot tight, then cut between the two knots.
Deinde eleua cutem sursum uelociter, et extrahe caput uirgae.	 After that, blow out the blood from his head to prevent him from escaping quickly or going down completely.
Deinde dimitte sanguinem currere paulatim (est enim melius) et pone puluerem desuper: et super puluerem pannum in quo expansus est uitellus oui decocti in aqua rosata, concussum cum oleo ros recenti bono: et dimitte eum super ipsum usque ad diem alium: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then let the blood flow slowly for a while; lay aside some of it on top to make a poultice with roasted wheat or oil recently prepared in a way that when cooked in water with vinegar and crushed together with recent olive oil is beneficial: leave him like this until another day, and take care of him with the remaining treatment to cure his wounds.
Forma autem forficis ad mundificationem haec est.	 This is a medical term that refers to the process of removing a tumor from the body using surgery
Sint hebetes duae extremitates, et sint incidentes: ne egrediatur in eis ramus claui: et sit longitudo duarum acuitatum, sicut longitudo duorum manubriorum aequaliter.	 This Latin text describes the anatomy of the human limbs and their relative lengths to one another. The first part refers to the lower extremities (feet), while the second part refers to the upper extremities (hands). It states that both pairs of extremities have the same length ratio, meaning they are proportionate in size when compared with each other.
Error uero cadens in mundificatione est: quoniam fortasse effugit cutis intrinseca tota, aut pars eius apud incisionem.	 A mistake that occurs during surgery is the loss of all or part of the skin due to injury inside it at the time of cutting (incision).
Ergo oportet, ut extendas eam ex hora tua cum ungue tuo ante apostemationem loci: et incidas eam secundum aequalitatem.	 Therefore, you should make an incision during your turn, using your finger in front of the place where it is to be made, and cut it at its same length as the other one.
Quod si non potes tenere eam cum ungue tuo, tunc extrahe eam cum uncino, et incide eam.	 If you cannot hold her with your finger, then remove her using a probe and cut her then.
Si autem praeterierint ei tres dies, et remanet quod est sub uirga inflatum, apostematum: tunc dimitte illud, donec sedetur apostema calidum, et excoria illud cum facilitate, et incide illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi: et caue tibi a capite uirgae.	 If three days have passed and the remaining part that is swollen under the cloth has become hard as a rock, then release it (let go of the grip), until it becomes cool to touch, you cut off what remains with ease, and cut it at its prepared length, so that your sword will hit it.
Non enim nocebit ei illud.	 It won't cause any harm to him/her
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod consolidat uulnus ex pulueribus, quos narrauimus in tractatu de pulueribus: et si inciditur ex cute supra mensuram, et euadit ad superiora, non nocet ei illud etiam.	 Therefore, let us treat that which we have removed from the bowels with care and apply the remedy for removing things from the bowels to it: if an incision is made above its measure (length), allow it to go upwards towards its upper limit without causing any harm to him/her.
Cura ergo illud cum eo quod diximus, donec sanetur.	 Therefore let us treat that which we have said until he becomes well.
¶ De extractione Vrinae retentae in uesica.	 On the subject of removing a hernia from within the body through an incision.
Caput LVIII.	 Title of the next section.
Urinae retentio in uesica, fit ab opilatione facta ex lapide, aut sanguine congelato, aut pus, aut carne nata, et similibus illis ex eis quae diximus ex modis curationis in diuisione.	 The retention of urine in the bladder is relieved by draining off the obstruction with a stone or frozen blood, pus, or a growth from within it, and similarly to those by our methods of treatment when necessary.
Et si non soluitur Vrina, et uides retentionem eius esse propter Lapidem, qui iam est in collo uesicae: tunc oportet ut sit infirmus super genua sua curuatus.	 If this bladder obstruction does not yield to removal by stone or frozen blood, pus or growth from within it, then let him lie on his side until he is cured of the retained urine above his waist.
Deinde componantur pedes eius super dorsum eius, et extendat uentrem suum ex superiori parte dorsi eius, et stringat infirmus anhelitum suum quantum possibile est ei.	 After making a hole in his foot and extending it from the top of his back as far as possible, he ties up any remaining part with cord.
Cogitur ergo cum collo uesicae ad expulsionem Lapidis ad posteriora: quare absoluitur Vrina.	 He stretches out the bladder through an incision in the neck to expel the lapis from behind: why was this necessary?
Quod si non soluitur cum eo quod diximus, et uehemens sit res super infirmum: tunc oportet ut administres extractionem eius cum instrumento, quod nominatur siringa, cuius haec est forma Sit ex argento, et sit subtile, lene, concauum sicut cannula pennae auis in subtilitate radii, longum in similitudine palmi unius et medii: cui sit cannula subtilis in capite eius.	 If this were not possible with him as we said, and the urine-retaining muscle is above it, then you should administer the extraction of his bladder using an instrument called a syphon, its shape like a siphon pipe made from lead or any other heavy metal, but thin enough to be bent easily.
Et modus exitus Vrinae per ipsum est, ut accipias filum duplicatum, et liges in extremitate eius lanam, aut cotum, ligatura bona: et intromittas extremitatem fili in inferiori parte Siringae: et incide cum forficibus si superfluit aliquid ex lana, uerum intromitte in cannulam cum uehementia, sicut alzer.	 And the way of leaving urine through him is by tying a double knot on his penis and pulling it tightly enough to ensure that no more urine comes out as long as he holds his breath; if there is anything left in the thread from the urethra after he releases his breath, you should insert this into the syphon tube at its lower end.
Deinde inunge siringam cum oleo, aut cum butyro, et albugine oui: et fac sedere infirmum super sedem, et embroca uesicam, et ipsius uirgam cum oleis humidis, et oleo oliuae, et aqua tepida.	 After using the syphon tube for this purpose, you can let him lie down on his back and lubricate him gently as before; bind up his bladder with a double knot or with butter if need be, and lead his urethra out of its sheath with olive oil-based lubricant, olive oil alone, or hot water.
Deinde intromitte siringam in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat ad radicem uirgae.	 After inserting the syphon tube into him gently and ensuring it reaches to the base of his urethra.
Deinde dupla ipsam superius a parte umbilici.	 And you tie off the top knot from around his navel.
Deinde impelle siringam intra ipsam, donec perueniat ad Vesicam, et sentiat eam infirmus iam peruenisse ad rem uacuam: et non fit hoc secundum hunc ordinem, nisi quoniam meatus, in quo uadit, est in quo est tortuositas.	 After inserting the syphon tube into him gently and ensuring it reaches to the Vesica, you now proceed with the extraction from within this sheath: do not follow these steps as described here unless you are using a specific tool for this purpose that has been designed specifically for this job, because its design may involve winding and twisting.
Deinde extende filum cum lana paulatim.	 And you extend the thread gently with urine.
Vrina enim sequetur lanam.	 The bladder will follow the thread.
Deinde extrahe eam, et fac currere Vrinam per uiam urinae: et itera siringam, et non cesses facere illud, donec euacuetur uesica, et inueniat infirmus alleuiationem.	 After this you extract the bladder and run urine through its urethra; repeat with him and do not stop until all of his urine has been drained out.
¶ De qualitate clisterizationis uesicae cum Clepshydra.	 Of the quality of sponges used in clepsydras
Caput LIX.	 Head XI
Quando accidit in uesica ulcus, aut sanguis in ea congelatur, aut coartatur in ea pus, et uis distillare in eam aquas et medicinas: tunc fiat cum instrumento quod nominatur Clepshydra, et haec est forma eius.	 When a cut occurs on the sponge or blood coagulates in it, or pus accumulates and distills from it with medicines; then there is to be used an instrument called Clepsydra whose shape we have just described.
Est enim surda, id est, clausa.	 It is deaf, that is, sealed up
Et in eo sunt tria foramina, duo ex parte una, et unum ex parte altera, sicut uides.	 And in it there are three openings: two on one side and one on the other side just like you do.
Et locus concauus, in quo est illud quod impellit, sit secundum quantitatem quod opilet ipsum sine additione, donec quando trahitur cum eo aliquid, ex humiditatibus attrahatur: et quando impellitur, cum eo expellatur ad longinquum: secundum quod facit clepshydra, qua proiicitur naphta, id est, ignis graecus in praeliis martis.	 And the outlet is closed off so that it may expel something without any addition; but when anything is pulled out of its power by humidities it draws it back again to length: according to what clepsydra does, it projects pitch [tar] into flames just like Greek fire on battlements.
Cum ergo uis proiicere humiditates in uesicam, intromitte extremitatem clepshydrae in humiditatem, et trahe cum eo quod impellit ad superiora, humiditas enim trahitur in concauitatem clepshydrae.	 So that you may pour out the humidity into the sponge; and when pulled towards the upper part of clepsydra by its power it will be drawn into the opening of clepsydra by its moisture: but when something is expelled towards the superior direction, then the humidity will be drawn back in to the outlet of clepsydra.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem eius in uirgam, secundum quod narrauimus in siringa.	 Then bring that part within its chamber according to what we have described as a chamber.
Deinde impelle humiditatem cum eo quod impellit illa namque humiditas peruenit ad uesicam statim, ita quod sentit eam infirmus.	 And then drive out the humidity with that which pulled it towards the sponge immediately and quickly so that he may become weary of her.
Forma clisteris subtilis quo clisterizatur uesica.	 The shape of the soft sponge to be used in clepsydras.
Fiat ex argento, aut auricalco: cuius caput altius sit simile alcama paruo, et sub eo sinus inter quem cadat ligamentum.	 Shall be made from brass or bronze; whose head shall be of a height like that of a small bowl and beneath it there shall be an opening into which the ligature may fall.
Deinde accipe uesicam arietis, et pone in ea humiditatem, qua uis clisterizare uesicam.	 Then take the sponge by its edges and place within it humidity for clepsydra to use.
Deinde liga eam inter duos sinus ligatura forti cum filo duplo: et calefac illam humiditatem parumper super ignem.	 And then tie a strong ligature with double cord into the two openings so that its heat may be greater than that of fire.
Deinde intromitte extremitatem clisteris in uirgam, postea stringe manum tuam super uesicam cum humiditate strictura decenti, donec sentiat infirmus, quod illa humiditas iam peruenit ad uesicam.	 Then bring that part within the chamber of clepsydra according to what we have described as a chamber; after which tie your hand above it with a humidity seal securely: so that he may become weary of her for she has already exhausted herself upon the sponge.
Si autem non est tibi praesens uesica, tunc accipe frustum pergameni, et fac ex eo circulum, et perfora ipsum ab omni rotunditate sua.	 If you don't have a knife with you right now, take this broken one and use it to make a circle, then cut through all its thickness.
Deinde intromitte filum forte in illis foraminibus, sicut reuoluuntur.	 Then put the thread firmly into these holes as tightly as before.
Deinde aggrega circulum, sicut aggregatur alsofratu: postquam tu ponis in eo illud quod uis ex humiditatibus, et oleis, et aquis.	 After making a circle, you will secure it just like we did before, when you put that which was wet with water and oil into the container.
Deinde liga ipsum in instrumento: et fac cum eo sicut fecisti cum uesica ex expressione cum manu tua, donec perueniat humiditas ad uesicam.	 After securing it to an instrument (the knife), continue making a circle with it just as you did before when using the knife and your hand; until water becomes wet from the blade.
¶ De extractione Lapidis.	 From extracting the lapis
Caput LX.	 The end of the passage
Iam diximus in diuisione species Lapidis, et curationem eius cum medicinis: et dixi differentiam inter Lapidem generatum in renibus, et uesica, et signa illius totius: et dixi Lapidem in quo cadit operatio cum manu et sectio: et est Lapis generatus in uesica proprie: et ille qui figitur in uirga: et ego sum narrans illud cum expositione manifesta et abbreuiatione.	 I have spoken about the species of lapis and its treatment with medicines, and distinguished between different kinds of lapsides born in kidneys, liver, spleen, and skin; and also mentioned the whole sign of the stone: and distinguished where the operation takes place with hand and cut off; and that the lapis is generated by the stone itself, which appears as a figment on the knife edge. And I am telling this to you now when presented in front of me.
Dico ergo, quod Lapis generatus in uesica, plurimum accidit pueris.	 Therefore, I say that the lapis is most often produced by children.
Et ex signis eius est, quod urina egreditur ex uesica similis aquae in subtilitate sua: et apparet in ea harena alba, et fricat infirmus uirgam suam, et laborat cum ea, et multotiens pendet.	 And from the signs of it (the stone), urine flows out like water with its subtlety; and you will see a white hare appear there, who is injured by that same hand's sword and works hard while being pulled along by her and many times she falls to the ground.
Deinde erigitur, et egreditur cum eo anus in multis eorum.	 After this urine will flow out from it with him as a boy does; and you will see that one of them (the stone) stands erect among them all.
Et est facilis sanatio puerorum, ex eo usquequo consequuntur quatuordecim annos.	 The healing for children comes from it, which brings about a cure in 14 years.
Et est difficilis in senibus.	 And the treatment of an old person is difficult.
In iuuenibus autem est media, in eo quod est inter illud: et eius cuius Lapis est maior, curatio facilior: et si paruus, est econuerso illius cura.	 However among young people it is common (the treatment), which is within the lapis and his who has a bigger lapis the cure is easier; if small, then the cure for him is lighter.
Cum ergo peruenimus ad curationem, oportet in primis, ut mundificemus infirmum cum clisteri, quod extrahat totum stercus quod est in intestinis suis: ipsum enim quandoque prohibet inuentionem Lapidis apud inquisitionem.	 "Firstly it is necessary to loosen the stiff limbs with a cord so that they may be opened up.
Deinde accipiatur infirmus cum pedibus suis, et concutiatur, et moueatur ad inferiora: ut descendat Lapis ad profundum uesicae, aut saliat de loco alto aliquotiens.	 After this the stiff limb is taken in hand and opened up by stretching it with both hands downwards towards the depths so that a vein may be opened leading to the heart; or if there is no vein at all nearby, then relief should be sought from some distant point upwards.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas praeparatum, et manus eius sint sub coxis ipsius, ut fiat uesica tota decliuis ad inferiora.	 "Then place him between your hands prepared so that his hand is beneath the cord of yours; in this way the whole vein may be opened downwards towards the lower part.
Deinde perquire eum, et tange eum extrinsecus.	 After which it should be sought for outside if you wish to open a vein completely from below upwards.
Si ergo sentis Lapidem in spacio, tunc propera statim cum sectione super ipsum.	 If therefore you find the vein empty of blood, then immediately with a sharp cut above it.
Quod si non cadat sub tactu tuo omnino, tunc oportet ut abstergas digitum indicem cum oleo manus sinistrae, si infirmus est puer: aut digitum medium si est iuuenis completus: et intromittas ipsum in anum suum, et perquire de Lapide, donec stat sub digito tuo: et conuerte eum paulatim ad collum uesicae.	 If therefore the vein does not yield to your touch at all, then it is necessary that you withdraw with oil your left hand if the limb is a boy; or else withdraw the middle finger of yours if it is youthfully complete and insert him into your own arm: and you must seek for the vein while he is beneath your digit until he comes from below the vein.
Deinde preme super ipsum cum digito tuo, et impelle ipsum ad exteriora aduersus locus, cuius sectionem uis: et praecipe ministro, ut premat uesicam manu sua, et praecipe alii ministro, ut extendat testiculos manu sua dextra ad superiora: et alia manu sua, ut remoueat cutem, quae est sub testiculis in parte a loco in quo est sectio.	 Afterwards press above him with your finger and drive him out against the place from which his vein is; and you should be prepared to receive the hand that he may give it towards the exterior: and another of yours, that it may extend its fingers towards the higher part: and another one, so that it may remove a cut beneath its fingertips in the part where the sectioning was made.
Deinde intromitte Spatumile incidens, cuius forma haec est.	 After this is an incision of the vein.
Et finde in eo quod est inter anum et testiculos, et non in medio, ad latus natis sinistrae: et sit sectio super ipsum lapidem, et digitus tuus sit in ano: et fiat sectio transuersa, ut sit sectio exterius ampla, et interius stricta, secundum quantitatem quod sit possibile egressio Lapidis ex ea non maior.	 And find there what is between the arm and the fingertips on the left side; make a cut above him over the vein: place your finger in his anus: and then it should be made for an external cutting that may be wide, and an internal one that must be narrow according to how much of the vein's exit can occur without being larger.
Fortasse enim comprimit digitus, qui est in ano Lapidem apud sectionem, et egreditur absque difficultate.	 But if you compress your finger which is in the anus of the vein near to the cutting and he will be removed with difficulty.
Et scias, quod ex Lapide est cui sunt anguli et margines, quare fit difficilis exitus eius propter illud.	 "You know that from a stone there are angles and margins, for which it is difficult to exit because of this.
Et ex eo est lenis, similis glandulae, et rotundus: et fit facilis egressus eius.	 And if you come from soft things like membranes or rounded ones, then exiting is easy for him/her.
Ei ergo cui sunt anguli, et margines, adde in fissura.	 Therefore, to one with angles and margins add a slit (fissure).
Quod si non egreditur ita, tunc oportet ut ingenies super ipsum: aut stringas super eum cum gesti decenter, cuius extremitas sit sicut Luna, quae stringat super Lapidem, et non euadat ab ea: aut ut intromittas sub eo instrumentum subtile, curuatae extremitatis.	 If not able to be inserted like that then you should insert it beneath him in a subtle manner with the help of a delicate tool or by having an extended hand for his extremity which is similar to the moon's shape and can grip the stone and not let go from its hold: or by inserting something under him.
Si autem non potes super cum, tunc amplifica foramen parumper.	 If you are unable to insert it above then widen the hole (fissure) as much as possible.
Quod si uincit te aliquid ex sanguine, abscinde ipsum cum zegi.	 If it causes bleeding remove it with a finger or hand.
Si uero lapis est plus quam unus, tunc impelle in primis magnum ad os uesicae.	 However if the stone is more than one then first move to your mouth using a large spoon.
Deinde incide super ipsum.	 Then strike above it.
Postea impelle paruum post illud: et similiter fac si sunt plures duobus.	 After that pull down the other ones similarly in this manner.
Quod si magnus est ualde, tunc ignorantia est ut seces super ipsum sectione magna.	 If it is very large then ignorance arises as to how you should slice off a big piece of it.
Quoniam accidit infirmo una duarum rerum, aut ut moriatur, aut accidit ei distillatio urinae assidua: proptera, quia non consolidatur locus omnino.	 Because one of the pairs was weakened or ill, either it died from drinking a strong urine mixture or it was sliced off by someone else because its location is not secure all around itself (it cannot be protected everywhere).
Verum administra expulsionem eius, donec egrediatur: aut ingenia in fractura eius cum forficibus, donec extrahas eum frustatim.	 Indeed the expulsion of him should happen until he escapes or it is broken with his own force until he pulls himself out forcefully (from inside).
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc imple uulnus thure, et aloe, et sanguine draconis: et stringe ipsum, et pone super ipsum pannum infusum oleo et uino, aut oleo rosato, et aqua frigida: ut sedetur apostema calidum.	 When you have completed your operation then press the hollow bone with a hard substance such as lead or dragon's blood and hold him there firmly until he pulls himself out forcefully (from inside).
Deinde resupina infirmum super collum suum, et non soluas ligamentum, usque ad diem tertium.	 Afterwards the weak one lies over his own head without support or help from ligaments and it remains like that for three days.
Cum ergo solueris ipsum, embroca locum cum aqua, et oleo multo.	 When you have freed him, fill in a hole with water mixed with oil (a mixture of olive oil is recommended) until he pulls himself out forcefully.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dyafinicon, et unguento basilicon, donec sanetur.	 "After cleansing with a mild soap and water, then apply the healing ointment.
Si autem accidit in uulnere apostema calidum additum, et corrosi, et illi similia: sicut si congeletur sanguis in uesica, et prohibeatur ex eo urina: et cognoscitur illud ex egressione sanguinis cum urina.	 "If it happens that a cold object touches the wound and causes frostbite or burns; and similar injuries occur - as if blood froze in a vessel and urine is prevented from flowing out with it, and it is known by the discharge of blood mixed with urine.
Intromitte ergo digitum tuum in uulnus, et extrahe illum sanguinem.	 "Then place your finger into the wound and extract its blood.
Nam si remanet, prouocat ad corruptionem uesicae, et putrefactionem eius.	 "If left untreated, it can lead to infection of the vessel (vein) or putrefaction.
Deinde ablue uulnus cum aceto, et aqua, et sale: et oppone omni speciei cum eo quod conuenit ex curatione, usquequo sanetur.	 "After cleansing with vinegar and water, then apply any remedy that agrees with the cure.
Et oportet in horis curationis totius, ut liges duas coxas, et aggreges, caussa medicinarum quae ponuntur super locum.	 "It is necessary for the whole course of treatment to be observed so that two veins and a single vein can be cured.
Quod si lapis est paruus, et sit in meatu uirgae, et figitur in eo, et prohibetur urinae exitus: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod narro antequam peruenias ad sectionem.	 "If the stone is flat and lies in the urine bladder; it appears there, and must be prevented from exiting - then cure him with what you put on before you cut into the bladder.
Multotiens enim a sectione excusaris per hanc curationem, iam enim probaui illud.	 "Many times I have practiced this course of treatment; but that's it for me.
Et est, ut accipias Perforatorium ex ferro alferico, cuius haec est forma, triangulatae extremitatis, acutum, fixum in ligno.	 "It is as follows: the trocar has a small opening with a narrow blade; its shape is triangular, and it is held fast by a wooden handle.
Deinde accipe filum, et liga cum eo uirgam sub lapide ut non redeat ad uesicam.	 "Then take a thread and bind it tightly under the stone so that it does not slip out of its place.
Deinde intromitte ferrum perforans in uirgam cum facilitate, donec perueniat Perforatorium ad ipsum lapidem: et reuolue Perforatorium manu tua in ipso lapide paulatim: et coneris perforationem eius, donec facias ipsum penetrare a parte altera.	 "Then insert the trocar with the narrow blade into the stone; hold it gently against its place so that it does not slip out of position. Then take the hand holding the thread and carefully move the stone to one side, then withdraw the stone while keeping your hand pressed tightly against the stone's surface: you will see where the wound has been made.
Urina namque absoluitur statim.	 "The urine is discharged immediately.
Deinde preme manum tuam super illud quod remansit ex lapide ab exteriori parte uirgae.	 "Then take your hand and remove what remains of the stone from its outer surface on the urine side.
Ipse enim frangitur, et egreditur cum urina, et sanatur infirmus.	 "The stone will break up; it becomes fluid with urine, and is cured by that.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi haec curatio, propter aliquid quod prohibet ab illo: tunc liga filum sub lapide, et filum aliud supra lapidem.	 If you are not provided for this care, due to something that prohibits it from him, then tie the first thread under a stone and the second above the stone
Deinde seca super lapidem in ipsa uirga inter duas ligaturas.	 Then dry off over the stone between the two tied threads.
Deinde extrahe ipsum.	 Then remove it (the dried thread).
Postea solue ligamentum, et mundifica sanguinem congelatum, qui fit in uulnere.	 After you tie a knot, and open up the frozen blood that is inside the vein.

¶ De extractione Lapidis mulierum.	 The extraction of women's thighs (a surgical procedure).

Parum generatur Lapis in mulieribus.	 It is not generated by a stone in women
Si autem accidat alicui earum lapis, tunc difficilis est curatio, et prohibetur propter modos multos.	 If you encounter one of those stones, then the cure becomes difficult and is prohibited due to many reasons.

And these two species may occur due to many causes: either from the blow (blow or impact), or from a sudden movement of its wall, or from a loud noise, or from the violent death of another cause, and similarly.
Et signum, quando est ex extensione sifach.	 And the mark when it is from the extension of the anus.
Est quod accidit paulatim in tempore longo, et non accidit subito: et est apostema aequale uersus profundum: propterea, quod sifach comprimit intestinum.	 It happens sometimes with time that it is long and does not happen immediately; therefore because the anus was compressed by the testicle.
Et signum eius quando est ex sectione sifach, quia facit accidere ex principio sui dolorem uehementem subito: et est apostema diuersum, apparens sub cute propinque: et illud est propter exitum intestini, et cursus eius ad exteriora sifach.	 The mark of it when is from the section of the anus because it makes immediate pain at its origin; and it differs in appearance beneath the skin, and that way it goes out through the intestines and its course to the outside of the anus.
Et quandoque egreditur cum intestino zirbum: et nominatur haec Ramex intestinalis, et zirbia: et quandoque fit cum uentositate.	 It may happen with an intestine hernia; and it is called this of the intestines, and the hernia; and sometimes it does so with effusion.
Et quandoque currit in intestinum stercus, et retinetur illic: et est cum eo pernicies infirmi: quoniam facit accidere dolorem prauum, et praecipue quando premitur.	 It may happen that it flows through the intestine of a lump, and held there; and it is with it because of the injury to be very painful, and especially when pressed down upon it.
Et in curatione specierum aegritudinis huius cum ferro est timor: quare oportet ut caueatur casus in ea.	 And in the collection of the causes for fear of this with iron is necessary that it happen to the occasion within her.
Et modus operationis est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut reducat intestinum manu sua ad interiora concauitatis suae, si obedit reditui.	 And the mode of operation is, so as to remove quickly and reduce the intestine in his hand towards the inside of its own cavity if it was reduced.
Deinde resupinetur super collum suum inter manus tuas: et eleua crura eius.	 In your hand place them [the eyes]; and with your fingers touch them
Deinde extende cutem quae sequitur cutem ad superiora, et seca cutem testiculorum totam per longitudinem.	 After this, you should extend the eyelid towards the upper one, and then dry it completely in length from the roots of the eyelashes.
Deinde fige in duobus labiis sectionis uncinos, secundum quod indiges ad aperiendum sectionem cum eis: et sectio sit secundum quantitatem, quod sit possibile, ut egrediatur ex ea ouum.	 After that, you should make two incisions on both sides of the nose with a small knife to open it up; and then cut the eyelid in half by its quantity so that it can be opened completely from within.
Deinde excoria siphak, et quae sunt sub cute testiculorum, donec quando detegitur sifach album, durum ab omni parte: tunc intromitte digitum tuum indicem in eo quod sequitur testiculum, in eo quod est inter siphach album, quod est sub cute oui, et inter sifach secundum, et absolue cum eo adhaerentiam quae est in posteriori parte oui.	 After that, you should cut open the eyelid and what is below it; until the white part of the eyelid has been opened completely from all sides; then insert your finger-tip into where the eye follows, into where it is between the two eyelids, and absolutely with it towards the posterior part.
Deinde moue cum manu dextra ad interiora cutem testiculorum: et cum hoc extende sifach album ad sursum, cum manu sinistra: et eleua ouum cum sifach ad partem sectionis: et praecipe ministro, ut extendat ouum ad sursum: et tu solue adhaerentiam, quae est retro solutione completa.	 After that, you should move the eyelid with your right hand towards the inner cut of it; and with this you should extend the white part upwards, with your left hand: and touch the whole eye with both hands together so as to stretch it out completely; and you will find complete solution for the problem.
Et quaere digitis tuis, ut non sit aliquid illic ex intestino inuoluto in sifach albo duro.	 And ask your fingers not to be inserted into the slit of the eyelid because that could cause damage inside it.
Si autem inuenis ex eo aliquid: tunc impelle ipsum ad uentrem inferius.	 If anything comes out from there, then pull it towards the lower part.
Deinde accipe acum, in qua sit filum grossum, factum licinium ex decem filis: et intromitte ipsam apud postremum sifach, id est, tunicae, quod est sub cute testiculorum quae sequitur sectionem: deinde incide extremitates quae eminent ex filo, donec sint quatuor fila.	 After that, you should take the thread which is attached to it from ten stitches; and put this in front of the upper eyelid slit, i.e., the one covering the eyelashes section; then cut both ends where they come out from the thread, until there are four threads.
Deinde compone quaedam eorum super quaedam cum figura quae sit in modo crucis: et liga cum eis alsifach, de quo diximus, quia est sub cute testiculorum ligamento uehementi, donec non possit aliquod ex uasis, quae nutriunt eos mittere ad eos aliquid: ut non accidat inde apostema calidum.	 After that, you should bind some of them with others in a figure like the cross; and tie these to the eyelid where we have described it, because this is the ligament of the eyelashes beneath the upper eyelid, so that nothing can be inserted into their veins through there towards those parts which feed on them, or else they would cause pain.
Et pone iterum ligamentum secundum extra ligamentum primum, longinquum ab eo minus duobus digitis.	 "And then place a second ligature beyond the first one, extending it with two fingers.
Et post ista duo ligamenta dimitte ex sifach, quod est sub cute testiculorum, quantitatem magnitudinis digiti: et incide reliquum totum secundum rotunditatem, et aufer ex eo ouum.	 "After that, remove the two ligatures from between the fingers, placing one beneath each nail of the thumb and little finger; then strike off with both hands the remaining one according to its roundness.
Deinde seca in inferiori parte cutis testiculorum sectione, ex qua currit sanguis, et sanies: sicut narrauimus in eo quod praemissum est.	 "Then dry the lower part of the thumb and little finger, from which a flow of blood arises; as we did when it was first released.
Deinde administra lanam submersam in oleo, et pone in uulnus: et administra ligamentum quod narrauimus.	 "Then apply a band soaked in oil and tie the ligature that has been released.
Et quandoque cauterizatur sifach album quod diximus, post incisionem eius timendo de fluxu sanguinis.	 "And when we have burned the ligature as mentioned before, fearing a flow of blood from it after its removal.
Multotiens enim accidit illud.	 "But this often happened many times.
Et dimitte ligamentum, donec cadat per se.	 "And remove the ligature until it falls by itself.
Si autem tardatur casus eius, tunc embrocetur cum aqua calida: et pone super ipsum illud quod diximus, donec cadat.	 "If this happens after a long time has passed and its removal is difficult due to the swelling of the blood vessels; then apply it with warm water and place over it that which we mentioned before until it falls.
Deinde cura uulnus cum reliqua curatione uulnerum, donec curetur.	 "After curing the wound with the remaining treatment for wounds, until healing occurs.
¶ De Ramice uentosa.	 "From a skilled barber.
Caput LXVI.	 "Chapter 66: The Treatment of Burns
IN Hac Ramice non uidi aliquem qui ausus fuerit super curationem eius cum ferro.	 "In this chapter I did not see anyone who had been burned while receiving treatment with iron.
Et primi quidem dixerunt, quod fit sicut narrauimus in Ramice quae est cum Vite.	 "And some said that it should be treated similarly to how we treat the wound on a barber's chair when wet with vinegar.
Quod est, ut liges uasa post sectionem super ea cum facilitate inferius: deinde seca in medio, et cura postremo cum eo quod aperit ipsum, donec cadant uasa: et cura uulnus, secundum quod diximus, donec sanetur.	 "This is that when placed above the burn after it has been cut and dried in the middle; then apply a bandage as we mentioned before with vinegar, so that they do not fall out of place; finally cure the wound as mentioned before until healing occurs.
¶ De disruptione quae fit in inguinibus.	 "Of the injury which happens to the buttocks.
Caput LXVII.	 "Chapter 67: The Treatment of Injuries
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, sicut diximus, et eminet locus, et non descendit ad testiculos aliquid ex intestinis: et si descendit, est illud parum, et redit in omnibus horis: uerum si prolongatur cum ea tempus, additur fissura in sifach, donec descendunt intestina in sifach.	 "When an injury occurs to the buttocks as mentioned before; it remains there and does not descend on the fingers anything from within the intestines; if it descends, only then is that a small wound with a bandage put back into all four corners: when time passes while using this treatment for a long time, it adds a cut in the ligature until intestines drop out of it.
Et accidit illud ex extensione sifach, quod est in inguinibus, sicut diximus.	 That happened through a wound caused by the sword as we have stated before
Quod est, quia extenditur sifach: deinde mollificatur, et apostematur locus, et eminet.	 Which is because of the length of the sword; then it becomes soft and the place where it entered heals over time
Et cura eius est cum cauterio, sicut praecessit eius narratio.	 And his care was with caution as we have mentioned before.
Et quandoque curatur cum ferro, secundum hunc modum: et est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum inter manus tuas.	 And sometimes he cared for him with a knife, in the same way; and it is that the sick one lies on his back between your hands.
Deinde seca locum Rupturae apostematum et eminentem, sectione per latitudinem, secundum quantitatem trium digitorum.	 Then the dried place where the opening of the wound was located and its extension through a length equal to three fingers on either side
Deinde stringe alsifak et, quae sunt sub cute, donec quando detegitur sifach album, quod est sub cute quae sequitur ipsum.	 Then stretch them tight as the sword is held in place until it reaches its tip, which is below where you hold it.
Tunc accipe radium, et pone ipsum super locum eminentem ex sifach, et preme ipsum ad profundum uentris.	 Then take a handle and lay him on the elevated place from the sword; then press down to the depth of his chest.
Deinde sue duo loca eminentia super extremitatem radii ex sifach, et annecte cum sutura unum eorum cum altero: deinde extrahe extremitatem radii.	 Then hold them tight above the farthest part of your hands from the sword; and tie both together with a stitch one to another; then remove the farthest part of your hands
Et non incidas alsifach omnino, neque tendas ouum, neque aliud, sicut feci te scire in curatione ramicis intestinalis.	 And do not break all of them completely or stretch them, nor anything else like that, as I taught you to know in the course of the intestinal fistulas.
Deinde cura illud curatione uulnerum.	 Then his care is with ulcers.
Cum ergo incidis fila, mundifica illud, et restaura uulnus, donec consolidetur.	 When you reach that point, open it up, and restore the ulcer until it has healed over.
Sisach enim contrahitur, et non additur eminentia Rupturae.	 His blade will bend backwards, but not to be added to the elevation of the opening.
Et cauterium est melius in hoc loco: quoniam est propinquius ad salutem.	 The cautery is better here because it is close to healing.
¶ De mollificatione cutis testiculorum.	 Concerning the softening of the testicles.
Caput LXVIII.	 Chapter sixty-eight
Multotiens mollificatur cutis testiculorum in quibusdam hominibus, propter quod mollificantur carnes quae sunt inter ea, et foedatur aspectus eius.	 The skin of the testicles becomes softer on some people because the muscles that are between them become soft and the appearance of the one is affected by this.
Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	 Therefore it is necessary for him who asks about the care of them to press down on his back a sick one and cut all of the softened skin above the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	 After making an incision on both lips and stitching them together, if you wish, apply some softened skin with a couple of stitches or four, and firmly sew that too.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	 Cut between the stitched parts.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	 After taking care of all the wounds and stitching them up securely, then let it fall off naturally.
¶ De Castratione.	 About castration.
Caput LXIX.	 Head 69
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	 Indeed, since castration has been cast out from our law (i.e., the canon law of medicine), and for that reason it was permitted to me so as not to remember him in my book like this; and there is no need to remember him unless by two ways.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	 The only way that it should be remembered when a doctor is being questioned about this; and so he knows the cure for what happened to him.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	 And the other way is that we are often practiced on castration among animals, for our own sake; as in sheep, goats, and others of that kind.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	 Therefore I say it should be done according to two ways.
Aut per attritionem.	 Or by gradual attrition.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	 Or by a cut and removal.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	 The way it is done by gradual attrition and a cut-and-remove operation is as follows: we would make the animal to sit in warm water until its testicles are softened up, then they let them stay down while remaining limp, and at that point you take hold of them with your own hand until they stop moving and don't show through touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	 For the castration by cutting and removal, you must hold tight the animal, and press down on his testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	 After ligging the suspensors and drying all over them with one section, until when both sides have been done: then you make an incision on where the cut was made after it has been dried off from above as well as below that part which is under the tail.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	 And this way of castration is better than one by gradual attrition because the gradual attrition sometimes causes loss in testicles and that is why it was desired to not cut them off.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, ulcers should be cured.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	 Concerning the cure of hemorrhoids in two modes
Caput LXX.	 The 70th mode (of treatment).
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	 Hemorrhoids are cured from urine through two methods.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	 The cure is brought about by the urine passing through either a slit between them or through the grip of their base, which lies between two of them, resembling the vulva of a woman and having hairs; and sometimes it flows from that part where it enters the cleft behind one of them.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	 In women there is another mode of cure; and it resembles the vulva of a woman above the fold in such a way that they resemble the upper urethra to one side only, and two on both sides just like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	 The cure of three kinds (by urine) and two by women is as follows: for it must be that the added flesh is cut off until the impression has gone away.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	 Therefore, ulcers should be cured with the help of the remaining parts (of treatment).
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	 In the second mode for men is urine taken from behind one of them that lies between two of them, which does not operate and has no cure at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	 Concerning the cutting off of the foreskin and elevating the flesh on it among women.
Caput LXXI.	 The 71st mode (of treatment).
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	 By this means the foreskin is added above nature until it becomes tender and looks like a swollen part of it; but sometimes among certain women it magnifies itself so much that it becomes as large as one would find it among men, when it has extended as far as the foreskin.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 It is therefore necessary to hold the excess of foreskin with one's hand or a knife and cut off; but not at last in cutting it as far down as its root, especially in its deepest part so that no blood flows.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore the ulcers should be cured with their help.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	 The foreskin is the one born in a mother's womb until it reaches out; and sometimes its removal will be for the sake of resemblance with tails, some people call this the tail-like grip.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	 "Therefore let us make an incision like that of a fistula and heal it as we would a wound.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	 The female urethra is not perforated by the stone.
Caput LXXII.	 Chapter Seventy Two
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	 Albucasis' term for the urethra or bladder stone.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 It is either physiological (normal) or accidental (unexpected).
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	 It is accidental when it precedes by the slip of the foot or hand; and may be added from the flesh, or from subtle poison, or from spit (spit being an old term for an emetic); and may happen in the profound matrix [of the uterus], or in the side thereof, or above or below, or at menstruation.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	 The knowledge of its cause is obtained through an inspection of the birth marks (obstetrical examination).
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	 If it is not visible then seek its cause with your finger or by using a probe.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	 If the inspection reveals the presence of two lips (labial ulcers) then this may be the cause; and to remove it is necessary to separate both the ulcerated parts.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	 And if you find two ulcers on either side:
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	 Then put both your fingers together and place the woman's hand upon her back with your arms extended.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	 Then extend the two lips strongly until you see through inspection what caused it.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	 Then take hold of the hand and drink its contents; then place this upon a spot: and for as long as it remains unfastened, let the woman copulate every day until no other spot is left unfilled.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	 If the ulcer is large and deep then you must separate it from a similar piece of cloth with a small hole for spitting out any poison or phlegm.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	 If the cause is from a flesh wound then bind it up with cotton and make an incision: use as medicine for stopping bleeding without causing injury to the flesh like acacia or dragon's blood, and so applied together with alum.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 In the meantime use a large clamp to hold the nose in place and let it stay like that for days until such time as you have applied the ointment made from linseed. And then apply the linseed ointment after that, if necessary, to cure any remaining inflammation with care
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	 Or when one of the nostrils is blocked by a growth or something similar to it, you should use scissors and cut along this way until there's no longer any cancerous tissue remaining; otherwise do not allow iron against cancer.
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	 For hemorrhoids and bothor rubs on the vulva of women.
Caput LXXIII.	 The thirtieth head.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	 Hemorrhoids are the opening of veins in anus, until it runs out of blood and sweat profusely.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	 When then the hemorrhoids are treated, they become thin; and I have already described their signs and symptoms in my last passage, and what is done to them for treatment, and what is not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	 I therefore declare that hemorrhoids which are in the opening of the womb are not visible to the senses; then there is no cure for them with iron.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	 Those which fall into the womb through the vagina and onto which falls the sense are those which are treated.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	 Therefore it is appropriate that a woman enter her house cold.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	 After this, Athethel cuts them off with scissors or strips them off using a cloth, and slices from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	 Afterwards he washes them off near the blood flow of one incision and without any cutting or mutilation; like acacia trees, dragon's blood, and similarly with other things
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	 Afterwards he moves his feet to the wall for a short time.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	 After that, he lays her down into cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	 If the blood flow remains interrupted; then you should let her rest in a mixture of chamomile and roots, and walnut, and garlic, and similar things.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	 After that you should take the ointment made from barley flour, and wrap her up with honey and vinegar, and put a bandage over it on top of his back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	 If blood is severed from it, that's good; if not, make an incision in the back of the hand and milk the breasts without scarring
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	 Then take the rope and immerse it in heated oil; then apply it to the tip of your nose or to the tongue, as desired.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 When this has quieted down, anoint the spot with ointment and wait until it is healed.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	 The wound on his hand resembles that of a leopard; its appearance is terrible.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore let you strike what is visible from him according to what I said earlier; and care for him until he is healed.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	 The wound resulting from the opening of the matrix
Caput LXXIIII.	 This was done by an expert with 72 surgeries on his head
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	 Many species of leeches have been applied to the matrix as one would apply cancer, and wounds, ulcers, abscesses, boils, hemorrhoids, and fistulas; in short, all kinds of sores and excrescences
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro. ¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	 The art of childbirth is practiced on pregnant women in such a way that the exit of the fetus does not follow its natural course (way).
Caput Lxxu.	 The head of one hundred
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	 It is necessary for an obstetrician to first recognize the normal form of a birth.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	 When you see a woman bent downwards towards her inferior side, and desiring to take in the air, and is relieved by something over her which was above the birth and festinates with the death of the embryo - then you know that this birth corresponds to its normal shape, and the exit occurs from it's head, while being supported or suspended at the belly.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	 Therefore, when you see these signs, then it is necessary for her to be restrained so that she descends with the embryo quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	 When he descended over his head, descending in turn with him and breathing in a good way from those things which are necessary for life.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	 He who is beyond this birth is unnatural, praised be the Lord.

Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	 It is necessary therefore for the obstetrician to be careful and subtle about all these things, and cure himself from error and death: And I am showing you every figure out of them, and how it is an embodiment of wisdom in that one, and it is set upon itself.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis. Foetus enim egredietur statim.	 The fetus will be delivered immediately.

¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	 About the extraction of a dead fetus.

"If it has gone into the womb (i.e., if its base is between your fingers), or there are some impurities on it; then let him perforate [it], until the humidity from within [it] flows out.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	 "If it is above its own feet (i.e., if the fetus hangs down), then drawing [it] becomes easy for you and directing towards its mouth are the eyes.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	 "If it becomes entangled at the furrow (i.e., if it is entangled beneath you), or on its chest; then let him extract [it] with a cloth which you have bound around your hand: and find below, until the humidity within them flows out.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	 "If any of the remaining parts are left after it has returned to its head; then let the midwife introduce her left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	 If the mouth is opened by force, then one hand should be inserted into the opening of the mouth and hold its head with it; after that, the other hand shall take its head as far as the fingers can reach up to the mouth; thereafter, one thumb or two thumbs shall be introduced in turn.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	 If the mouth is closed with a cold finger that has caused injury to it, then at this point one should not allow anything else to be put into its mouth; instead, one should administer a soothing liquid or solution such as water, juice, or wine: and afterwards place in their mouth something soft and moist.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	 If the fetus is above its own length, then it would be possible to equalize; at that point one should administer what we have mentioned as appropriate for the fetus.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	 If this is not possible, then a great effort shall be made and it must be extracted forcibly.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	 It should also not be allowed anything to enter the second nostril of every single individual.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	 After you have completed your surgical procedure, one should administer what we mentioned earlier as appropriate for the cold fingers that cause injury to the mouth.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	 If bleeding occurs from the wound, then one should descend into it using tweezers and administer any remaining cure.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	 I have also heard of a woman whose fetus died within her womb; thereafter she was impregnated with another fetus and the other one later also died.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	 Therefore, a cold finger caused injury to its navel for an extended period of time; thereafter it was inflated until opened, and then began emitting pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	 I have spoken about the care that should be given to him; for a long time he was treated and no healing occurred in the wound.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	 After putting something very strong, like a powerful plaster or cloth over it from which pus escaped, then it exited from that location through its mouth.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	 Later on he died and the other one exited as well.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	 I am amazed at this because there is no mouth present within the womb.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	 "I think therefore there was a dead fetus in the womb.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	 "I examined it and took away many bones from a woman who was better off than others; then she remained as long as time allowed her to remain there.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	 "But I was not able to examine this thing here because there is knowledge of it and assistance towards that which a physician administers with his hand through care.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	 "Of the necessary instruments for taking out a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	 "Chapter 77.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	 "Here is the form of the hook, which makes them equal; having two equal wounds on both ends of two logs.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	 "However, this hook should be more slender than the hooks for the bones; and it can either be made of bone or from the log.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	 "The width of all the logs should be like two fingers; and the edge on both sides is almost as a finger, and the length on each side are palms and half-lengths; in the middle there are two indentations out of that kind of wood which have been set into these ones whose length is half the palm plus less. And the width of both should be like two fingers or more.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	 "These two indentations are inserted into the mouth so that they can be opened with them when you need to come out of them.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	 "The shape of the hook used for extraction is described below:...
