Therefore, I do not think that this is because a woman was present among those who are accustomed to detecting the sick with their eyes; hence it seems to me that there is an agitated feeling being changed by its movements.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 It is necessary then for those who are delighted and whose bodies are full of delight to not be present among those who detect the sick by their eyes, and the hidden ones.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Thus, with the care of his senses and feeling the pain as a patient feels it; if you see this agitation in your eye, as we said earlier, then tighten above him and below too on him; and as long as he stays there without moving, so that the agitated feeling is cut off.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If you do not see him with your eyes, then carefully remove his body and accompany them by the feathers of the little birds, the feathers of the swallow or any other that is similar to those.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 The extraction of the arrows
Caput XCVI.	 One hundred and six.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 The joints differ according to their nature and the places where they fell off the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 Their difference is because some of them have sharp points, and others are blunt; and some are concave, and some are convex.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And from these there are three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 From them there are the tongues
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And from these there are stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 The second type of difference is according to the two modes of those which fell off through the members.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or if from the main parts of the members those which fell off through them are by the two modes as is the head and heart and liver and lungs and kidneys and bladder and all similar things
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When therefore one of the members falls and you see signs of death which I tell you after this then it is necessary that you should pull out those joints from there because death follows him in many positions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And if to you these bad signs are not evident and the joint is hidden in the member's depth then pull it out and make sure it is secure.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 From the head when it falls and it penetrates the nose and it is covered with phlegm which is above the head there are those which fall from him sneezing and blindness and vertigo and redness in the eyes and swelling and redness of the tongue and spasms and mixture of intellects and cholera death.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And it may also be that blood comes out through the nose or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 Or the speech may be cut off and destroyed by the wind.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And it may also happen that from a wound in the head there comes forth white pus-like fluid.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And it may come out of him like water and excrement.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs are evident then stay from the cure and pull out the joint if it is not removed
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 When an arrow falls into the heart, there are two possibilities: either it lodges near the left breast or by chance it fixes firmly on the hard part of the chest and does not fix onto the soft part
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 It is possible that an arrow falls with a force similar to the force of the heart's pulse, and it may run out through the wound, causing black blood to flow forth.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 It is followed by extreme coldness in extremities (of body), and cold sweat, and numbness.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Therefore, it can be said that death was close but not quite at hand.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 When an arrow lodges in the lung, it is said to be a sign of death by blood's exit from the wound; and those that follow behind may cease, or change their color, becoming pale.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And the large breath expires high up in the air, seeking cold air's attraction.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If an arrow falls into the arm, it is near to the back; and there occurs a great breath with pain in the shoulder, accompanied by a sigh, and all the members of the arms may tremble.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 If an arrow lodges in the stomach, it is possible that some indigested food will come forth from the wound.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 If an arrow lodges in the rectum or anus, it may cause something foul from the wound to come forth; either excrement, or a ruptured part of the intestine that has already been disrupted.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore, there is no hope for his cure and no way to remove the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If an arrow lodges into the bladder and urine comes forth from it, something foul will come out; there is a stronger pain on top of weakness; you know that this is mortal
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 The muscles and the joints also give out in many ways like faces; the collarbones, the shoulder blades, the elbow joints, the elbows, the wrists, the buttocks, and the thighs will also be affected when an arrow does not reach a vein or artery; it is an arrow that has become useless.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 I tell you what I learned from Albucasis about arrows, that they are used in conjunction with your treatment
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 Because a bow struck the eye of a man while he was crying and entered his nose
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore, I removed it from the other side of his face and placed it beneath his ears: he was cured without any harm to him.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 Therefore I took another arrow from the Jews who had struck him under his eye, beneath his lower eyelid; and it was hidden so that its use did not come through except for part of his cheek near to where it would have been attached on his wood: and the arrow was large with a curved shaft like the Turks' arrows made by iron, which does not have ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 Therefore, the Jew is cured without any harm to him from an arrow incident injury.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I took another arrow from Christians' quiver:
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 It was an Arabic arrow and it did have ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 Therefore I put the two arrows over his head together, and she was hidden beneath them in his quiver.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 Therefore I became skilled with her, until I took away from him; and the Christian is cured.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 And we thought about it because he was suffering from this arrow.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed by him and no change was made upon him from the dispositions of his own, I took the arrow; and my mind put it there for use, and I removed her; and he is cured without any harm to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man whose arrow had struck his back: and it was set fast upon her.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years the arrow left from his waist.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 I saw a woman whose arrow had struck into her breast; and it was set fast upon her. And the arrow remained within her: and no change occurred from disposition of hers, and she did not receive any harm from any of her own actions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 A man struck another with an arrow in his face and the wound was closed, but he did not endure much pain; similar things happened to others
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 A royal arrow was drawn out from the head of a man who had been hit by it through his nose; and it had already declined towards the right side
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 I am therefore to look after him until three days after he has removed the arrow
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 The wound of the arrow was firmly closed
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I tried with great effort and did not feel it; and he himself felt the pain in his ear on the right side from being hit by the arrow.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 I therefore believed that the wound was caused at the extreme end of the arrow
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I therefore placed a bandage over the place where there was attraction of the arrow's power and digging out; confident that this place would be removed, and it showed me the sign of the arrow so that I could draw it away from its place: and it did not happen at the place in which the arrow had been stuck.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I therefore kept bandaging over him for many days; and it did not happen to be injured because the wound was closed temporarily; he remained weak from drawing out his arrow until he felt an arrow in his nose on a certain day
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 He told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I therefore put over this wound an acute medicine, corrosive for many days; until it was opened up; and with great effort tried to draw him, but felt the subtle end of the arrow which was sticking into the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Afterwards I added to the opening of his wounds that acute medicine; until it appeared before us how far the arrow was sticking out, and there remained with me for about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Afterwards when the wound had been enlarged and it became possible for me to insert my fingers into it and move it around; but it did not obey at its exit: then I did not stop twisting around with the methods of children until a certain day came with very painful efforts, according to which it was shaped out in the end, until I drew her away.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 I have restored the wounds
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And doctors say that the nasal cartilage should not be repaired.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 Therefore I have restored this one and it is now healed in its entirety without causing any harm to him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I inform you of the quality, extent and position of those things that need to be removed so that you can place them in their appropriate rule and meaning as I have indicated.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not comprehended with the narration; nor was it comprehended by that book or wise artificer (craftsman); he was compared to a little for many, and when absent from what is present, he brought down a new operation and a new instrument among external things in those arts which had happened.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 I therefore declare that the arrows are not drawn from the members to which they are attached except by two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or through attraction from where he went in.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or conversely the parts of another.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 That which is drawn to where he went inward may either proceed from there as a shaft penetrating fleshly; or it can be drawn by attraction toward itself.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not arrive at the exit from the hour that he falls; then you should let him rest a certain number of days until his flesh decays around him and he is freed by the force of his own going away.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 Similarly if there is a figure in bone and does not arrive at the exit for you; then let him rest equally that number of days until he has been removed by attraction and motion every day until he is drawn away.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not arrive at the exit after days; then you should perform a figure of arrows from all sides around him from each side gently with a subtle spear until they are expanded.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then draw her away and remove her.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in bone of the skull and has already reached one channel of the brain; and you have noted some accidents which I mentioned before; then stay away from drawing arrows to him until he is equal after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 If an arrow pierces through a sinew, then death cannot be prolonged for him
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 But if an arrow is not fixed but penetrates only to the bone and does not reach through the sinew, then he remains incapacitated for a while, but nothing happens to him from these accidents; at that point, the mind pulls it back with its own force and extracts it out of itself.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If the arrow is fixed and does not reach you to the bone, then administer terebellum around it as if tying a rope; from there take care of its location until he recovers.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow has already been removed at the place of the body and is hidden or concealed from view; then examine it with care when you take hold of it.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel it (i.e., the arrow), then tie it up securely with some instruments that will hold on to its removal from there.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot hold onto it because of the swelling or length of the arrow, and there is no opening, no slit for removing it; then find somewhere above to hold it tight until its swelling decreases and it becomes possible to remove the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If you hold onto his ears tightly, then release the fixed meat from all sides and with whatever force you can break it loose; if not, use your ingenuity to snap or bend its ears until he releases them.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And when you administer the extraction of an arrow wherever it is, use your force with both hands and instruments to all parts until you remove her; and with ultimate subtlety, so that she does not break, making it difficult for you to pull on it and its removal.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot remove her after one day, then let her remain for several days until she becomes rotten or spoiled from its position.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then you will repeat the process; if anything goes contrary to your order it causes a flow of blood; then administer what we have said from care in its chapter and guard your strength so that no wound is inflicted upon you or an instrument used.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 "And by every way possible to administer any vein as you like; and that should be done with ease, tranquility, speediness or patience, firmness or gentleness, according to your will.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 "You should do it while you hold the vein so that weakness might be according to its figure, as it was at the time of cutting from the vein.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 "Since then (i.e., after practicing)
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 "If not that, you should administer the one which is possible from figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 "The vein which is named from the contrary part of another one or has already proceeded to something external; it does make weakness at the extremity by feeling from above the closest parts of the skin and you recognize its prominence, so therefore over it, and should be cut according to how much they can carry in it with their fingers.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 "After that you hold her, she becomes easy for getting out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 "If you hold on to the bone, then stretch your hand according to its roundness until you press the vein into the bone and it expands itself; after that you should pull her.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 "And if not, let it go off for a few days: then repeat it until you get rid of it.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 "If the vein is found to be made from bone, then pull her with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 "If the vein has been found to be cut from bone, and you are ordered to administer pressure; then insert into her an instrument curved so that its fullness is put inside of the artery of the vein; after that pull her with it.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 "If the vein has been found to be curved, then pull her into herself with an instrument inserted into her.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 "The vein is cut through that way.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 "If the vein has been found to be poisoned, you must, until you have finished all the meat from which it is found; if possible, do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 "After that, take care of her in what was suitable for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 "If a testicle falls into the chest or abdomen or scrotum, or anus, and is grasped by the hand while being pressed down upon it; then if you attempt to pull out [the object] at that instant as it comes out of its place (its own) towards your body, an extraction can be made from it. Then wash away with a solution and cut off any pus, or remove it.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 "Then seek medical attention if you are able to do so, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 "This [description of the instrument used] is how testicles are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 "The limbs resemble a bow when they grasp it; but once taken away from the testicles, they do not give back.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 "Many shapes and sizes are produced by them; great ones, moderate ones, small ones, and ones in the middle according to their size of testicles and the power over them.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 "This is how they help or assist when grasped upon [by someone].
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 "And this [description] shows the opposite; they hinder and prevent when taken away from.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 "This is like a radius to enter into the testicles with an outstretched finger and assist them as you press upon them.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 "The extremity of the instrument is shaped like a pen's tail; to help it enter into them and push upon them as you pull.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 "Of [venous] bleeding.
Caput XCVII.	 "Chapter Seventy-Seven
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 "The veins of which are customarily found within the body are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 "From which there are six veins coming from the head; two veins for the ears and their names, two arteries visible only in the upper part of each arm with their names, two veins named Aspicientes running behind the eyes and the name of one vein behind the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 "And two cervical veins
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 "And two veins running within the upper lip of each mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 Two veins which are located in the lower lip
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 These are the veins called "Algecherich".
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 Two veins which are below the tongue
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 Veins that branch off from these veins mentioned earlier are five in each arm
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 These are the facial veins and one vein located at the back of the skull is called 'ulnar'.
Et Fusca.	 The basilar vein
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 This is the media vein and it is composed of branches from both the Basilar and Cephalic veins, and is called 'brachioradialis'.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 The basilar vein which runs through the back of the skull and one vein located at the front of the arm are called 'brachioradialis' (the veins in the arm) and 'Titillicus' respectively.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And this is the internal jugular vein
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 This is the funicular artery of the arm and it lies above the elbow joint; from this vein comes that which is visible when the hand is dropped down to one's side.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 The Salutation artery and its two branches are between the annulus and the small artery, and they supply blood to the arm.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 There are three veins located on the forehead and foot respectively.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 These veins run from the back of the hand to the front of the wrist.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 The second is called 'saphenous' and it lies at the heel behind the ankle joint, from which vein runs that in the hand to the thumb.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The third one is called 'Nesse'.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 There are three more veins on the forehead similarly to those mentioned earlier.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 About the phlebotomy of two veins after auricles
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 The phlebotomy of the two veins mentioned after auricles consists in cutting off the ear and the nose and making an incision at the back of the head, and in treating with old remedies, bandaging, cauterizing, and curing the wounds of the heads.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 The quality of the phlebotomy is according to what is narrow.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 It is necessary that a head dressing be applied and hair of the forehead be shaved with scissors.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 After this, the patient ties his own collar using thread; until two veins are visible on each side.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 The ears lie down behind the temples at a height of two fingers below the top of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 Therefore take them with your finger and when you find their roots under your finger, there tie a knot with resin.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 After this, take the phlebotomist's bowl; it is called Incidens by some.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 After this, put him into a bandage so that he may drip the blood onto the mouth
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then take hold of your finger with a bandage and cut off one vein at its top.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 The length of the incision should be equal to twice the length of your fingers joined together; either straight or in a circle around it and release the blood as much as you can.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 After this, tie him with threads until he is free from pain.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now the beginning of the book has been introduced and their cauterization has taken place.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 The subject matter of two veins which are cut out in time
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The subject matter of two veins which are cut out in time is that by means of phlebotomy the ancient and modern methods should be known to us; so also how we may make a quick incision, quickly extract the flowing blood from the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 The quality or manner in which you remove them is according to what you have been told.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 The patient ties his own collar firmly until two veins of the face are visible; and their pulse will be felt under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then tie a knot with resin.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then take hold of the finger at its top and put him into a bandage so that his drip may be onto the forehead.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 "Cut it off like you did with two veins and others; then make a current flow from its blood according to the need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 After that, take hold of the vein with one finger at once
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then grasp your own hand and its fingers, and strangle it by a strong constriction; then release it, so that the patient may recover.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now you have finished their remembrance, their incision, and the extraction of their book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 After cephalic phlebotomy comes venipuncture (venepuncture).
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 The wound from the first venepuncture after cephalic phlebotomy is after old-fashioned bruises on the face; to its swelling and bleeding; and a sore or ulcer
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of that phlebotomy is according to what you have opened up in it.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 The patient's hand with its fingers is bound by a strong constriction until it appears
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 After that you take the thing called the forceps.
Cuius haec est forma.	 Its form is as follows:
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Take the highest point on the head of the forceps and strike above it with the fingers or another part as necessary; then release the flow of blood according to how much you need.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 After that, take hold of the perforation with one finger at once.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes when you are with a venepuncture on the opposite side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, it is not necessary that the phlebotomy be from the very tip of one's hand as in other cases; rather it should be from an open palm.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 The venepuncture is done according to the incision; which is close by, and it may be that the phlebotomy breaks when it is soft.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 After cephalic phlebotomy comes venipuncture from two lachrymal veins (tear ducts).
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 The wound from the venipuncture of two lachrymal veins is after old-fashioned bruises on the face; to its swelling and bleeding; and soreness of the eye, and old-fashioned pains on the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 And the quality of the veins is such that when they are pressed with a tourniquet the injured limb will be drawn towards itself
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 After the veins have been taken, you place them on his head
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 You tie a tourniquet at a point that is below the length of the veins but above their size, so as not to obstruct them where they exit the body.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If the tourniquet is too loose on the extremities it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 After this you draw off as much blood as necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 And place them on top of each other and tie them at night so that they may be loose when needed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 The veins of the nose are taken
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The veins of the nose are taken because they cause fevers and chills, and redness on the face as a result; especially when ancient.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 And the quality of his veins is such that when pressed with a tourniquet the injured limb will be drawn towards itself.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold the nose of his left hand and take a subtle vein from it; and tie him between two veins that were distinguished by the nose according to their lengths.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Because one cannot see there, and because blood starts to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And you should tie the tourniquet at a point that is below the length of the veins but above their size so as not to obstruct them where they exit the body, and draw off as much blood as necessary for your benefit.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 And ligate her at night one.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 His will be restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 The veins of the eyelid are taken
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 The veins of the eyelid are taken because they cause a desire to constriction and the expulsion of scabs, and black spots on the face; and with ulcers, and wounds caused by biting creatures, that is, reptiles.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 And the quality of their veins is such that when pressed with a tourniquet the injured limb will be drawn towards itself and remain fastened on top of his head while he lies down
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 After removing the vein and stretching it out for a distance of one hand's breadth
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then remove from the blood an amount equal in temperature to what you see as necessary for that
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 And then repeat the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Afterwards, sew up the ligature of each of these two veins so that they are not easily parted.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And remove it from your hand.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 Then take care of the wound.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 Of the removal of veins by Albucasis
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 The purpose of the removal of veins by Albucasis is to drain blood from the mouth and gums, prevent ulcers on the tongue, heal wounds, sores or cuts on any part of the body, as well as those inside the nose or on its surroundings.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 And the quality is such that you can perform it without causing harm to an ill person in your presence, and sew up his neck with a thread.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Afterwards return to the lips and gently apply two veins, one on each side of his mouth; then demonstrate their respective positions by examining them in red light.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And this is it because the veins are very small and black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Then cut off both with one incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If you are doubtful and don't know which ones they are, then make a larger cut that will reveal them better.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And then make the same cut for both veins that are in the upper lip, and it is customary to do so when you have them; then cut two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 Of the removal of veins below the tongue after cephalic vein phlebotomy
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 The purpose of removing veins below the tongue after cephalic vein phlebotomy is to drain blood from the throat and ulcers, as well as prevent further erosion of the mouth and lips.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 The quality of phlebotomy should be such that the patient lies between your hands and is exposed to light from above; and let him have one lancet on each side, with which he may pierce his tongue.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Phlebotomy therefore both of you to attend that your hand is not injured in the process.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 There are arteries beneath him; and perhaps he may suffer loss of blood from these arteries
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 Of three veins in a hand
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are usually used for phlebotomy, located in the hand, are common to all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 Phlebotomy of these is done according to two ways
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Either by piercing with the lancet made from myrtle wood or using a sharp edge for cutting; either by pulling gently upon the vein and twisting it; or by scraping off with the phlebotomist's knife: that is phlebotomy in its simplest form.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is how he does it.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 Thus, for phlebotomy agrees with cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 The large and narrow forms of phlebotomy using myrtle wood are as you would expect them to be.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 Phlebotomy agrees with opening large veins and cutting through fat ones, making them visible, full of blood, red in color, broad in size and filled with thick, dark blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 The phlebotomist is of narrower dimensions than the large phlebotomy form, and more subtle than that one.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 Phlebotomy agrees with the subtler veins which carry clear blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 Of phlebotomy in the church.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 The church which is one of three places for phlebotomy is set apart.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it gives rise to blood from the arteries in the neck and armpit, following which part of the body is unknown; therefore phlebotomy should be made with care by the phlebotomist so that he may take a sample without fear, for there under it lies an artery
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If there is an error and it was added while taking care of the vein puncture, it will cause injury to the artery, and blood flow stops
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 He should not strike a vein when puncturing with the phlebotomist's needle: let there be a separation between them
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the basilica of an appearance is not manifest at that time, it should be taken as if he had another vein, and you are to change over to another one, or else you may wound someone's arm with his own phlebotomist needle: or else strike a vein somewhere in its elbow.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 This is manifest and let her go along with the phlebotomist of Anesil as we have already said
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 However, if you are to perform the phlebotomy on this same vein of his own, then it is necessary before making an incision in the arm so that you strike a place, until you know exactly where the pulse is located.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 After striking on the place with a heated probe, afterward you make an incision in the arm and then let one vein be cut off with the phlebotomist of Anesil as we have already said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And so that no injury occurs due to striking at a space within the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you know that with tightening of the ligature and inflating at a place where you have struck with a heated probe, then this inflation is an inflation artery: so therefore she was inflated.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood near the phlebotomy go up with urine as a child does, and it is clear that there are fine veins, then this is because the artery has been damaged through blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 After that you press firmly with your finger upon a space for a long time and then remove it.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off then tightly hold on to your arm and let it go; and there will be an attack by weakness of his motion; and so it must remain over fear in him.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And not move this for a long time until he is cured.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 However if the blood is not cut off and you see it then do not stay present at your moment of medicine; and so strike an artery as he appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 The hand is amputated and bleeding blood
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Remove the fist bone and take hold of it; then take one medium sized thread and tie it over a fresh healthy vein with a knot and the thread's end tied up until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 Once the hand is amputated, it is good
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 If it fails and the memory of those who preceded him has been forgotten by the flow of blood from the cuts: then cutting off his own blood is not difficult because of the abundant veins or possible use of a bandage
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 From the vein in the forearm.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The vein of the arm is a type of phlebotomy that carries blood from the top part of the head down to the lower body; because it's made up of parts such as the artery to the brain and the artery to the abdomen, just like I said before.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 The bandage was placed over the vein from which blood flowed out of his body; because below it is a nerve
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 If he added a wound to the phlebotomy and it caused him to faint from shock: then his treatment was difficult, possibly resulting in loss of consciousness.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 The nerve is seen by many times
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If it is hidden by some people and is thin so that it's not seen; then you should put your phlebotomy over them like the one I described, making a cut with an alnesil and tying up the nerve with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If it's between two nerves, find one of its lengths.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 From the vein in the head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The vein of the head is a type of phlebotomy that carries blood from the top of the head down to the eyes; because it's part of the artery in the brain.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 If you're using this one, then tie it with a phlebotomist or the myrrh phlebotomist; because it is better than any other, as it isn't a vein and doesn't have a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 "However you must meet with the phlebotomist to receive only the head of the hare and you will find a lesser place; but it shall not harm him if he does not come together with the first blow, so that he may be hit with the phlebotomy afterward.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 "However, it will occur to some men when they do not have phlebotomy during the first blow, but it shall not harm them that way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 "About the usefulness of phlebotomy and caution should be taken about it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 "The quality of phlebotomy and its accidents from which one must consider to correct oneself.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 "First of all, it is necessary to know that phlebotomy must not be administered except for the sake of health and its preservation, and caution against the entry of pain.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 "And that phlebotomy should be given to three veins which are in a hand, namely the cephalic vein, and the femoral vein, and the basilar vein.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 "And that phlebotomy should be given at the beginning of fasting and during sleep, as well as after eating; but not afterwards when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 "And that phlebotomy should be given on the first or third day after going three hours without eating.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 "However the phlebotomy given to someone on pain is not determined by a set time; but when it was agreed and necessary for that person to have it, either during the night or day, and at all hours of the day and night.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 "It is not necessary for children until they reach fourteen years old to have phlebotomy.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 "A woman must not have phlebotomy before the fourth week or after the seventh week.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 "A senior (someone aged 60 years and older) must not have phlebotomy.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 "Therefore if someone decides to have phlebotomy for whatever reason it is necessary that they cleanse their intestines beforehand with a laxative, so as not to draw from them the excess of waste material harmful to the main veins.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 "The patient is not to be cauterized while eating; i.e., he should not vomit after eating a nauseous substance.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 The patient was not to receive any treatment with the use of urine.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 After intercourse, he was to be cauterized with a passion again and again until vomiting, urine, and the flow of the stomach, multiplication of sexual acts, and work, exercise, food, eating, all things that have dissolved the strength from his body or animals.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 After considering the subtlety of humors before this thing if blood is thick with food and drink or medicine; If possible for him.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 After considering the subtlety of humors before this thing if not prohibited by anything else: or exercise another exercise to make the blood subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And put the cauterization of his in the heart on the third day as we said; and conary to make him vomit all the accidents from animals' bodies that day like distress, anger, fear: and with all the body's accidents such as labor and punishment and supererogation and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 Let him make these present with whom he is accustomed to using from the use of aromas and smells and steam as much as possible.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 After he sits in the patient's hands who is higher than the phlebotomy of the ear, after that he pulls his arm out and frightens him with his hand twice or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 After he stretched the ligament along with correction, then again pulled it once more.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the heat be tempered because when there is a difference in stricture or by excessive tightness, it prohibits the flow of blood; and also with softening, that too prevents the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 After the stricture is done so that his hands frightens at once with the incision and they are felt by sensation.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 The phlebotomist takes away the phlebotomy of the patient slowly with a little oil, according to custom.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 In order to grasp or hold on with his right hand the thumb of left hand upon that vein whose phlebotomy he desires (to prevent it from escaping), but only if this does not cause injury; otherwise a blow must be delivered to the thumb
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Because he has taken the vein as if it were a slackened bowstring near to phlebotomy; and on these veins is there fullness of breath (or air); when you place the phlebotomy upon her, she will contract beneath the phlebotomist's hand, and the phlebotomist falls. And should this not occur, then he must deliver another blow to the vein. But if it occurs, immediately it shall be tight, because of that; therefore it is necessary for him who causes the phlebotomy (to do so), in order that he may struggle against all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 He released or let go of the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If then the vein is opened by chance from its own fullness (of air), it is beneficial to that one who causes the phlebotomy.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then again another vein must be sought from beneath or above him with a fetter; should the place fail there
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If he fails, either by accident or because of weakness, then let him abandon his task on that day; or in two days more. And do not bind the ligature.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Fearful indeed is it if the vein should be taken away by frost.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Nor shall he enter the chamber of air; that is, the skin pores or venules.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 He will try again if he desires phlebotomy.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the opening is small or the blood flows gently (that is, the quantity of blood drawn must be within certain limits), he will try again from this same vein and on the next day at least; add to his work as little as possible.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And do this with a fetter before the place is opened; for a place must often be sought from phlebotomies that are very poor and many times by different men when phlebotomizing.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If indeed you have found him who has already been phlebotomized (that is, he should not be phlebotomized again), do not try to go over and above him in any way; for this cannot excuse anything on your part.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 Using olive oil from above puts something on top of it because it cleanses/cleanses blood flow
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 The use of olive oil is better here than any other kind of oil and the rest as well
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 In all veins of yours where the veins run through, they apply olive oil to remove iron stains and make them bright again, and when it is placed on one spot
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 The blood becomes thinner and lighter as time passes when it's thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If you apply it to a large spot where the veins run close together, and this happens repeatedly especially for those who are not phlebotomists except using that one way opening/pathway, then you put a sponge soaked in water and salt into the spot immediately: you heat it up with warm water as well. And after a while tie it down with a string: because it becomes thinner.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 It is necessary that you do this after the blood has left using your own thing and adding something else, or from another source
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If after a few days something is left behind in the spot or urine, do not worry, just put something on top of it like aloe or myrrh sellers' extracts, or from mint extract, i.e., burning with warmth and similar things.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 Many people get stains in the veins of the basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Therefore you should place your hand on top of it and if there is a lump above that spot press down on the clump: then that stain becomes bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 And so to put something on top of it from what we said earlier.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 There is no blood in the arteries due to that.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But if you put a lump on him where there was stiffness before it will become loose/loose up.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 After this care for him with the rest of your cure until he is healed
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 You have to remove all the blood from everyone according to their strength.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears in a bright color on top of the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 If the skin is black, it must be removed immediately; if the skin is white, then remove him (the patient) with a razor blade gently and carefully to ensure smoothness of the skin
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 The skin must be extracted with a single razor blade if he is full and strong; to increase the blood flow of one's body and make it straight forwardly; but for those who are weak, then extract him using an opposite razor blade in order that they may be stronger
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 The skin must be extracted with the help of veins if he is in a state of thirst; to ensure that it will become narrow and tight: better than any other way because administering blood flow works much better than making a cut or piercing.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 The mode of phlebotomy is safe due to the flow of blood; and from the incision of nerves; it's better than any other way because administering a blood flow works much better than through width or length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 If the man preferred to drink while phlebotomy is performed at random intervals; then he must drink before phlebotomy occurs with a moderate amount of warm water which will cause him to sweat; but if the man becomes hot during the process; then extract blood from his veins by three or four of them.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 If the man's face is burned; then he will take before phlebotomy a piece of food which has been infused with honey of my kind or with honey mixed with aromatic spices or with honey mixed with an unpleasant smell.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If it is preferred to drink before phlebotomy at random intervals and if there will be a loss of blood as a result; then take water with the help of meat and scented syrup: so that you will breathe through your nostrils, make yourself thin and make a groove for his mouth in order to do this.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 If someone prefers to amputate their arm and drink the blood of them quickly; then take the phlebotomy of him who is due to a great deal of evacuation because his power is weak so that he drinks it gradually by the amount of strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 "When he is about to amputate the arm and cleanse its blood with the second lancet, it becomes strong; then let him perform this operation within seven hours or eight days at his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 "Whoever is about to draw blood from the other side of his body towards him; he must allow himself to be drawn on the second day or at most three days.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 "In a person whose body has much blood and is heated up; he sweats and brings on fever. It must be done that some blood be drawn out from him in one vessel, and of quantity many. And the opening may be made as wide as it wants to accid until you are accustomed to all the conditions of phlebotomy: and when your hand is placed upon his chest at the descent of the blood so that it does not fall at once.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 "Indeed, many times it occurs when the phlebotomist does not know how to do his work and is careless.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 "It is not to be done when one has already cleaned the arm and cleanses its blood with the second lancet; since at that time the opening of the vein will become hard, so that it may cause death prematurely or very quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 "This operation is a bad thing to do; therefore abandon it unless you are second phlebotomist.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 "Or else remove the thing that has coagulated from within the opening of the vein and place upon it something dissolved in water.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 "Or else place on top of that something from a sponge or a towel; and press it lightly until the blood flows.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 "If already the thumb is used up, then let go of that one immediately; and do not press it tightly until it stops bleeding.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 "If a necessity arises to draw the second blood; and there is no excuse for it, then either place him on top of that one or another arm at once.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 "The veins of the forearm are phlebotomized on the Fossa and the Basilica; since they do not penetrate or are occluded because they have been made from them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 The quality of its bloodletting is such that a sick person puts their hand into warm water and holds it until the wound bleeds brightly and clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then, gently but firmly, it is bound with medium tightness to its surface.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Next the bloodletting is performed gradually and sideways, neither longitudinally nor transversely; with a wide opening to avoid pain during bloodletting, and with your phlebotomy tool as you connect it to the hand higher up.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the loss of blood is forbidden by death or other circumstances, then put your hand into warm water and release the blood to run freely; until you need its removal.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 If however you are in a state of illness or old age, then you may excuse yourself from further hand use in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 And most importantly, the course of bloodletting is performed in hot water for as long as it takes to achieve its purpose.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 The first tool of this kind is superior to all others because it is not dull or heavy in use, and does not tire the hand.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 The right hand's bloodletting tool is a gift to those who are left-handed, as it is designed to help them more easily perform the procedure.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 The quality of its bloodletting is such that you gently but firmly bind your hand with a cord or your own hand after putting it into warm water until the wound bleeds clearly and strongly to the eye.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then the bloodletting is performed by moving it across the surface.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 If you are too weak to perform the bloodletting entirely yourself, do not let it harm that particular thing at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 And continue using your hand with the tool until its purpose is complete and the wound has stopped bleeding brightly and clearly to the eye.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 The veins of the hand are removed from the flesh by it, as a preparation for bloodletting.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then put your hand into warm water and release the blood to run freely within that same water until you need its removal.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 But if you do not put your hand into warm water for this purpose, the blood will coagulate within the wound and prevent further bleeding.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 When you take out a certain amount of blood due to necessity, then place over that one oil and salt so as not to be lost or damaged
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, when doing with every branch tightly
