Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 It is necessary that you use every caution not to touch the Terebrum or Incisor anything from the sheaths.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you have finished with the perforating and separated from the sheath if it was continuous with that and removed him you must know how to pull off his remaining part of the bone with another instrument like an Incisor.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 Nevertheless, be sure to have them thin and subtle more than others' Incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If there is something left from the bones by a little bit and the teeth you take that with ease along with what is at your place from instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Afterwards take care of the wound after this with linctuses and ointments which we have spoken about.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of surgery is easy to do but it has the fear associated with it because what said Galen and was praised by him greatly: this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 First of all, you must detach the broken part from its place using your fingers or some other instrument to isolate it; then after having isolated this part and placed it under that end (of the lens) of the incision on the hand holding the fingers, you will have made a complete detachment with precision.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The lens part itself is not cut: but the sharp edge of it, facing outwards and directed to both sides of its width as you see fit, will be placed with a blunt end against the object it strikes acutely.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then, when you have detached the broken part and placed it under that end of the incision on your hand holding the fingers, you will make a complete detachment with ease; so to say, by means of a small blow against this very incision made gently without contact or touch of any kind upon the object which strikes violently: but striking back quickly after it has struck.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were a more skilled man and knew it well, he would not be sleeping; but then staying in such place with his finger or some other instrument, when he has detached that part and placed it under that end of the incision on your hand holding the fingers, you will have made an easy detachment from him as easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It will be released without any trouble or fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 But if the fracture of your fingers does not reach all the way through to the bone and that which is detached from the bone has a rough face: then you should strive for its roughness (or asperity) in order that it may be removed by those blunt instruments with which you have prepared so many numbers, amounts, quantities. So when you will have done this operation on your hand holding the fingers, you must break and cut off that part from bone and shape it as you were able to administer it most conveniently and rightly into whatever place is convenient for them according to what was done by the operation; then do fracture its face or form of it.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 So you must administer with your reason as first and foremost using your fingers more, then applying the blunt instruments which are more suitable for them.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then you will use after that a more subtle instrument of it.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 Until no further harm is done by doing it in accordance with its continuous nature until having emptied them for administration and handling of the most subtle of all
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In wounds that remain after removing hair and breaking them gently, it is necessary for you to administer the remedy in order to rectify his condition according to what was done when he took [the medicine]
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is that which cannot be hidden from everyone who has made any kind of study in this art and remained over what we have written down and demonstrated in the large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If the loin is detected and you are to take it out when you have removed its os: then it is necessary for you to gather up the loin according to their quantity of wounds, and lower it into rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another loin or three of them and lower them into wine and rose oil as well, and place them over the first loin; and so do this with greater ease than that on it, in order to avoid any harm being done
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer the ligature over it; and do not bind it, unless according to how much of a wound holds onto it; and loosen it with this care one day or two days until six are securely bound from above.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 After that, loosen it and administer remedies with those which are in excess of dryness; such as the roots of mallow, flour of herbs, and ashes of turpentine, and aristolochia, and similar to them: and so you will do from these medicines more use than what is done over the wound just like the scab.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 In every one of them administer every medicine whose property it has so as to stop and not cut.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 So that your skill may be used well so that the wound becomes clear; and neither shall there be any unclean odors from unguents or foulness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Neither should you allow the wound to be gathered together on every part; for when it is gathered upon the loin of the brain, it corrupts him and putrifies him, and causes him to fall upon the sick after such great malice: and now he has fallen into the scalp when his mouth is opened up, particularly when he neglects his care, a black spot on its surface occurs.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Therefore, if they occur to a sick person, you know that it is harmful because of its proximity
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 If the person is not burned but by medicine placed on top of them and it works as a remedy for that person's illness: then you must take one part from honey mixed with three parts olive oil and wrap a linen cloth around your head with this mixture
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 After placing it on the siphon (a type of medical instrument used in ancient medicine), you should then apply care to him as best you can until he is cured.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 In case of a break in the restoration process
Caput IIII.	 The head contains 4 parts
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 You know that the nose breaks in two pieces when only two of its upper parts are broken at once or if one piece of each is broken. So because he has two bones: one below which is cartilaginous and cannot be broken, and another above which can cause damage to him through injury and tortuosity and simitas (not sure what this last term means).
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of its two pieces is broken, then you must insert your finger into the nostril and with that finger tap on it to break up the bone as much as possible so it fits over her own natural shape. And do this gently with art
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 So you don't cause any more harm through your operation on him with pain.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If it is broken in the upper part of the nose and cannot be reached with your finger: then you must extend the fingers as far apart as possible to where there is a small amount of swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If both pieces are broken too and the restoration process should be done within a day after the fracture if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not then on the seventh or tenth day at a peaceful location you will have to do so with warm towels
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 After placing it into the nostril with a linen cloth if one piece is broken or two pieces are broken and there should be as much swelling of that size which fits through the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 "Some restorers of old said that a supply of linen should be abundant and changeable every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 "For this I do not understand you; it seems necessary to me that linen be abundant and changeable with egg-white.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 After removing the linen, the mouth is opened up and the cartilage is released from its bonds.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a feather from the breast of an egg is introduced into the nostril's niche; after that, when it is gently placed upon this same soft membrane: and so it is, that in this manner she holds with great force the fracture of the nose, preventing it not to be hindered by inspiration.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish so, do that; and if you wish so, do the linen.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If while you are working on a warm instrument the nostrils become blocked by cold, or with fat or with oil, or through a mixture of these three things;
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 If this does not happen while working on a warm instrument, then it is necessary that you apply the mixture of flour and egg-white, and press upon him with softened cheese.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 After placing this over his head, do not allow any of these things to come near the nostrils.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If this causes a fracture of the bones or loosening of them, then it is necessary that you cut away from above what remains after these things are broken, and remove him with the instruments which sustain him apart from those things.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then take your scissors, and care for that which is made, and strengthen him with the soft things or ointment.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If this happens between the nostrils, then it is necessary that you care for him with the linen; and administer the ointment from lead until he becomes healed.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 On the restoration of the lower jaw when broken off.
Caput V.	 Head V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken off and its fracture was not with the breaking-off of the nose; if only a portion of it was broken away from him so that he does not fall apart into two pieces, but he should be pressed inward: then knowledge to him becomes easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 "If there is a fracture in the right side of his mouth," you must insert your left index finger into the opening of the mouth; similarly if the fracture is on the left side of the mandible, then put it by inserting your right hand.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 "If the mandible is separated by fracture into two parts," you should administer an extraction with both hands on both sides in accordance with correctness until there is equality of position.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 "If the teeth are injured by a movement or breakage," you should pull out those from which they can be removed with a dental floss, or an implement.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then apply a ligature over the fractured mandible.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 "Then place over it two doubled strips of cloth and one large starched strip; or if you lack them, make the skin of your hand equal to the length of the mandible.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 "Then tie it over after preparing the ligature as given to you; and apply its application until it is not destroyed; and give him a spoonful of his medicine in ease.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 "If you find that something has changed in the figure or manner," then come quickly and give him to eat a third time.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 "Then correct what has been altered from it; and pull him out of the meal with a spoon after straining the broth or liquid, using a linen cloth if you have one, otherwise use flour.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 "While this is kept over it and not altered by the disposition of his limbs; then remove him to eat until he becomes well or as much as possible.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 "It must be tied many times in three seven days.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 "If it occurs to him a cold foot while he is eating," then give that which we have said many times after his meal until the cold foot departs.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 "And if there is a fracture along with vomiting, consider this.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 The severed limb is either useless or can be of little use; therefore, apply this remedy to it so that you will be able to remove the bone from its joint with a knife as before.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If the artery is very narrow, then stretch it out using the phlebotomist in proportion to your need for this purpose.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you have removed the satage and nothing remains from them, stretch out the artery if it is broad; but if not, place something over it that fits into this opening, so that it may be restored to its proper state.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 After the fracture of the phalanges.
Caput VI.	 The Sixth Part (of Surgery).
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 Certainly the sixth phalange is often broken off from the anterior part by the arm; and its fracture takes one of three forms.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it may be broken off separately from two parts, apart from the cause that is usually found in its joint; and this makes restoration of it easier
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 Thus if a satage falls on the bone; and this makes restoration more difficult.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 Or there may be a fracture with a tear, when some injury to the flesh is inflicted at the same time
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And when there is a fracture with no tear present, you should have two surgeons perform the operation; one holds up the phalanges that are broken off and the other extends from below to above part of it.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then if your fingers are equally broken, until its form is made equal to what it should be; and this should not exceed the extent of its ability, nor diminish its compactness
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If the fingers are extended further than this, then you should put a small ball of wool or cloth beneath it; and its size should be according to your need for this purpose; extend and hold the phalanges up with one hand, and use the other hand to stretch and pull back the shoulder part.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you are unable to pull the phalanges of the hand outward; because it has been forced deep inside; then put something beneath his arm that is medium in size and press down on one of its fingers with your other finger so that he may open his mouth as before; after this rectify the fracture, making it equal to both of yours.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If you hear a saw sound from a cleaver, and it stops; then you should remove the bone attached to it by means of that cleaver, so as to get hold of the bone with ease
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If a saw is stuck on the bone; then get it out by making an incision through that saw with one of the saws you prepared for this purpose and once you have grasped the saw from the cleaver [saw], if it's made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And here is how to do it
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 The cochlea should be filled in a patient who does not have fistula (leak).
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 Its length is proportional to the depth it reaches through the bones and fullness of its passage.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length of your incision should also be according to what you can reach during surgery.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 It has two ends; one end is broad and the other narrow
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If you disrupted the bone that you removed by the cleaver; then it is broad and secured with sutures at its narrow end; so make two holes in the bone with a saw, together with a suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 If it's a small disruption or if you do not need sutures; then make an incision with a saw and open the hole accordingly to the size of the cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If you have used a hot oil bath; then pour wine and vinegar on it, and put that above it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 When the narrow end of a bone is without an opening and without being cut; then you should place something above its form that has been made from flour mixed with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And put a linen cloth on it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place the sphere under its neck if there is an indentation there.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take the sickle [blade of a scythe] that the Saracens use which is long and broad; its width will be one palm's breadth or around it.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 And then place two layers on top of the linen cloth and put a bandage above that.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 "Then take a small plate and measure its width by measuring with three fingers; its length will be similar.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 "After that, put the plate on cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 "After that, place it (the plate) where the falling object had fallen and its location was known.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 "Then place it over the fracture in such a way as to be removed by the removal of one part and the support provided; then put it on top of his head with both hands, and supporting him with gentle strength from below while supporting him with weakness from above; lower it completely so that nothing is left except for its broken parts. And you will see how when a straight line holds together two straight lines, this should also hold together the fractured part in order to fix it.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 "So that he may be able every day to support himself as much as possible.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 "Because the ligment was relaxed and you could remove it; then correct that thing and tie back the ligment.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 "Then place him with one hand under his back and put the other hand next to it on his chest; put one arm below his ribs when he is sleeping at night so that you can support him as an assistant.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 "Therefore, a fractured elbow should be treated through the elevation of the arm.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 "Or tie both hands around his neck and do not break loose unless the accident happened by a fall or from another person; for up to 12 days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 "Then remove the plaster if you see that its face is directed towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 "And add to it when necessary and remove it once healed; until restored and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 "And the fractured elbow is held together with a ligment for up to 120 days; and sometimes it happens among people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 "Of the restoration of fractures (of bones).
Caput VII.	 "Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 "A rare fracture occurs to the spatula and it happens at its side; except for its margins (edges).
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it is cut from there a cut occurs at the middle of its, and is not known except by touch; then according to which part of its figure the separation is made
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And move it over the natural figure with all ingenuity, which is possible for you
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place it on top of the cleaned skin with a sponge and lye, and put it over as if from another cloth.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place it on top of the prepared surface with a narrow spatula according to its length and the size of the entire spatula, either greater or less than this one.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If the surface below is not suitable for use with this spatula, then you should bring it to an equal size as if using another spatula after spreading some lye on it.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then spread with the longest and narrowest part of its length, and with the firmness of its spatula until it is not removed from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the ligaments every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever it weakens, you should tighten it and place the spatula on top of its healthy side if removed from its place; then rest it over its long side as before.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 The spatula will be restored within twenty days or within one hundred and twenty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number is complete, then tie it securely; you are safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 This is from the bones whose community cannot be trusted or solved by them.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If it comes out of a bone and bites under its own flesh then place it on top of itself and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do what we said about the fracture of a thigh bone from the pain of heated irons if you encounter something while removing it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Of the restoration of the shoulder bone's fracture.
Caput VIII.	 The eighth part.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 The breastbone sometimes breaks in its middle and rarely happens to that one.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities are the most likely to break from accidents with them.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 "When his middle bone is broken and drops downward towards the inferior position, causing him great pain in his back area; with difficulty in walking upright, and therefore he may lose blood or die from a fractured spine. And if this occurs without consciousness returning, then surgery must be performed to allow him to lie on his back again.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	 "Then his humerus and collarbones must be straightened out as much as possible towards the two sides or elbows with hands: and by skillful manipulation of them to find a position that is comfortable for him so he may resume normal use again.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	 "Then he must place a plaster on top of him to cover his wounds and put another plate above the first one so it covers all his wounds: or use bandages soaked with salt water or vinegar as well.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	 "Then the surgeon must wrap her around his broken limb so it does not move at all; and after applying a bandage in a round shape towards the back of his body some distance away from where he was wounded, tie it with a fine cord tightly.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	 "The surgeon must consider the bandage at all times and every time it is loosened, tie it tighter; if he finds a solution for his case with oil or vinegar to treat what has occurred in that place, then apply this solution immediately: but otherwise remove the plaster and correct where the injury happened with his care.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	 "If he finds that he can put it back on again after removing the bandage.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	 "Regarding restoration of fractures.
Caput IX.	 The ninth head.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	 "Remember that a fracture of the ribs does not occur unless it is in the large areas following the back and from the extremities away from the front part.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	 "And they do not suffer attrition except because of their cartilaginous nature.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	 "Their consciousness is not lost when interrogated with the fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	 "His restoration should be such that the broken part is fitted together with fingers following an appropriate manner so as to look like the original.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	 "Then the splint and hold the fractured jaw by a star if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	 "If the bones of the jaws are broken in pieces towards their inside - then there occurs a great pain and numbness from this, as well as puncturing it with much force if one has many blood vessels; therefore, so that the mouth is painful and difficult to breathe for him, and also he suffers from difficulty in swallowing due to which his face becomes pale because of lack of breath: and these are very difficult to cure.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	 "Moreover, inventors of devices are also found in there with many fingers: and from these come those who say to place food into the mouth of an inflamed one who generates inflammation and thirst so that it is inflamed inside as well as extended, and forced by the fracture towards the outside.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	 "We are afraid lest there be no cause for coldness when trying to make a hot meal if it is not necessary.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	 "If however the cold occurs then he adds into him.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	 "And some of them said: 'It should be placed above the place and sucked with force then it is similar reasoning.'
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	 "However, however there may be fear that the sucking of too much food into the place due to weakness of the person.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	 "And some of them said: 'It is necessary to make the place cooperate with wool that has been submerged into hot oil and should be placed between the bones so that it may become loosened, until it is equal to when being pulled out according to roundness.'
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	 "Then the weak person was cured through food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	 "If the weak person becomes too thin and does not tolerate this, then the mouth is painful because of the fracture causing numbness; therefore it should be that we cut above the place and pull out the fractured bone.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	 "We shall place upon it a tool that holds it securely in place; its remembrance precedes this: and we cut with ease.
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	 "We then gather the two upper lips together if it is large enough to be stitched; and we remove with plasters what has been cut off.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	 "And if the lukewarm instrument comes temporarily; now we put it into a container of oil and warm water to make it ready; after which we remove what has been sewn up.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	 "Also, if anything falls off the upper lip while asleep, then we put it back in place until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	 "For repairing a fracture of the spine and neck.
Caput X.	 "Head X.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	 "Collarbones are sometimes fractured and rarely suffer attrition; the same applies to the spine as well.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	 "Thus if it happens to someone who is knowledgeable about this subject and has knowledge of how to treat them; but if not, then we look for a doctor.
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	 "And if his hands are already softened and stiffened and dead; and he cannot move them nor stretch or tie them with your finger; but when you try to press on them gently with your thumb then it is not felt by him and they do not feel any pain, because of their death: at that point you know that nothing can be done for them, in fact the situation is fatal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	 "If he moves them and feels their tightness with your finger tips; you know that a certain treatment is available for him.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 "If the neck behaves like a hand that is soft and stiffened; you know that it can be treated as well.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	 "No need for his labor.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	 If he had not injured him with anything from that, it would have been less harmful.
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	 His care which caused the injury is such that you should administer a soothing ointment with warm oil; if someone else does this for you, please do so instead.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	 Place the ointment over that part of his body with several applications each day until he is completely soothed; if someone else does this for you, please do so instead.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	 Do not let him rest on the part where he suffered pain until he is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	 If it was caused by a breaking away of the bones or tendons; if something separate was caused from that source, then you should wash over his wound and bring him this.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	 Then, with two stitches on both lips, if it is a large one.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with another person using an ointment until he is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	 If the hind limb bones are broken away and the end of the tail has come; then you should insert your left hand's index finger into his anus, and break both ears with another hand, as much as possible, and second by second until he is healed.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then place over him and bring it; and care for the wound with what precedes, until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	 From the restoration of Anchae
Caput XI.	 The 11th head.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	 Rare are the bones of Anchae's broken.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	 If the bones of Anchae's are broken but not by comminution; and they are split longitudinally, and they fall towards the inside; there is pain inflicted from that spot, a wound, and the limbs which were cut off.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	 And its restoration to him is as follows: you place your hand over it until it becomes healed in the same way that figure of his was.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	 When there is only one fragment of bone to be worked on, then restore that fracture according to the method with which you were shown how it was done for yourself from the equation provided.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	 If there is a fracture that extends into the bone's length, or it has already bent towards its inner part, then proceed to apply pressure against your hand, until you are able to restore the fractured part for yourself.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	 After you have restored the bone to its proper shape by applying pressure against your hand, then place a plaster over that part of it which has been fractured and secured with pins or sutures; after that, put an arrow made from wood or thread above the fracture as well, so that you may not disturb the alignment of the bone until it is healed.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	 And after you have restored it to its proper condition by applying pressure with your hand, until the fracture has healed according to equality; and apply an ointment on that part of the bone so that the person who is treating the fracture rests their head on their back or shoulder as appropriate.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	 If the arrow is heated up (which I assume means if it gets too hot), then stop applying pressure to that part of the bone and restoring it until you have cooled down the arrow; after that, place back over it what supported it before, according to how it was placed originally, so that its restoration continues. And apply a bandage around it as needed.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	 If the arrow went through bone or cartilage instead, then remove and dispose of it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	 Information on restoring a fracture by an assistant
Caput XII.	 The twelfth part (of Albucasis' text).
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	 An assistant is that which is between the elbow and the head of a spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	 If it breaks then the restoration of this part follows one of two methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	 One method is to use a flat medium length piece of wood according to that shape which follows.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	 And two ligaments are tied at both ends of it.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	 Then it is suspended from the place where it was removed and the person treating the fracture rests on a bed or table.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	 As soon as the arm was broken and laid upon a stick, it would gently move towards its tip
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	 Once you suspend it above something heavy, so that it extends downwards
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	 The physician would attend to the broken arm simultaneously with both hands, until the fracture is healed according to what should happen
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	 Another method was that the patient would be lifted over their own bed and suspended from above by the hand of one of them holding it at the back with a cord.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	 Two persons would help lift the patient over their own bed and hold onto them above the broken arm each with both hands; one of the two to hold at the bottom of him and extend downwards towards his other side
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	 If needed to increase the stretch then hold under the arm with a cord and above it with another, and have one of them extend towards each side respectively.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	 If the fracture is near to one of the ends of the arm then it would be necessary for one person to place a cord under its tip and another under the broken elbow.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	 If it is near to the elbow then one person should place a cord above its location and another over the elbow.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	 When the fracture is equally facilitated and without much effort until the fracture has been equalized according to what should happen then bind it securely with a good application if it does not slip from cold hands.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	 If by chance the hands slip away at the seventh day let the binding be released until then.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	 Place above it a strong cord soaked with vinegar and oil, until the hands have become still; then bind securely onto it; and the mode of binding is to place a bandage over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	 Then apply a fresh bandage on top of it.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	 Finally suspend the arm over an assistant and place your hand open onto its own shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	 "Place a cloth on your shoulder and extend it over the broken arm so that the injured limb remains in its place; if something is not permitted to be placed above you by this, do not let anything fall upon you from bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	 "If something is permitted to be placed above you from the broken bone, then use a stronger arrow to do so; otherwise, place an arrow on top of it that has been damaged and is weaker than others.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	 "And place an arrow between all the arrows in length of your hand; let the length of the arrows be according to their fracture and with an additional three fingers from every part.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	 "Finally, extend the stretch above the arrows as I described at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	 "And let your stretch be stronger over the place where the fracture is more restricted.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	 "The longer the fracture, the smaller the stretch should be.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	 "If you want the stretch and length as described at the time when you restore the member quickly, then do this; if a cold arrow is used, loosen up the stretch and arrows until tomorrow, exactly like we said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	 "After that, consider the ligament for three days so it doesn't cause itching or inflation to your body as you move towards the member; due to excess of fluid in stretch.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	 "Therefore, do this entirely according to what we said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	 "If you are above the faith so nothing is allowed from it; then only loosen up the ligament, not after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	 "And let there be a pillow above his back and his hand over his stomach; put it below the support with full wool evenly.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	 "Consider at all times of night or day so that nothing loosens up the fractured member or softens the ligament.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	 "Therefore do this entirely with your own skill.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	 "And put food to the infirmary according to what we've described so that his body is first soft and then he begins eating; at this time you must let him eat more.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	 In accordance with the custom of a barber and an assistant for cutting hair is that it should be shaved every forty days; therefore, at this time it must be shaved off, and medicated with some ointment to soothe it
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	 If a fracture has occurred, apply this as soon as possible; shave off the hair and tie it up with threads until after 50 days have passed, or two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	 Of the restoration of the arm bone (shoulder).
Caput XIII.	 The thirteenth head
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	 The shoulder is composed of two bones called the clavicle and the scapula.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	 Of one of which (the clavicle) it is narrow; and that follows with the hand.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	 The other one being broad, and following beneath by a lesser part from below.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	 Therefore if the larger clavicle is broken alone or narrow; and if both are broken together.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	 When therefore the upper clavicle breaks, then its restoration is easy, and healing easier still.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	 And when it breaks beneath, the fracture to him is bad, and the healing more difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	 It's worse then if both bones are broken together.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	 Therefore when it breaks the clavicle above alone, then he should come to a doctor for its restoration, so that he might place upon it a narrow strap with ease and relaxation until equality is reached.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	 If the upper clavicle has broken this one; then he should do that it might be put on a stronger strap.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	 And it is necessary to place the form of the hand for his restoration and lengthening over the thumb.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	 And the hand of the fingers to the superior shall be higher than all other fingers; and the articular inferior to all others or the rest, and seated square upon himself, and the thumb before him, or on his side directly, at height in order that he may not fall into a weaker position.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	 Afterwards extends the arm of the forearm downward, either with his hand, or using a cord.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	 Another surgeon extended himself out from above in a similar manner
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	 Then the physician takes his mouth and reduces it to its best form possible.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	 If a bone has broken, then you should reduce every fragment back into its original place with the help of your skill.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	 If you see a separation of the flesh and it becomes inflamed; then there is no hope for his restoration: turn him over onto himself and restore him to his original position as before.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	 If a fracture has occurred with a wound, then I made this specific finger-like splint for him so that you can take care of him from there.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	 If you are beginning to make a restoration of the flesh and it is too cold then turn the bandage around with some olive oil, and white cloth; so that there will be an even medium between smoothness and subtlety: and tie the bandage over onto him tightly as before until his restoration has ended. Then remove the bandage from around him and put on a prepared plaster made of flour mixed with water to restore it completely.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	 Afterwards he puts them there; so that the star which is placed over the fracture itself is larger and stronger than before.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	 You know that there are six stars on the arm usually; either if a fracture occurs at one place among them or two places simultaneously.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	 Afterwards he puts your bandage over the fracture and tighter than before; as well as much stronger with a tight bandage above the fracture or below it: also put on a looser bandage to replace what has gone from his previous bandage's memory at the beginning of this chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	 And there are bandages that you can put over the fracture; soft ones, moistened with water; and they should not be rough or hard.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	 The thread is made from linen properly, in between the fine and coarse parts as described before.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	 After a day or two.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	 If something whose repair is necessary occurs, like the itch that occurred to a member: then you should wet the body part with heated water and wait until the itching stops; when you remove the bandage do not tighten it too much as before so that it can stop on its own after being removed from around.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	 "If the narrowing has already been softened and the nose is now remote, similar cases should be corrected in the same way; consider each one.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	 "If feeding is prohibited to enter the member due to excess narrowing, then it should be corrected by first softening what surrounds it more and releasing it after a certain number of days; until its nourishment arrives, hold off on binding it.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	 "If nothing has been weakened among those things that we have spoken of, then it should not be corrected by a solution until after twenty days, or in a different manner.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	 "...and hold off the hand while the weakness is with him [i.e., bound to his neck].
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	 "And let its neck be equalized and be held by your virtue against any movement.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	 "...and let him lie on his back [i.e., supine].
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	 "And you know that this fracture is to be corrected within thirty days, or within thirty and two days; possibly within one hundred days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	 "...it's all done according to the dispositions of the complexion and virtue.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	 "On restoration of fractures
Caput XIIII.	 "The twelfth chapter on the restoration of fractures.
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	 "You know that the fingers often suffer from a fracture in the hand.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	 "...and it does not happen to him unless there is much weariness.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	 "If the plants fracture happens due to fatigue or weariness; then it should be corrected by letting him lie flat and having his seat adjusted according to equality.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	 "...then put the hand upon that extending object.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	 "...and extends the broken bones of the minister and equalizes them; until they are united by a good connection.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	 "Then it is appropriate that he put on an emollient ointment if there isn't a warm one available.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	 "...then place the bandage upon his back according to the quantity of the place; and you already have placed it on him [i.e., into a linen bandage].
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	 If a bone has been broken in such a way that it extends towards the center of the plant, then fashion something like a ball out of linen and apply it to the affected part with some sort of bandage; bind tightly so as to support the fractured limb securely while also supporting its own branch or limb.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	 And there is an asterisk on which the length of ease can be applied to the body of the plant; and bind it so that it may stretch out according to need.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	 If a bone has been broken towards the outside, then it is necessary to place an asterisk on top of it and another one at its base on the plant; open your hand completely straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	 After placing the strap tightly as before, extend between the fingers with a bandage.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	 If the bone is broken in any of the finger joints, then it should be bent according to need if there are no other injuries.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	 After binding as before with the plant and if you wish, place a right-angled asterisk on its head and one flat one at its base; so that it may be held in place securely without moving around.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	 If the bone is broken in any of the other fingers (middle, ring finger or little finger), then bend it as before and bind with a healthy digit following it; or bind them all according to their connection together so that they are all good.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	 Or place the flat one over its head just like we said for the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	 And consider during your restoration and after placing the others with warm fingers; and place it as needed when something happens to him according to his description in its narrative.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	 Of bone fracture of the wrist
Caput XV.	 Chapter Fifteen
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	 The shoulder joint is often broken and it's declared to be so because the head turned towards inside and outside parts.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 Its restoration is done thus: you bind the ligament above the break with another one below the break.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	 And if it's weakened, he extends his face upwards.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	 "Therefore he stretches out every ligament towards his own limb proportionally
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 "If a fracture is near the elbow joint (Coxae), then he stretches out the ligament towards the chest side to enable extension upwards; and another ligament underneath the fracture.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	 "And similarly if a fracture is near the knee joint (genu), then he stretches out the nearest ligament towards the lower part to enable extension downwards; and another ligament underneath the fracture.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	 "Therefore the surgeon extends his own hands towards each other proportionally to match their natural shape; and joins them with a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	 "Then he must place splints and dressings if the limb is not restored perfectly.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	 "If it should fail to heal after a certain period of time (days), then he releases him until the limb becomes warm; and thereafter returns him for your care.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	 "His dressings shall be thus:
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	 "He places a hard band over the fracture itself, namely to prevent the separation of the bones; and binds two or more tightly on either side for support; and any excess shall be removed.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	 "Afterwards he adjusts his fingers until the heel touches the root of the foot [nerves].
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	 "Then he places a long cord between the elbow and the leg near the knee to extend upwards; and the fingers of both hands on either side.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	 "Thereafter they are adjusted over the wrist and elbow, until whatever is left from above fits underneath.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	 "Then he places a star on top of each shoulder where there was a fracture; and one star below the mouth (cranium).
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	 "He adjusts his fingers between the legs and elbow with the help of bandages to ensure an even tightness.
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	 "Then he begins with four or more bindings on either side over the place where there were three fractures; and then adds another to even it out.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	 "And as you add more of them towards the place of fracture, your own tightness becomes less tight and softer; and gentler.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	 "Having opened up the two extremities, you cut between the thigh and calf.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	 Therefore tie three stars which are above it.
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	 Then close with the two extremities to the lower part, until you reach the foot of the calf.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	 And tie also the three stars on one side, so that the bond is not removed from its own place
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	 Then remove the band above this [point], while keeping it in place, so that no member cutting, or pulling back, or inflation occurs there, nor anything of a similar nature
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	 So if something is removed from there.
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	 Therefore, after removing the solution and correcting what was cut off at that point as we said many times before.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	 If you chop bone on to bone when it hits [i.e., if the knife cuts into a bone], then it is necessary for you that this [point] be adjusted so that if it's possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	 And if not, find above the solution and remove it; and care with him who preceded in remembrance so that he may be healed.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	 And when this is tied with a broken thigh bone, apart from adding the stars as we said earlier, so that it may be healed and braced in both assistance and support
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	 However, if he is restored by this means broken, there was no weakness of the leg
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	 And if it is restored only by adding to him the other thigh, then necessity arises so that he who had it always will be unable [to walk].
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	 You know that the thigh can be tied for 50 days or added to a limited extent; sometimes it is lessened also in an equal manner; all of this depends on the variety and state of what remains after subtracting the other member.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	 Of the restoration of the broken thighbone.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter Sixteen
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	 You know that the thigh bone is rarely broken, but it often suffers from atrophy.
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	 If a bone is broken then it must be either fractured or through an opening (in this case a hole).
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	 It is accompanied by pain and without injury/damage
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	 From the top of that goes the whole with sense (or feeling).
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	 The restoration of that is such as to make equal what was broken from the parts (of his body) by using hands until he gathers it and binds it according to what can be done through a balance and easily, with making/fabrication.
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	 Then put a plaster on the forearm from ground meal or of powder made with eggs and put over it a round star if you are not able to reach high then bind/tie it tightly above in order that it may be applied there.
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	 Then consider all the dispositions which we mentioned in other fractures as a hot iron and similar things to him: so that you may oppose against every injury with what he was able, until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	 Of the restoration of a broken leg
Caput XVII.	 Chapter seventeen
