Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	 It should be noted that the legs have two bones of which one is large and called by its name Cruris and the other is subtle and called Feclis.
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	 And both were broken by the same kind of fracture in two parts of the arms and because of this there was the restoration/treatment of that limb as the treatment of the arm is one operation.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	 If both bones break at once then they are turned towards all parts.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	 And if the subtle bone is broken it is turned/bent towards the front part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	 If the large bone breaks then they are downwards from that.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	 Then administer an extension (of treatment), and balance/equilibrium, and tying of stars according to it equally.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	 However if the fracture of Cruris is a broken limb you have to use many bands/straps so that it may be an extension less than and quieter your hands are used for it.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	 "There is something to be found in the operation over the arm; and it happens when you equally balance on both sides, and all take your own operation, then take two stakes from wood which are used for making tables [boards], as they are placed under boards: and they will become palm leaves. And choose one of those with a small thickness, so that none may be by the size; and it is length to them according to the length of the arm up to the lower part of the elbow.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	 "Then apply two of your own solutions around a single piece of cloth, according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	 "Put one part on the elbow, and another on the other side; and it will go from the elbow down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	 "Then tie two stakes around at each end of your cloth, between them.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	 "Since the stretch is forbidden to be done in one direction only, it falls down towards the right and left; and at a fixed place stands firm.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	 "And indeed, the cincture of wood is done according to the length of the arm, and it will be placed on him who needs it; so that he may hold onto it by force.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	 "And furthermore, if you need to make a split when the wound is already open properly.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	 "Then consider your cincture every day; and with it practice last until you become familiar with all its uses, whether by burning or other ways.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	 "If something falls to that cincture then hold it as long as you can until you are able to heal if God wills.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	 "About the fracture of the foot and fingers.
Caput XVIII.	 "Head 18th.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	 "The heel is not broken by a crack in it.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	 "In the foot and fingers there can be a fracture; and of the fingers also a fracture happens but seldom; and it does not happen to them unless attrition through many circumstances.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	 "If there is a fracture in the foot, and you wish to raise it up by yourself; then he takes his sickly foot placed ready on the ground like a stretcher.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	 "At that point you should place your foot on the other which is lifted by those bones; afterward smear it with oil and apply evenly.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	 "Afterward place your foot on top of that [bone], then put a cloth under the toes which have two flat pieces.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	 "Then draw it with a gentle [motion] of the foot, after you use it with the cloth and those others who need.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	 "When three or four days have passed then remove the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	 "You will make it level if they are fractured, dislocated or not properly positioned [i.e., not aligned].
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	 "Therefore the operation is done as you understand.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	 "If any of your fingers are broken then restore them and arrange them according to what I showed you in the restoration of the fingers.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	 "Afterward place your finger into its own little ring according to the length of your fingers and make it a bit smaller on that side; then put under the foot the cloth as I showed you.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	 "If it is broken due to the bones being two or three or more then put a ring on every finger of its quantity and bind it with linen; then place it under one of the toes so that there may be good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	 "And you will remember to avoid bending it so that all of what I said to you regarding the fractures from accidents which we mentioned, and confront every accident with [the treatment for] that.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	 "Of a fracture of the upper arm bone, or humerus, or the bones in the chest and forearms.
Caput XIX.	 The twentieth chapter.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	 When a fracture of a woman's arm occurs then place her on a square rest.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	 Afterward incline it towards the back of that shoulder and let it hang backwards.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	 Afterward insert a support into the woman's armpit so that she is held securely; and let it be as if from her like a sphere.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	 After the woman has been sewn up and her back is bandaged
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	 Then this tool is brought out, so that it may be placed before the vulva as a ball, and the mouth is opened
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	 And then a small piece of silk is put on his back
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	 Once the tool has been lubricated and brought forward quickly, it is withdrawn with ease; then you apply some more lubrication and reduce it to its original size as much as possible, so that when inserted first time, it goes in easily: thereafter return it to its own opening.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	 This will be done over a period of seven days or by way of another route, until the mouth is restored back to normal.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	 And if so you wish, take a sheath made of sheep's skin and fasten it over the opening of his urethra with cordage made from rushes, then introduce the entire sheath into your vagina.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	 Then breathe slowly and smoothly through it until the sheath is stretched inside the vagina to its full length, after which you can break off any excess part.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	 And afterwards with this tool it will last for a certain number of days as we have agreed upon until the pain is relieved.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	 And when the mouth of the man or woman has been broken, then you administer restoration to him and his equivalent as we have agreed upon by way of Anchae.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	 And not the anus should be hidden from him after his injury is treated so that he can recover as much as possible.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	 And you should learn my book well because the very word 'fracture' means different things to me and also to many people depending on their situation or use; therefore understand this.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	 And for the man when he has been broken you take a rooster's beak and introduce it into him.
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	 Then a cloth is put on his solution and he is inflated as much as possible; afterwards it will last for three days or by way of another route until he is cured if God wills it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	 And from the restoration of bones that have been broken when they are with a wound.
Caput XX.	 The twelfth head
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	 The twelfth head was fractured with a sharp blow to the skull, especially if it is large; similarly as in the case of the cheekbones or the nose, so that you must quickly apply ligatures and tourniquets and remove the blood immediately: if conditions for phlebotomy are established according to our instructions.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	 If the wound is bleeding excessively at that time you should immediately apply ligatures to stop the bleeding and remove it as quickly as possible; unless something else needs to be done right away.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	 Then begin to repair the fracture on that very same day, and do not defer it unless another injury has occurred.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	 If a cold injury occurs after the fracture, then postpone repair until one day later, unless it settles down spontaneously.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	 And do not apply to him on the third or fourth day, as you will cause further harm to him.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	 If the nose is fractured and protruding through an opening in the skin, then you should immediately reduce it to its normal position while gently pressing and stretching it with your hands.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	 If no extension is available for him, nor his adjustment by hand, then reduce to its normal position using that instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And the instrument is one made from iron with seven or eight fingers in length and its width corresponds to that of your finger, except for the thumb which has a smaller width than all other fingers.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	 And because of this it is necessary for a physician to receive three or four treatments depending on the size as required by the condition of fracture in all its types.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	 And it should be rounded to prevent it from being pushed aside under the force of compression during surgery and it must have a sharp edge to cut through flesh with an open hand for cutting wounds on its sides or corners.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	 And above all, make sure you apply the instrument from the middle of it up to its bottom end so that no other part gets in the way during surgery.
Et haec est forma eius.	 This is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	 Let him be operated on such that an acute curved edge is placed over his extremity by the prominent fingers of one hand; and with this hand he will press down upon it gently until he has released the lips and equalized them with some fluid
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	 So that the fractured extremities may be aligned
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	 If his extremities are fractured and he cannot accept the tool by grasping it properly then let him strike at them with his fingers until he has control over it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	 If you cannot reduce them with him as we have described above then strike him in whatever manner is possible for you to do.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	 After that let the remaining part of bone be rubbed gently and carefully with a coarse emery stone.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	 And if after the reduction he is still in great pain then you know that his lips did not return to their proper place.
Fac ergo illud.	 Do this therefore
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	 And if you are now complete in restoring the restoration that you have done to his limbs.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	 After this let him throw off the bandage with a black cloth.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	 And if it is still summer
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	 Nor should you place over the wound any ointment or thing that contains oil so as not to cause irritation on it and prevent any corruption or decay from occurring.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	 After this administer these things at the appropriate time of your restoration.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And cut away the wound as you strike with your fingers through a hole that is made to allow blood circulation according to the amount of wounds.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	 With all caution do not tie up the wound if it has been broken.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	 Therefore many of these remedies have been devised by doctors and they did harm either to the patients themselves or their death or decay or putrefaction, that is, to no avail.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	 And make your stitches soft, gentle and diverse from those of fractured parts.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	 "If a wound is bad or great, there are other wounds that come upon us and cause pain; therefore, it should not be applied until later.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	 "And apply a solution from hard cloths to the wound itself.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	 "When one or two days have passed since the wound was inflicted and it is beginning to generate pus; then wash off what you applied over it with vinegar.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	 "After that, we apply a remedy and ointments which are by our custom applied to wounds; such as the tetrapharmakon ointment and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	 "And make sure you have enough bandage for it.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 "Consider the wound daily and often, until it heals completely and is healed.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	 "It's necessary to carefully remove the limb so that the pus flows downwards more easily.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	 "If many days pass and it doesn't heal or get better; then you know that the bandage is now too tight.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	 "Therefore, be careful to examine the wound as soon as possible.
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	 "Remove any remaining rags and get rid of them separately.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	 "If anything from those rags remain stuck to the limb and cause pain; pull it out of there gently and remove as much pus as possible.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	 "If the limb is infected or rotten; that is, infested with worms, or some other corruption and putrefaction; then it's necessary to have someone who has used what he applied remove from there as much pus as possible.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	 "And from that you have to make sure my speech stays strong and I'll give it the present thought when your mouth opens up; like the coxae and assistant, as well as similar ones in the big organs of the body, so that you won't let him go free unless he is very important. After all, many times he has caused death from there because of his actions.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	 One hundred and one days
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	 If you require medical care within a day of injury or within thirty days (30), otherwise remove it.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	 In case of fracture healing the wound should be treated: either on the first day, or within thirty days (30). Otherwise, clean the wound.
Caput XXI.	 Twenty-first
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	 This fracture healing has caused multiple wounds
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	 It's a matter of the greatest importance (most important), which is in connection with these wounds: and it leads to swelling of the body part
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	 And if this limb is being operated on by itself,
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	 So that if the treatment is within a day of injury or within thirty days (30), then administer medicines which have astringency in them: as aloe, and hyssop, and myrrh, and colocynth, and acacia, and similar ones to those
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	 So that you may apply these ones or all of them: and mix with a wine bandage, or a white bandage, or vinegar; and put the bundle on the treatment place, and bind it tightly to good stitches (suture).
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	 And remove the suture after many days have passed.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	 After that, remove one of them and repeat with another until the treatment is done (the healing has taken place).
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	 Or tie it tightly to the bandage from above downward.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	 Therefore, water is a property of all things that are bound out (removed) by the body parts.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the treatment has already been done on a hard surface and is tight and needs to be loosened because of the necessity for doing it (healing), then find from above his part, and cut off the excess moisture that is prominent; or tie it with some other material until it's done (until healing takes place).
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	 When the cure has been restored and the limb is after that delicate, not according to its own nature.
Caput XXII.	 Twenty-second
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	 When healing of the bones is restored and the limb after that delicate, weak; then it cannot happen (heal) except by many causes
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	 "One solution is available for a ligature and ligation of its own kind, either by restricting it due to an excess of ligament tightening or preventing the movement of nourishment to the member when necessary, but not allowing any nourishment to be taken from outside: or because of excessive lubrication in non-time, or because of the scarcity of blood within the body's weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	 The care for him is feeding him and keeping his body firm until there are many times as much blood within him.
Et administra balneum.	 And applying a poultice
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	 "And introducing joy and gladness over him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	 Then, place a wick above the member so that it may draw much nourishment to itself.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	 And he diligently applies warm water with lubrication until it draws the nourishment and returns to its natural figure.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	 "When the care of broken bones will be restored, then.
Caput XXIII.	 The 23rd head.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	 "When the member has been restored after treatment of its own kind and there is stiffness in the bone due to fracture and prominence, or perhaps a knot forms - then it should be torn out using that form so that the member cannot be hindered from its own operation: at this time you will not need to give him a speech.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	 "And there have been many physicians and restorers who did it in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	 And this operation is very fearful to do, leading either to death or great sorrow, as it leads to the fact that it is called a death.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	 "But if the weakness and knot have just happened: then it is necessary to lubricate with warm water, which are boiled soothing herbs like those of alder trees or bitter ones, root included.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	 "And let the bandage be made with a soft, lubricated paste as if it had been made from hemp fiber.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	 "Or, ground alder bark can be used, or chicken fat and honey as a paste mixed with it.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	 The bones are cut off, and with wax they are prepared to be applied over a heated iron, so that the medicines may decrease in strength due to their heat.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	 At times, it is permitted for breathing with a constant friction and warmth, ancient, and gentle, which occurs while the fingers of the hand are in use.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	 The movements of all members shall be applied to each part equally from above everywhere.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	 However, if the tortuousness has preceded and was strong and conversed with a stone, and provoked necessity to its cure by iron, then it is necessary that his superior be cleared off of excessive swelling with bones, and to continue the continuation by them, and to strike what remains from the nodation or the bone with subtle razors: and the administration shall take place in him with solicitude and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	 About the dislocation of the knee.
Caput XXIIII.	 The 24th head
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	 Dislocation is the breaking off from its usual place by one or both of the joints.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	 Because it is forbidden to move that member itself and it becomes a figure of the limb.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	 And causes the superior pain and wounds very much.
Quando ergo accidit alicui dislocatio, tunc oportet festinare ad restaurationem eius: neque tardet eam omnino.	 When then dislocation occurs to an extremity, it is necessary that it be treated at once for its restoration, and not delay any of the others.
Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	 If delayed, he must lose his place, or may have with him a reduction in dislocation.
Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	 Therefore it is not necessary for that member to move so that its extension does not occur at the time of the separation from him.
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	 Because often he causes an attack on spasms and pain the more.
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	 Indeed when that occurs then it is necessary to apply as quickly as possible to phlebotomy.
Deinde dimittatur, donec quiescat apostema.	 Then he must wait until the separation is finished and quiet.
Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	 Then his member shall be treated with hot water and oil.
Deinde reducatur cum facilitate.	 Then it will decrease very quickly.
Et curetur omne membrum cum eo cuius rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	 And all the members, except that one which is forgotten at its place shall be treated with him.
Ego quidem iam ordinaui capitula dislocationis, etiam secundum quod praecessit in fractura, a superiori parte corporis usque ad inferiorem eius.	 I have already made an incision for dislocation and also according to what came before it on fracture, up to the inferior part of his body.
¶ De cura dislocationis Mandibulae inferioris.	 Treatment for dislocated lower jaw
Caput XXV.	 The 25th book
Parum dislocantur duae Mandibulae nisi raro.	 The two jaws are rarely dislocated.
Et dislocatio ambarum fit secundum unum duoru modorum.	 When both jaws are dislocated, they heal in one of two ways.
Aut enim remouentur a locis suis remotione parua, et mollificantur parumper.	 Or, they may move back to their original position and heal by themselves.
Aut dislocantur dislocatione integra, completa, donec mollificentur ad partem pectoris, donec currat saliua infirmi, et non possit tenere eam, neque possit claudere os suum, et inuoluatur lingua eius cum sermone.	 Or they may be dislocated completely and heal to their original position, so that the lower jaw can move and close normally again, but cannot hold it open or allow it to fall, while its tongue is moving up with a sound.
Quando autem dislocatio eius est parua, tunc redit in pluribus dispositionibus per se cum paucitate.	 When the dislocation happens frequently, then he returns from several positions by himself slowly.
Si uero est dislocatio completa, integra: tunc oportet, ut administretur reductio eius uelociter, et non tardetur penitus: et est, ut teneat minister caput infirmi: et intromittat medicus pollicem manus suae unius in radicem Mandibulae dislocationis inter os eius, si dislocatio est a parte una.	 If the dislocation is complete and whole, then it should be corrected quickly either by reduction or traction; he must maintain his position to prevent loss of tongue movement: and it is necessary for him to have the physician apply a finger in one hand into the root of the jaw's dislocation through the mouth if there is one.
Aut intromittat duos pollices suos simul, si dislocatio est a duabus partibus.	 Or he may introduce two fingers at once if the dislocation happens to both sides.
Et reliqui digiti manuum eius sint extra, quibus aequet.	 And his other hand must hold them steady as they are applied.
Et praecipe infirmo, ut mundificet Mandibulas suas, et absoluat eas ad manducandum ad omnem partem.	 He should instruct the patient to relax both jaws and allow them to move naturally back towards their original position.
Et medicus aequet Mandibulam, et impellat Mandibulam, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 And the physician holds the jaws steady until they return to their normal position.
Quod si difficilis sit reductio eius, praecipue si sunt ambae Mandibulae simul: tunc administra uaporationem cum aqua calida, et oleo, donec fiat facilis reductio ambarum: neque tardes reductionem ambarum omnino, sicut diximus.	 If the correction is difficult or both jaws are dislocated at once, then he should administer a reduction with hot oil and water until it becomes easy to correct them together; and not prolong either of their corrections separately as we said before.
Cum ergo redeunt et aequantur, et clauditur os infirmi, et non mollificantur: tunc pone super eas puluillos pannorum, cum ceroto quod sit factum ex cera: et oleo rosato.	 When they have returned and are steady, the physician should press gently on them with a pad soaked in oil; he should also apply heated oil if there is any doubt whether it was made from wax or not.
Deinde ligetur cum facilitate cum ligamentis mollibus.	 With ease when ligatures are softened
Et sit somnus infirmi super dorsum suum: et caput eius sit stans inter duo puluinaria, ut non moueat ipsum ad dextram et sinistram: neque conetur, uel cogatur masticare aliquid: imo ponatur cibus eius sorbitio lenis, donec quando remouentur dolores, et nodatur Mandibula: tunc comedat quod uult, et administretur illud cum facilitate.	 Sleep is placed upon the back of his head; and its chin lies between two veins, so that it does not move to either side; lest he be moved by force or compelled to eat; a little fluid (phlegm) must be swallowed with ease: until the pains subside, and then shall it be applied.
Non laboret super operationem oris sui apud comestionem et potum, et oscitationem, donec nodetur Mandibula, et sanetur.	 It should not rest upon the mouth of his own body during eating or drinking, lest he fall asleep; until the mandible is set, and he is restored.
Quod si difficilis fiat reductio duarum Mandibuiarum, quando dislocantur in hora aliqua, et non conuertuntur ad loca sua: tunc multotiens accidunt inde febres, et soda assidua: et fortasse soluitur uenter infirmi, et fortasse uomit choleram puram.	 If the reduction of both mandibles is difficult, when they are dislocated in a certain hour; then they cannot be restored to their places; often thereafter fevers arise, and excessive heat follows: and perhaps, he may vomit pure bile (choleric) phlegm.
Cum ergo uides illud: tunc scias, quia est perditio, et multotiens moritur ille cui accidit illud in decem diebus.	 So you know this; for if it is lost (the mandible), many people lose their life after being struck by it within ten days.
¶ De reducione dislocationis Furculae, et extremitatis humeri.	 Of the reduction of dislocations in the lower arm and shoulder blades.
Caput XXVI.	 The 26th head.
Furcula quidem non dislocatur ex latere intrinseco, propter continuationem suam cum pectore.	 Indeed, the furcula (collarbone) is not dislocated from its own side by a slip of flesh alone.
Et dislocatur quandoque ad exteriora: et declaratur illud sensui.	 It can be dislocated occasionally on the outside; and it is declared to him who sees it.
Et restauratio eius est, ut iaceat infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat brachia sua.	 And its restoration is that he may rest his body upon it and extend his arms
Deinde coarta locum cum palma tua coartatione forti, nam ipsa redibit.	 Then with your arm as a support; for she shall be restored.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stringe eam.	 Then he will place the bandage upon it and the wounds and tighten her up.
Extremitates uero eius quae sequuntur cubitum, et continuantur cum eo, non dislocantur, nisi raro.	 The extremities of his body which follow from his arm; they shall continue with him, unless dislocated very rarely.
Quod s dislocatur die aliquo: tunc oportet, ut reducatur et aequetur secundum quod diximus, et quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is dislocated on any day; then you must reduce and equalize as we have said and what was prepared for you.
Deinde pone super ipsam emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam.	 Then he will place the bandage upon it and the wounds and tighten up the stitches.
Et praecipe infirmo, adhaerere tranquillitati et quieti, donec sanetur.	 Until a man is healthy and tranquil, he should not eat.
Et cum hac eadem curatione reducitur extremitas Humeri, quando separatur etiam a loco suo.	 And when the same treatment reduces the extremity of the arm to such an extent that it separates from its own place.
¶ De reductione dislocationis Humeri.	 On the subject of dislocations in the human arm.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Scias, quod Humerus non dislocatur, nisi secundum tres modos.	 It is known that the humerus does not dislocate unless it follows one of three modes.
Quorum unus est, ut dislocetur ad partem titillici ad inferiora.	 One of these modes allows for dislocation at the tip to become detached from below.
Secundus est, ut dislocetur ad partem pectoris.	 The second mode causes dislocation in the shoulder area.
Et fortasse dislocatur ad superiorem partem Humeri: et illud fit raro.	 And possibly it dislocates to a higher degree of the arm, which is rare.
Et non dislocatur ad posteriora, propter spatulam.	 It does not dislocate at the back because of the shoulder blade.
Et non dislocatur ad anteriora, propter neruos.	 And it doesn't dislocate forward due to nerves.
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur et egreditur ad inferiora uersus titillicum: praecipue in illis, quorum carnes sunt paucae.	 It is possible for the dislocation to occur at the tip and become detached from below, especially among those whose arms are weak.
Quoniam egrediur in eis uelociter, et ingreditur uelociter.	 Because it can follow both outward and inward movements simultaneously or one after another.
In illis autem quorum carnes sunt multae, est econtrario illius, scilicet quia egreditur cum difficultate, et ingreditur cum difficultate.	 It is uncommon for this to occur in those with many weak muscles.
Et fortasse accidit quibusdam hominibus percussio, aut casus, et apostematur Humerus apostemate calido, et putatur propter illud, quia iam dislocatus est.	 And sometimes it happens to some people by accident or injury, and the arm becomes dislocated in a heated manner from its opposite side, which is due to this because he has already been dislocated once.
Oportet ergo, ut experiaris illud, donec stes super certitudinem eius, et tunc procedas in curatione eius.	 Therefore you should observe it and proceed with its treatment until certain of the certainty is given to him.
Et cognoscitur dislocatio, quando est ad inferiora uersus titillicum: et distinguas inter Humerum dislocatum, et humerum sanum.	 It can be distinguished from a dislocated arm and a healthy one when dislocation occurs at the tip.
Nam tu inuenis inter eos diuersitatem manifestam, et inuenis in capite Humeri concauitatem, et sub titillico apud tactum caput humeri quasi ipsum sit ouum: et non potest infirmus reducere manum ad aurem suam, neque mouere eam omnibus motibus.	 You must note the difference between them and look for any movement at the shoulder area, even if it only moves like a dislocated arm when it touches the head of the arm: and cannot an infirm person reduce his hand to touch her own ear with all movements.
Et similiter, si dislocatur uersus pectus, aut ad sursum: tunc inuenis manifestum tactum, neque occultatur.	 If dislocation occurs on the chest or up, you must note any movement and cannot hide it.
Et huius quidem dislocationis fit facilis reductio, quando est recens, aut infirmus est puer.	 A reduction of dislocations is easy when a man is young and robust
Et reductio eius est, ut eleuet minister manum suam ad superiora.	 A reduction of his own body to the superior part
Deinde pone tu pollices tuos sub titillico eius, et eleua iuncturam cum fortitudine ad sursum ad locum suum: et minister eleuet manum suam, et extendat eam ad sursum.	 Then you should place his limbs under a hook of iron and lift it to its upper part, then join the limb with force and courage to the back; and from there you will stretch out the limb towards itself: and at that point you will minister the hand as far upwards as possible.
Deinde ponat eam inferius, ipse enim redit uelociter.	 Then he pulls it downwards or lifts it quickly.
Si autem non redit per illud quod diximus, et sunt a principio quo accidit dislocatio dies multi: tunc oportet, ut balneetur infirmus in aqua calida, et administretur embrocatio quae mollificat et lenit, sicut si decoquantur radices alteae, et foenugraecum, et mellilotum in aqua, et administretur.	 If he doesn't lift it as we have said and many dislocations occur at the beginning of this day: then let a warm bath be given to him who is suffering from pain or discomfort; and a soothing ointment should be applied which soothes and relieves the pain just like if one were to apply cold compresses to the head, feet, hands, and face.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et ponatur sub titillico eius sphera et lana, quae sit aequalis inter lenitatem et stricturam.	 Then he is placed on his back; and a hook of iron is placed under him and wool which is equally equal between the relief from pain and restriction is applied.
Deinde ponat medicus calcaneum suum super spheram, et eleuet caput humeri cum uirtute, et attrahat manum infirmi ad inferiora.	 Then a doctor places his foot above the hook; he ministers the arm of the patient towards the lower part of his body.
Et minister alius teneat caput infirmi, ut non moueatur ad inferiora: ipse namque redit statim.	 And another minister holds the head of the patient so that it does not move towards the lower part; he himself then lifts up quickly.
Et si uis, reduc eum secundum modum hunc: et est, ut facias esse praesentem uirum qui sit longior infirmo, et stet a parte lateris, et intromittat humerum suum sub titillico infirmi: et eleuet titillicum eius ad superiora, donec sit infirmus suspensus in aere.	 And if it is easier to reduce him as we have said; then you should make an effort so that the limb of the patient who is longer and weaker will be brought down to one side where he can rest on his back: also place both of his arms under the hook of iron, and lift them towards the upper part until he has been supported by air.
Et minister alius trahat manum infirmi ad inferiora uentris eius.	 And another minister holds down the hand of the patient to support it in front of him; he himself then lifts up quickly.
Si autem infirmus est leuis: tunc oportet, ut suspendatur cum eo aliquid aliud, ut grauet ipsum: nam redit dislocatio statim.	 If the patient is weak or too tired to carry on with this reduction; then he should be supported by something else so that he can continue until a dislocation occurs quickly.
Et reducitur etiam secundum modum alium: et est, ut figatur in terra lignum longum, cuius caput sit rotundum figura: sicut manica mortarii: quod non sit grossum, neque subtile.	 And the reduction is done according to another way; and it is like placing a long stick with a round head which fits into the hand of death; but not too large or thin
Deinde ponatur sub infirmo postquam ponuntur super caput ligni panni lenes: et infirmus sit stans secundum longitudinem ligni.	 Afterwards, after they have been placed on the head with a linen cloth and are removed from under it when they become heavy (because of their weight), the patient lies on the length of the staff.
Deinde extendatur manus eius ad inferiora a parte altera, et extendatur corpus eius ab altera parte cum fortitudine: nam iunctura redit ad locum suum cum uelocitate.	 Afterwards, his hand is extended towards the lower part while the other arm extends his body from another side with forcefulness; for this union brings him to his place of motion.
Quod si difficilis sit eius reductio per omnia quae diximus, tunc utere hac cura: et est, ut accipias lignum cuius longitudo sit quantitas duorum brachiorum, et eius latitudo quantitas quatuor digitorum, et grossitudo eius quantitas duorum digitorum: cui sit caput rotundum, ut alleuietur introitus eius in profundum titillici, secundum hanc formam.	 If his reduction is difficult by all that we have mentioned so far, then use this method of care; and it will be like lifting up a staff whose length equals the sum of two arms, its width equals four fingers, and its thickness equals twice the thickness of two fingers: if its head is round in order to prevent its entry into deep crevices by means of this shape.
Deinde ligentur super caput rotundum panni lenes, ut non laedat lignum infirmum.	 Afterwards, linen cloth is placed over the rounded head so that it does not drag down the staff while moving.
Deinde ponatur sub titillico infirmi, ut extendatur manus, aut brachium super lignum usque ad inferiora: et ligetur lignum super adiutorium et brachium et extremitatem manus.	 Afterwards, they are placed under the staff and its hand is extended or upper arm is stretched up to it until below; then a cord is tied around the staff and both hands and arms.
Deinde ponatur brachium super gradum scalae per latitudinem, et extendatur manus ad inferiora, et dimittatur reliquum corpus suspensum a parte altera.	 Afterwards, upper arm is stretched to above until below; then the hand is extended downwards and the remaining body suspended from another side is released.
Iunctura enim ingreditur statim.	 The union brings about its movement immediately.
Cum ergo completur introitus eius secundum quemcunque modum possibile est: tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico spheram aequalis quantitatis ex lana.	 Afterwards, the entry of him is completed in any manner possible; then it is necessary to place under a sphere of linen equal quantities from wool.
Deinde pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum olibano, et albumine oui super humerum totum, sicut reuoluitur desuper.	 Afterwards, put on the prepared plaster made by mixing flour with water and olive oil; then place it all over his body as before was done.
Deinde stringe sub titillico strictura decenti: et reuoluatur ligamentum super emplastrum desuper: et annectatur manus eius ad collum ipsius, et dimittatur, neque moueatur manus eius septem diebus.	 Afterwards the binding of the linen plaster is done with a decent tie; then the band above the plaster is tied on as before was done; and his hand is attached to its collar so that it does not move for seven days.
Et oportet, ut ponatur cibus infirmipaucus, donec confortetur membrum: quoniam est uelocius ad sanationem eius.	 And it should be necessary that the food of him who is ill is placed after he is comfortable; because its place is for his healing to happen.
Deinde ponatur amplior post septem dies, aut quinque, et ex ercitetur cum motu.	 After seven days at most, or five; and it is removed with motion
Si ergo firmatur et non mollificatur, tunc iam sanatus est.	 If after that time there was no improvement, he has recovered.
Si uero iunctura dislocatur multotiens, propter humiditatem quae accidit ei, aut propter caussam aliam: tunc oportet, ut administretur in ea cauterium cum tribus foraminibus, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo de cauterio.	 If the joint is dislocated excessively due to moisture that happened to him or some other cause, then it must be treated with a cautery containing three holes; according to what was mentioned earlier in the chapter on cauteries.
Quod si fiat hoc totum, et soluatur ligamentum post septem dies, et non confirmetur iunctura, et reducatur emplastrum et strictura super ipsum aliquotiens, et non firmetur, et cadat, et non possit eleuare ipsum ad superiora: tunc scias, quod nerui eius qui sunt ad caput humeri, iam incisi sunt, aut extensi, aut mollificati: et scias, quod iunctura nunquam figetur in loco suo.	 If all this is done and the joint does not heal within seven days, it may be loosened or reduced with forceps; however if it will not loosen or reduce, then it dies off, and cannot be restored to its proper place: you know that the nerves of the arm are cut and can either be made straight again, stretched out, or relaxed.
Dislocationis autem quae fit uersus pectus et mammillam, aut ad posteriora reductio, fit cum impulsione et extensione cum manibus: donec redeat, et administretur in ea reliqua strictura et cura, donec sanetur.	 The dislocation that happens due to the chest or nipple, or a reduction towards the back is treated with force and extension using the hands; until it is restored, then use the remaining restraint and care for its recovery.
Quod si accidat post sanationem grauitas in membro, et tarditas in motu eius, tunc utatur infirmus balneo multotiens, donec leniatur illa grauitas, et redeat ad naturam eius primam.	 If a gouty pain after the recovery occurs in any member and stiffness in its motion is treated with a strong bath many times until it relaxes and returns to normal; until then use restraint and care for its recovery
¶ De curatione dislocationis Cubiti.	 Of the treatment of dislocations cubitis (upper limbs).
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter Twenty-eight.
Scias, quod iunctura Cubiti dislocatur cum difficultate, et similiter redit cum difficultate etiam: et ipsa quidem dislocatur ad omnes partes, et praecipue ad anteriorem, aut ad posteriorem.	 You know that the joint of the upper limb may be dislocated with difficulty; and similarly it can be reduced with difficulty as well, in fact even more so; and this same joint is easily dislocated towards all parts, especially towards anterior or posterior.
Et eius dislocatio non occultatur tibi: quoniam est cadens sub uisu, et sub tactu, secundum quamcunque figuram dislocetur.	 And its dislocation will not be hidden to you because it is easily seen from below and from the touch, as dislocated in whatever form.
Et quando coniungis cubitum dislocatum cum sano, declaratur tibi illud manifeste.	 When you bring a dislocated upper limb together with one that is healthy, it will be clear to you
Concauatur enim iunctura, et non potest duplicare brachium, neque tangere cum eo humerum suum.	 The joint cannot be tightened up and cannot grasp or touch the lower arm with it.
Et oportet, ut properes, et reducas dislocationem statim, antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 The patient should be positioned and immobilized immediately before the application of cold compresses
Nam si accidit ei apostema calidum, difficilis fit eius reductio: et fortasse non sanatur omnino, praecipue quando est ad posteriora.	 If a hot poultice is applied to him first, his reduction becomes difficult; and perhaps he will not recover completely unless the poultice is immediately followed by cold compresses on the back
Est enim deterior omnibus speciebus dislocationis, et uehementioris doloris eis: et multotiens descendit cum ea mors.	 The removal of dislocations generally worsens with pain; and many times it has descended along with this death.
Et restauratio eius quando est ex eis quae possibile est reducere, est, ut extendatur manus eius cum duabus manibus: et brachium eius sit expansum, et manus medici sint supra cubitum et sub eo, et ipse impellat iuncturam cum pollicibus manuum suarum simul, aut cum radice palmae suae, donec redeat ad locum suum.	 The restoration of him when it is possible to reduce him will be as follows: his hand should be extended with two other hands; and the physician's arm should be stretched above the cubit (about a person's height) and below, so that he may push himself back by pulling on both sides simultaneously, or by using the palm of his hand, until he reaches his place.
Aut uero dislocatio est ad anteriora: tunc redit ita, ut duplicet manum cum manu sua, donec percutiat cum radice palmae suae cubitum qui est dislocatus.	 Alternatively the dislocation may be reversed in this way: first he doubles his hand with his own, until he strikes on both sides simultaneously by using the palm of his hand which is dislocated; or alternatively it can be done by reversing its position so that it becomes an anterior dislocation when the palm is pressed against the dislocated cubit.
Quod si non obedit dislocatio ad reductionem, tunc administra extensionem uehementem, fortem ualde: et est, ut extendant brachium duo ministri: et teneant ipsum duo ministri etiam, ut non remoueatur apud extensionem.	 If the dislocation cannot be reduced then administer a strong and intense extension; it is as follows: two physicians should extend his arm with all their strength, so that they may not remove him while he extends himself.
Deinde reuoluatur brachium ad omnem partem postquam inuoluitur super manum eius pannus duplicatus longus, aut ligamentum latum.	 Afterwards the arm should be returned to its whole length after it has been doubled over by means of a strap or a ligature.
Et quando tangit medicus manu sua iuncturam, inungat ipsam cum oleo: ut sit illud ex eis quae adiuuant in lubricitate iuncturae cum facilitate.	 When the physician strikes with his hand he also uses oil; so that this which is done with ease and lubrication may come into play as a remedy.
Deinde impellat iuncturam impulsione uehementi, donec redeat.	 He then pulls himself back by pushing with great force until he reaches his place.
Et post reductionem eius oportet, ut ponatur super ipsam emplastrum, in quo sit stipticitas, et exiccatio cum albugine oui: et stringatur strictura decenti.	 After the reduction of him is done he should be placed on a flat surface where there is stiffness; and with a warm bath and oil he should be warmed up until the tension is released and he can move freely without any restriction.
Et suspendatur brachium a collo infirmi: et dimitte diebus aliquot.	 The arm is suspended at the level of the sickbed for several days.
Deinde soluatur.	 After that, he should be released.
Si ergo firmatur iunctura in loco suo, tunc solue ligamentum ab ea, et dimitte ipsam.	 "If a suture is firmly placed at its proper site, then immediately remove that ligature and let go.
Et si uides iuncturam non bene stringi, tunc itera emplastrum, et ligamentum, et dimitte ipsam diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 "If you are not able to firmly place the suture, then try again with a different ligature and remove that one later after some days or until it becomes firm.
Deinde solue ipsam.	 "And afterwards let go of her.
Si autem accidit ei grauitas post reductionem iuncturae, et dispositio sit in motu: tunc administra humectationem in balneatione, et fricationem subtilem, et compressionem, donec liniatur, aut pone super iuncturam iliati, id est, natem arietis pinguem.	 "If something goes wrong with the suture after reduction of the ligature and positioning has been made: then administer humectation in warm water, and also friction (rubbing), subtle friction (rubbing) gently, compression, until the line is taut or the ligature is tightened from above. Or you can place a small bird on top of the ligature.
Deinde ligetur, et dimitte ipsam super eam die et nocte.	 "Then tighten it up and let go after one day and one night.
Deinde aufer eam, et intromitte ipsum in balneum.	 "And afterwards remove her from there and put him back into the bath.
Cum ergo sudat, tunc frica iuncturam fricatione temperata.	 "When she is done bathing, then apply friction to the ligature gently with warmed water.
Deinde itera super ipsam aleliati uice una, et secunda, et tertia cum introitu balnei, donec leniatur.	 "Then repeat three times over her and into warm water until she becomes slack or relaxed.
Et si uis, pone super ipsam stercus uaccinum, humidum, calefactum cum butyro, et stringe super ipsum.	 "And if you are able to place a heated iron on top of her with oil and tension it up.
Fac illud aliquotiens.	 "Do this several times until she becomes slack or relaxed.
Ipsa namque lenitur, et redit ad dispositionem suam.	 "Her line is loosened and she returns to her normal state of being.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Almahassem.	 "From the removal of a ligature by Almahassem.
Caput XXIX.	 "Chapter Twenty Nine: The Removal of Ligatures.
Mahassem manus multotiens dislocatur, id est, iunctura quae est inter brachium et manum.	 "Almahassem makes the hand loose by removing a ligature between the arm and the body.
Et reductio dislocationis eius est facilis.	 "The reduction of his dislocation is easy.
Econtrario reliquarum iuncturarum.	 "In the case of failed ligatures.
Verumtamen oportet, ut uelocitas sit in reductione dislocationis eius in hora in qua dislocatur, antequam apostemetur locus: aut accidat in eo apostema calidum.	 "However it is necessary that the loosening of his dislocation should happen before he becomes loosened up completely or at a place where something hot can be put to reduce it.
Et reductio dislocationis in eo est, ut ponas Mahassem manus infirmae super tabulam, et extendat minister manum eius: et ponat medicus palmam suam super eminentiam iuncturae, et impellat eam, donec redeat.	 "And the reduction of his dislocation is in him as he puts a weak hand over a table and extends the assisting hand to him. And the physician places her own hand above it on top of the ligature and pulls it until she is done.
Verumtamen oportet, ut consyderetur, si palma iam recessit ad uentrem manus: tunc ponat infirmus dorsum manus suae super tabulam apud extensionem et reductionem: et si dislocatio est procedens ad dorsum manus, tunc sit positio manus eius intrinsece super tabulam, id est, interior pars manus eius super tabulam ponatur, ut cadat manus medici super ipsam eminentiam iuncturae.	 "However, one should keep in mind that when the hand has reached its end and begins to return towards the thumb: then place it on the inferior part of the hand with the palm upwards; and if there is dislocation which proceeds to the back of the hand, then put it (the dislocated hand) naturally into position over the table itself as an interior part placed above the table - so that the surgeon's hand may cover its own prominence by union.
Si ergo redit statim, bonum est: et si non, tunc stringe eam cum emplastro sedante apostema: et dimitte ipsum, neque iteres illud.	 If then it immediately returns to the correct position, that is good; but if not, then grasp it with the other hand holding a bandage and release it without repeating this error again.
Nam si non tolerat, neque potes super reductionem eius, postquam praetereunt ei dies, uerumtamen iunctura remanet secundum tortuositatem suam: et non nocet infirmo aliquid, nisi quod mollificatur manus, et non potest stringere aliquid: tunc scias, quod nerui sunt abscissi, aut attriti.	 If it cannot be tolerated or grasped after a day's use (after 24 hours), then the healing process continues according to its tortuosities; and nothing is harmed unless the hand softens up, and nothing can be grasped - you know that the thumb has been lost.
Non est ergo ingenium in ea, nisi ut stringatur cum cauterio prope casum eius.	 It therefore is no use to grasp it with eagerness towards its injury.
Et fortasse non confert illud aliquid.	 And perhaps not even this thing may happen.
Cum ergo non redit Almahassem, tunc pone super ipsum emplastrum, quod narrauimus.	 When it does not immediately return to the correct position (when the hand is completely paralyzed), then place a plaster on top of its plaster as we did.
Deinde stringatur, et dimittatur quinque diebus: postea soluatur et dimittatur, et exercitetur manus.	 After that it should be grasped and released after 5 days; thereafter the hand is to be treated with a lotion and then released, and exercise done for its recovery.
Si autem priuatur motus eius, et accidat in ea aliquid grauitatis: tunc leni eam cum aqua calefacta, et fricatione aliquotiens, donec leniatur.	 If the movement of his hand becomes feeble and he falls ill from it: then gently grasp him with warm water and friction for a time until he is loosened.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Digitorum.	 Of the treatment of dislocations in the fingers
Caput XXX.	 Chapter 30.
Quando dislocatur ex eis Digitus ad omnem partem, uel ex eis Digitus ad dorsum palmae, aut uentrem eius: tunc extende Digitum, et impelle dislocationem pollicibus tuis, donec redeat.	 When a finger is dislocated from the back of its palm or towards it (i.e., thumb-side), then extend the finger and press down on the dislocation with your other fingers until it becomes right again.
Deinde sustenta caput Digiti, et suspende ipsum uersus partem ad quam dislocatur, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	 After that, support its head and suspend it towards the dislocated part and release him after two days.
Deinde suspende eum, et extende ipsum, donec aequetur rectus in illo die suo.	 "Then hold him down and straighten him out so he is straight on his day.
Cum ergo fuerit nox, liga ipsum secundum narrationem ipsam: et non cesses soluere ipsum in die: et exerce eum cum motu: et liga ipsum in nocte.	 "When it was night, hold him according to the same pattern; do not let him rest on his day; and exercise him with movement; and hold him at night.
Fac illud diebus aliquot, donec stringatur.	 "Do this for days until he becomes straight.
Et similiter fac cum eo, si dislocatur ad uentrem manus: et liga eum ad partem ipsam, et fac cum eo operationem tuam primam, donec sanetur.	 "And do the same with him if his arm is dislocated; and hold him at this side; and perform your first operation on him until he recovers.
Et similiter fac cum eo quando dislocatur ad reliquas partes.	 "Do the same with him when his arm is dislocated to other parts as well.
¶ De curatione dislocationis Spondilium dorsi.	 "About the treatment of dislocations in the shoulder blade.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter thirty-one
Quando accidit alicui Spondilium dorsi, aut colli dislocatio completa, aut remouentur Spondiles multae a locis suis: tunc non est in ea curatio, quoniam mors properat infirmo.	 "When the shoulder blade is dislocated completely or has been moved out of place by many parts; then there's no treatment for it because death comes to him weakened.
Et signum illius est, quod egestio infirmi egreditur absque uoluntate, neque potest tenere eam: et multotiens mollificantur ex eo quaedam membra eius, aut duo crura eius, aut duo brachia ipsius, aut unum eorum: aut remouetur Spondilis una de loco suo.	 "His sign is that ejection by weakness will not occur unless there's resistance; he cannot hold it, and many parts of him are falling out to some extent; or two bones from him, two arms from him, one bone from them, or the shoulder blade moves back into its place.
Multotiens enim remouetur, quod multotiens fit remotio earum ad quatuor partes.	 "Many parts become dislocated because many parts are pulled away to four parts.
Illa ergo quae remouetur ad posteriora, nominatur Gibbositas.	 "And the one that becomes dislocated at the back is called gibbosity.
Curatio uero eius est, ut consyderes tunc, si Gibbositas accidit a puericia: tunc non est in ea curatio, neque ex ea est sanatio omnino.	 "Treatment of him is to consider when gibbosity comes from childhood; then there's no treatment for it at all.
In illa autem quae accidit a casu, aut percussione, aut similibus illis, iam dixerunt antiqui modos curationis sermone prolixo.	 "But the one that is dislocated from childhood or by force with many others; as they have said in long speech of treatments for them.
Cuius plurimum non redit cum proficuo.	 "It doesn't return to its place when it has been moved much.
Ego uero iam abbreuiaui ex illo, cuius parum excusat a multo eius ex propinquitate mea ad intentionem: et expositione mea qua exposui illud, et formaui instrumentum eius diuerso modo ab eo quo ostenderunt illud, et exposuerunt ipsum.	 "I am now going to release him from that with a bit of effort and care because he has been moved much by my proximity; I will bring out the instrument for this purpose in a different way than they did it before.
Dico ergo, quod in gibbositate quae accidit ab anteriori parte, non est ingenium, neque sanatio ex ea.	 Therefore I say that what strikes off the front part is not an injury, nor healing from it
Et similiter in illa quae fit ad duo latera etiam.	 And similarly to that which happens at two sides as well.
Et non curatur ex eis, nisi illa quae accidit in dorso proprie, cum eo quod ego narro: et est, ut extendatur infirmus super faciem suam super podium aequale prope parietem: et expandatur sub eo stramentum humidum, ut non laedatur pectus eius.	 And not healed from these, unless the one that happens at the back in its own way, as I say: and it is, so extended becomes a weak over the face of his to the bottom equally, front and side: and extends under it the humid rope, so not hurt the breast of theirs.
Deinde ponatur lignum rectum fixum in fouea in terra, in extremitate podii, circiter caput eius: et lignum aliud circiter pedes eius in extremitate altera podii: et minister teneat lignum, et sit non firmatum in fouea.	 Afterwards a straight piece of wood is fixed firmly into the foot on the ground at the extremity of the thigh, around its head; and another piece round its feet at the other extremity of the thigh: and it holds the wood, so that it is not fastened to the foot.
Et minister alter teneat alterum.	 And hold the second one.
Deinde inuolue super caput infirmi, et sub titillicis eius ligamentum lene, firmum: et extende extremitatem ligamenti ad lignum quod est apud caput eius: et liga ipsum in eo.	 Afterwards stretches above the head of a weak one and under its ear ligaments, tight: and extends to the bone which is near the head of him; and binds it on it.
Deinde stringe ligamentum aliud supra anchas eius, et supra genua ipsius, et apud cauillas eius.	 Afterwards strings a different ligament above its ankles, above its knees, at the elbows of theirs.
Deinde aggrega ligamenta omnia, et liga ea in ligno altero quod est apud pedes eius.	 Afterwards gathers all ligaments and binds them to another wood which is near his feet.
Deinde extendat omnis minister ad partem ligni ligamentum, et non remoueantur duo ligna ex locis suis in quibus sunt fixa: uerumtamen non sint firmata, sicut diximus.	 Afterwards extends all ministers to the head of a wood ligament, and two pieces are not removed from where they are fastened as we said.
Et medicus ponat palmas suas super Spondilem cum fortitudine, donec redeat: aut ponat super eam tabulam.	 And the physician puts his palms on the spine with force until he expires or puts a tablet above it.
Deinde annectat super tabulam pedes suos, donec redeat.	 Afterwards takes both feet onto the tablet until he expires.
Si autem non redit per hanc curationem, tunc accipe tabulam cuius longitudo sit circiter tria brachia.	 If however it does not expire by this treatment, then take a tablet of whose length is around three arms.
Et caua in pariete de quo diximus quod est prope infirmum, locum in quem ingrediatur extremitas tabulae.	 And the place at which we said that it is near to weakness, into where the edge of the tablet will go.
Deinde pone medium tabulae super Spondilem.	 Afterwards puts an average sized tablet above the spine.
Et ponat pedes suos medicus super extremitatem alteram.	 And the physician takes both feet of his onto another edge.
Et stringat bene, donec coartetur Spondilis, et redeat ad locum suum.	 "It is firmly held fast in place securely until the vertebrae are ready to be released.
Deinde si uis, operare cum torno quod inuoluitur cum manu tua: et est, ut figas in terram apud caput infirmi in postremo podii duo ligna, quorum longitudo sit brachii unius: et apud caput eius in postremo podii duo ligna.	 "Then, if you're ready to operate with the aid of your other hand; and it is as though you are holding a staff that has two branches, one on each side of its head, at an angle equal to the length of one arm: and in his neck there will be two staffs.
Et sit longitudo quae est inter omne lignum palmus unus: et iam factum est in omni loco foramen, in quo currit tornum: et firmetur lignum omne in terra multum, ne moueatur omnino.	 "And the length of each staff is one palm's breadth; and it has been made at every place through which the arrow runs, so that a branch of wood may be laid down upon the ground everywhere.
Et intromittatur lignum rotundum: et est tornum in quo reuoluitur ligamentum in duobus foraminibus duorum lignorum.	 "And there is a rounded arrow, from which the ligament has been removed through two of its holes.
Et in extremitate eius est foramen, in quo firmatur lignum, cuius longitudo est palmus cum eo quod reuoluitur: et in duobus lignis aliis est similiter illius.	 "And at the end thereof is a hole into which a staff will be firmly fixed; its length being equal to that with which it was used.
Deinde stringe ligamenta quae strinxisti in pectore infirmi torno quod est apud caput eius: et ligamenta quae strinxisti in cruribus eius in torno quod est apud pedes eius.	 "Then, after you have loosened the ligature that was on his neck with your other hand (which is at his head), loosen the ligatures from both of his legs through his thigh.
Deinde stet apud omne tornum minister, qui torqueat manum suam cum licinio, cum quo reuoluitur tornum: et medicus aequet Spondilem, secundum quod diximus.	 "Then he will administer the arrow that is bent with your hand and the ligature through which it was shot; and the physician will treat the vertebra as we have said.
Haec est forma torni, quae sequitur.	 "This is the shape of the arrow that follows.
Deinde postquam redit Spondilis, et aequatur locus, tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum exiccatiuum cum albumine oui.	 "After you have treated the vertebra and made it equal to its place, then prepare an excitant with alum.
Deinde stuppam.	 "Then end.
Postea pone supra emplastrum astellam ex tabula, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, aut circiter eos.	 "After that, place a star above the excitant made of alum with its length equal to three fingers or extending from them.
Et longitudo eius quantitas quae capiat locum Gibbositatis, et super partem Spondilis sanae.	 "Its length will be such as to cover the space between the vertebrae and above the healthy vertebra without injury.
Deinde ligetur cum ligamento quod diximus.	 "Then he will tie with it the ligature that we have mentioned.
Et utatur infirmus nutrimento subtili, donec sanetur.	 "And feed him with a subtle nourishment until he recovers.
Quod si remaneat quiddam eminentiae in loco in fine sanationis: tunc oportet, ut administrentur medicinae quae mollificant, et leniunt, cum administratione tabulae quam narrauimus tempore longo.	 "When a wound has healed in its proper place:" then it is necessary that the medical remedies which have calmed down and relaxed be given out.
Et iam administratur in illo lamina plumbi.	 And when they are administered on top of the soaked linen,
Et quandoque accidit eminentia in postremo Spondilium dorsi: et putatur per eam dislocatio, et est illud os quod iam eminet.	 When a dislocation occurs at the end of the spine:" then it is necessary to perform the displacement and use the remedy that has already worked
Quare non oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei cum hac medicina: fortasse enim accidere faciet mortem.	 Therefore, it is not necessary for a treatment of this type to be applied when there is an attempt at self-preservation because such a treatment might cause death.
¶ De curatione Anchae dislocatae.	 Of the dislocation of the Ankh bones
Caput XXXII.	 Head Xii.
Scias, quod iuncturae Anchae, et iuncturae humeri, non accidit, nisi dislocatio tantum: neque accidit eis quod accidit reliquis iuncturis ex remotione parua, et concauitate.	 Note that the dislocation of the Ankh bones and the dislocation of the arm did not occur unless there was a displacement only, and they also didn't happen to those who experienced other dislocations far away from them or in conjunction with it.
Et iunctura quidem Anchae dislocatur secundum quatuor partes.	 The dislocation of the Ankh bones happens according to four parts.
Quod est, quia dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 This is because it is dislocated towards front and towards back
Et plurimum quidem dislocatur ad interiora: et parum dislocatur ad anteriora, et ad posteriora.	 Furthermore, it happens the most that it is dislocated towards the inside: and least of all towards the front and towards the back.
Et curatio dislocationis eius ad interiora, est: quia quando tu coniungis crus infirmi sanum cum infirmo, est longius: et est genu eius eminens plus quam sani, et non potest infirmus duplicare pedem suum apud inguen: et est locus qui sequitur inguen apostematus apostemate calido, propterea, quod caput coxae iam peruenit illic.	 When the dislocation is towards the inside, then its care is as follows:" when you join together a sick body with an unwell one, it will be longer; and the leg of him who has had it will rise more than that which is healthy, and he cannot make his foot come back to its place in front because it was dislocated near the hip: and there is a location following behind the other's head, hot, therefore, so as soon as the coxae's head reached there.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad exteriora est, quod sunt accidentia eius contraria istis accidentibus.	 The mark of him who was dislocated towards the outside is that his accidents were contrary to these accidents.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad anteriora, est, quia expandit crus sanum secundum complementum: uerumtamen non duplicat ipsum absque dolore qui est in genu: et si conatur ad ambulandum, non potest super illud ad anteriora: et retinetur urina eius, et apostematur inguen eius, et apud ambulationem est calcatio eius super calcaneum.	 The mark of him who was dislocated towards the front is that his leg expanded when it came into contact with a healthy body and did not have two legs without pain in its knee; if he comes to walk, then he cannot come back to the place in front because it was dislocated near the hip: there will be urine held onto him, and his head turned backwards towards the other's head, and at walking he is held down on the heel.
Et signum eius cui accidit dislocatio ad posteriora est, ut non expandat genu, neque possit duplicare ipsum antequam duplicet inguen: et est crus eius etiam breuius altero: et inguen est mollificatum, et est caput coxae apud locum ilii.	 The dislocation of his finger happened to the posterior side, so that it cannot expand (open out), nor can he double-joint (touch) it before it is doubled by itself; and his thumb is short as well: and his little finger is also shorter than the other one; and his little finger has been made soft, and there is a small protrusion of his thigh at that place.
Reductio uero huius dislocationis specierum est, ut consyderes tunc, si dislocatio est uetusta, quae iam antiquatur cum habente ipsam.	 The reduction or restoration of the dislocated finger is as follows: if it is a fresh dislocation and has not yet healed with its possessor, then it must be reduced by someone else; but if already healed when possessed, no one may reduce or touch it except in its own place where it was dislocated.
Deinde si tu administres reductionem eius, et remanet secundum dispositionem suam: tunc non est in ea curatio omnino.	 Therefore if you administer the reduction to him and it remains according to his disposition, then at that time there is no one's care for it.
Non ergo oportet, ut praesumptio fiat ei penitus.	 Therefore, he should not be granted favor with a whip.
In illo autem cuius dislocatio est recens, et est ex una specierum quatuor dislocationis: tunc propera ad hoc, ut uoluas iuncturam, et extendas ipsam ad interiora et ad exteriora, et moueas eam dextra et sinistra: fortasse enim redit, et non indiget alia cura.	 In that case where there is one dislocation and four fingers are dislocated, then the reduction should be applied to him in this way: you will close his joint (the finger), stretch it towards the interior and exterior; move his thumb and little finger from both sides; if he has reduced them himself, no other care must be taken for them.
Si autem non redit hoc modo, tunc oportet, ut praepares ministrum fortem, et extendat crus eius ab inferiori parte: aut cum manibus suis, aut cum ligamento, quod ligetur super crus eius supra genu: et minister alius extendat manum eius desuper, ita ut intromittat manus suas sub titillicis eius.	 If not done in this way then you must prepare a strong instrument and stretch his thigh from the lower part; either by using your hands or with some ligature that is tied above his thigh so as to reach under him, when he comes down upon him (the injured limb).  Another man extends his hand over him so it reaches under its own weight.
Deinde stringat cum ligamento leni super radicem coxae, et teneat extremitatem ligamenti alterius.	 Then with the help of a ligature gently stretched from above his hip-bone, and holds onto the extremity of the other man's ligature.
